records.title: Tel Marsha is part of the well known cave complex of Beit Gubrin some fifteen kilometres east of Kiryat Gat.

descriptions.value: The many caves in the area are all man made, cut into the chalk between the 1st and 10th century B.C.E. The inhabitants of the area preferred to live in the caves as it offered them protection both from the heat in the summer and the cold of the winter. The semi-nomadic Israelite tribes also felt that the caves offered protection from the local Philistines and Cananites. The caves date the development of the start of the monarchy when the kingdom was unified under King David. Some of the caves are spectacular by their size and dimension. Many caves were used to produce olive oil and one recently excavated cave showed that it had been used for the rearing of doves. The underground complex of Tel Marsha covers some 320 dunams underground, while the infrastructure above ground is only some 24 dunams. Photo shows: the entrance to the oil press in one of the cave complexes.

Land Day, which commemorates the killing of six Israeli Arabs in the Galilee in 1976, was observed with relative quiet today. Israeli Arabs have observed Land Day each year following the death of the Arabs by police and security forces following violent riots over land expropriation. The killing of two traffic policemen in Hadera earlier in the day ensured that there would be law and order, as the police were in no mood to see breaches of the peace. The only scuffle reported was between supporters of rival Islamic movements over the participation of women in a Land Day March in Shfaram, in the Galilee. Here in Shfaram many carried photographs of the deportees and shouted slogans against the Rabin government. Municipal services in the Arab sector were closed down and many shops and businesses closed in the morning. Photo shows: hundreds of Israeli Arabs marching towards Sahhnin, where three of the Israeli Arabs killed are buried.

Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek has threatened to cancel the forthcoming 25th anniversary celebration of Jerusalem's reunification following the 1967 Six Day War. The mayor, always an outspoken critic of government poIicy, has threatened the cancellation of the celebration because of the situation created by Jewish settlement in the East Jerusalem village of Silwan. Kollek was concerned about the image abroad as well as the extra burden that has been put on the security forces to maintain law and order. Today thousands of Jewish left-wing peace activists joined with Arab villagers in Silwan to protest the Jewish settlers effort to take over their homes. The protest went off without incident even though there was a very small right-wing counter protest. Photo shows preparations for left wing protestors to arrive in Silwan for a demonstration against the Jewish settlers who wants to settle in Arab villages in East Jerusalem.

records.title: Two new Nahal settlements were established near Sakhnin near this Galilee Arab village.

descriptions.value: One of them, Atzmon, is populated by members of Garin Moran and is affiliated with Ihud Hakvutzot Vehakibutzim. The other is Eshhar and belongs to the Kibbutz Hameuhad movement. The soldiers-farmers are living in tents, but construction has begun on permament housing. A Defence Ministry source said no land had been expropriated for the new settlements as both are on state-owned land. During the last three years, five Nahal settlements have been established in Galilee and two more will be added in coming weeks. Photo shows: The official ceremony of oening the new Nahal settlement Atzmon.

Last week 180,000 Arabs living in areas close to the Green Line were issued with gas masks. Concern has been expressed that gas masks could be used by rioting Arabs for protection against tear gas. Arabs living in the West Bank and Gaza have been trying, through the High Court, to make the army distribute gas masks to all Arabs. The army has been against such a distribution not only for the reason stated above, bud also because there is nobody who is prepared to pay for the cost of such distribution, The gas masks distributed to Israeli Jews and Arabs have been paid for by the National Insurance Institute from money paid in to a fund by citizens for the equipment. Today Jews and Arabs in rural parts of the country have started to receive gas masks. Photo shows: an Bedouin from the Israeli Arab village of Beit Zarzir collecting his gas mask. Many Bedouin from the village have served in the Israeli Army.

The next four months will see the all important harvesting of the grape crop. Thousands of tons of grapes will be used by Israel's well known vinyards to create many fine wines. Many more Israelis are new beginning to drink more wine and experts are increasing year by year. It is too early to say if this year's crop will be better than usual, as the grape vines are subject to many diseases that can ruin a promising season. Photo shows: one of the first bunch of grapes being taken frem a vinyard in the Lachish region of the northern Negev, known for its grape production. The outstanding Lachish grapes are generally sold for eating rather than wine production. They are one of the first of the grape crop in Israel to be sent for export to Europe.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון בהילולת הבבא סאלי בתאריך 4 בינואר 2014, ד' בשבט התשע"ד , בנתיבות. בבא (אבא) סאלי (ישראל) אבו חצירא (1889-1984) היה רב במרוקו ובישראל שהיה מקובל כעושה ניסים ומביא ברכה. לאחר פטירתו ירש אותו בנו, בבא ברוך. ביום פטירת הבבא סאלי, ד' בשבט, נערכת מאז 1985 הילולה סביב קברו בנתיבות. ההילולה משכה בתחילה בעיקר יוצאי מרוקו שבאו ביום הפטירה. במשך השנים גדלה והתרחבה ההילולה וכיום היא נמשכת יומיים ובאים אליה למעלה מרבע מיליון מאמינים מרוב שדרות הציבור. הילולת הבבא סאלי היא הגדולה שבהילולות שעל קברי צדיקים. במשך השנים נבנו מבנים גדולים על הקבר וכיום, בניגוד לבעבר, קיימת הפרדה מוקפדת בין גברים ונשים. הקרן הקיימת נטעה פארק, בצורת חמסה, מסביב לקבר שבימי ההילולה מתקיים בו שוק גדול. בתצלומים ניתן לראות את התפילה שנערכת באוהל הגדול שהוקם על יד המצבה, ארוחות שמתקיימות במהלך ימי ההילולה, תצלומים מהשוק שמתקיים בפארק קק"ל ואת פולחן זריקת הנרות.תפילה אל מול המצבה: רוב הבאים מתחילים בתפילה ב"אוהל" הגדול שהוקם על המצבה.קוסקוס ומופלטות: רבים מביאים אוכל ומקיימים סעודות עליזות. נשים רבות מחלקות אוכל וממתקים לקהל וגברים מגישים משקאות חריפים.שוק של מצוות: באזור הקבר מוכרים אנשי הבבא ברוך נרות, מאחיה (עראק) קדוש, שמן מקודש, ספרים ושאר דברים המביאים ברכה(בעבר היו מוכרים גם בקבוקים עם מים קדושים). ביום ההילולה הראשון, ערב יום הפטירה, מתקיימת תהלוכה המוליכה ספר תורה מביתו של הבבא אל הקבר. אנשים משלמים עבור הזכות לשאת את ספר התורה. השוק הגדול: הפארק של קק"ל הופך בימי ההילולה לשוק ענק, שמוכרים בו כל מיני חפצים הנושאים את דמות הבבא סאלי, תכשיטים, כיסויי ראש לנשים וכיפות לגברים, כלי בית ושאר חפצים ודוכני מזון.פולחן זריקת הנרות: פולחן הנרות הוא פולחן חדש שהתפתח עם השנים. בשנת 1987 בעת שהיתו של דנצ'ו בהילולה, אנשים ונשים הדליקו נרות על בתוך האוהל שנבנה על המצבה. עם השנים, רבו הנרות ואי אפשר היה לשהות באוהל בגלל העשן לשם כך, התקינו מיתקן שריפה ממתכת מחוץ לאוהל, ליד היציאה, ואנשים הדליקו את הנרות בתוכו. כשרבו המדליקים, היה מסוכן להתקרב למיתקן מחמת האש החזקה ולכן גידרו אותו והמדליקים נאלצו להשליך את הנרות הדולקים מרחוק פנימה. כך החל פולחן הנרות; מדליקים נר, מבקשים בקשה וזורקים פנימה. אם מצליחים לקלוע, הבקשה תתקבל. בשנים האחרונות יש מיתקנים נפרדים לנשים ולגברים, אך מיתקן הנשים פופולארי יותר ורק גברים מעטים זורקים במיתקן שלהם.

records.title: מראה כללי של בתי הכפר ליפתא.

descriptions.value: תצלום שבו נראה הכפר ליפתא מדרום לצפון: הדפס כסף, שחור לבן. על-פי החותמות שהוטבעו בגב התצלום, הוא הופק על ידי הצלם א. מ. ניומן (E. M. Newman) מסוכנות העתונות האמריקאית Publishers Photo Service, New York והופץ באמצעות סוכנות International Newsreel, גם היא בניו יורק. על התצלום אין ציון תאריך, אך יש להניח כי הוא הופק בשנות השלושים של המאה העשרים.

תצלום שבו נראה הצייר מאוריצי גוטליב עומד בסטודיו שלו, לצד גיסו ד. טרגרמן (Tregerman) ושתי אחיותיו: הדפס חלבון מודבק על גבי כרטיס בגודל 118X134 מ"מ. במרכז התצלום, נראה ציורו של גוטליב: "שיילוק וג'סיקה", ממוסגר. גוטליב עצמו (ראשון משמאל) עומד על יד כן שעליו מונח ציור דיוקן נוסף, ומחזיק בידו מכחול. בגב הכרטיס, נכתב בעפרון תיאורו, בידי אחיו, ליאופולד גוטליב, תוך ציון שנת הצילום: 1874. ככל הנראה, טעה גוטליב, כיוון שהציור המוצג בתצלום הושלם רק בשנת 1876. כן נוספה הערה בכתב ידו של ד"ר אברהם שבדרון, כי תצלום זה נתרם לספרייה הלאומית בחודש אדר ב' תרפ"ד (מארס 1924) על ידי לאופולד גוטליב.

records.title: ירושלים: מאה שערים, חצרות בתי אונגרין.

descriptions.value: תצלום ובו נראה קהל פועלים חוגג בעצרת שנערכה לכבוד חג הפועלים, אחד במאי, במתחם "המכתש" בפאתי שכונת בורוכוב (כיום גבעתיים). בשמאל התצלום נראים במה ומסך שהוצבו במקום, והם מלמדים על מסכת שהוצגה לפני הקהל. התצלום נדפס בתבנית של גלויית Real photo וכותרתו נכתבה על גבי התשליל. על התצלום לא צויין שם הצלם.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-30 במרץ 2018, המתעדים את התחנה השתיים-עשרה בפסיון של ישוע, בה נראה ישוע כל הצלב. זאת כחלק משחזור הפסיון הנערך על ידי ההודים-קונקונים, ביום שישי של השבוע הקדוש בירושלים.

גלויה מחולקת ובה הדפס רשת מתצלום שחור לבן של הקצה הצפוני ברחוב ביאליק, תל אביב. בחזית התמונה נראה הגן שסביב בית חיים נחמן ביאליק (מימין) וברקע, בניין עיריית תל אביב, רחוב ביאליק 27, (בית סקורה). במקום המיועד לבול, צויין כי הגלויה נדפסה בצ'כוסלובקיה. גלויה זו לא היתה בשימוש, ולא צויינו עליה פרטים כלשהם באשר לזהות הצלם או תאריך הצילום. ככל הנראה, היא הופקה באמצע שנות השלושים של המאה העשרים. גלויה זו לא היתה בשימוש.

records.title: صورة منشور المهدي السوداني لاحبابه يحذرهم فيه عن ضرب الاسلحة النارية بالديم.

descriptions.value: זוג עותקים שונים מאותה גלויה, ובה הדפס רשת מתצלום שחור לבן המציג את הכניסה אל קמפוס האוניברסיטה העברית, גבעת רם, ירושלים (כיום: קרית אדמונד י' ספרא). באחד מעותקי הגלויה נצבע הדימוי בתהליך ההדפסה. בגלויה נראים בניין המנהלה (בניין שרמן) ואחריו בניי הפקולטה למדעי הרוח, סמוך להשלמת בנייתם, ולפניהם אוטובוס וכלי רכב נוספים. על הגלויה לא צויינו שם הצלם או תאריך הצילום, אך יש להניח כי דימוי זה הופק עוד לפני השלמת בנייתה של תחנת האוטובוסים בכניסה אל הקמפוס, בשנת 1961, אך כבר לאחר חנוכת הקמפוס, בשנת 1958. גלויות אלו לא היו בשימוש, ועל-פי הנדפס בגבן, הן הופקו במסגרת סדרת "פוטונה" - Photona של חברת פלפוט (Palphot, Herzlia) בישראל, כנראה בסוף שנות החמישים או בראשית שנות השישים של המאה העשרים. בגב הגלוי

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Life in Urmia during WWI. Learning to read and write with Jewish teacher and with Assyrian-Christians teachers whose language resembles Aramaic of Azarbaijan Jews. Description of difficulties endured while migrating to Israel through Baghdad and Beirut.

records.title: Jewish Education in Egypt in the 1920s and 1930s.

descriptions.value: Born in Cairo, Egypt in 1936. Secular studies in a Jewish school and religious studies in Ahava Veachava yeshiva, founded by father. Active in yeshiva education committee, responsible for student attendance. French high school. Influence of uncle who studied mathematics at Hebrew University and brother Yizhak Shave, once candidate for presidency of Israel. Visits by Rabbi Isaac Nissim to their home. Zionist family. Visit to Israel with sister, 1947. Immigration to Israel, 1957. Mathematics studies at Hebrew University. Student of Prof. Avraham Frankel.

records.title: Absorption of Jews from Arab Countries in Israel.

descriptions.value: Of Kurdish descent. Discusses: language spoken at home; standard of living; friends; religion; encountering, through academia, people of Oriental origin; feelings towards social and economic manifestations of ethnic problems in Israel; contribution Oriental Jews have made to settlement and army in Israel; gaps and integration in education; gap between Eastern and Western intellectual criterion; reasons for little productive cultural expression amongst Oriental Jews; need for social integration; marriage between people of different ethnicities; responsibility of state in affirmative action to help Oriental Jews; responsibility of political parties; public positions would like to fill - and likelihood of this being realized; his education; impact Six Day War had on ethnic conflict.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Saqqez, Iran in 1929. Life in Azarbaijan. Reasons for aliyah of entire community. Different transitional camps for Iraqi and Iranian immigrants. Help from Jewish community in Teheran. Aliyah, 1950. Father provided statistical details of Azarbaijan Jews to President Yitzhak Ben-Zvi.

records.title: Ethiopian Jewry: Historical Traditions, Aliya and Absorption.

descriptions.value: Born in ethiopia, 1946. Life in Kefar Batya. Studies and curriculum. Reasons for immigration to Israel by Ethiopian children. Purpose of return to Ethiopia. Assistance given by graduates of Kefar Batya to other Ethiopian Jews immigrating to Israel.

records.title: Video Interviews with Holocaust Survivors Living in the United States.

descriptions.value: Born in 1922 in Miechon, Poland; during the war he was sent to: Krakow; Pionke Concentration Camp (near Radom); Auschwitz; Buna; Buchenwald; Kravinkel; was liberated in 1945 from Buchenwald; spent five years in Munich; came to the USA in 1951; lived first in Little Rock, Arkansas and Arron, Ohio before moving to New-Jersey.

records.title: Jewish Victims of the Generals' Regime in Argentina and the Attitude of Jewish Institutions in Argentina and Israel, 1976-1983 - Gabriela Lotersztain interviews.

descriptions.value: El matrimonio Frigoli es un matrimnio mixto,. Eran activos politícamente en Buenos Aires, antes del golpe militar. Se sintieron perseguidos, y fueron a vivir a la provincia de Salta, allí fueron detenidos por la Policia Federal a fines de 1975 y trasladados a Buenos Aires. Entonces tenian respectivamente 22 y 23 anos. En el curso de 1976 se los liberó y vieron como única solución, ir a vivir a Israel. Quien se ocupó al principio de los trámites fue el rabino Shobel, que en su opinión los trató groseramente y los discriminó, y ellos creen, que procedió asi porqu eran pareja mixta.. Posteriormente se encaminaron al enviado para Inmigración ,Daniel Recanati que actuo con corrección y getionó su viaje a Israel.. Con todas las dificultades que pasaron consideran que el viaje a Israel les salvo sus vidas. Les pagaron el pasaje, y les dieron los primeros medios de subsistencia. Pero por un tiempo estuvieron en un Mercaz Klitá ( Centro de absorción de inmigrantes a Israel ), en el sur del pais donde no había latinoamericanos, solo rusos, etiopes y otros, y no tenían con quien hablar y con quien comunicarse. Luego se trasladaron a Beer Sheva y ahí la organización de inmigrantes latinoamericanod, la OLEI, y una pareja argentina que conocieron les ayudaron y les fue un poco mas fácil. Ella también recibió una beca de estudios y él recibió trabajo en una fábrica de bromo. Les nacieron dos hijos, pero en resumen ellos no comprendieron al pais y a su gente y tampoco gozaron de apoyo y comprensión suficientes..Despues de vicisitudes diversas, a los cinco anos dejaron el país y regresaron a la Argentina. No estuvieron interesados en dar mas detalles, ni proporcionar sus nombres propios para no ser identificados.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Kurdistan, 1930. Aliya, 1950. Beit Lid transit camp. Binyamina. Pardes Hanna. Patish settlement in southern Israel. Settlement of Negev.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in 1927 in Czernowitz, Rumania to wealthy bourgeois family living in region annexed to Soviet Union in 1940. German orientation and spoken language in parental home. Father, active Zionist, arrested for activities during time of Soviet occupation. Czernowitz Jews relocating to Bucharest during that period. Family registered on aliya waiting list for several years. Senior position in foreign trade office in Bucharest required communist party membership, delaying immigration. Forged age in her certifictes. Aliya with parents and grandmother, 1951. Leaving almost all property behind. Welcomed by Israeli uncle. Poor first impressions of Israel in Shaar Haaliya. Using connections to obtain shack in Bat Galim, where family lived for one year. Socialist background facilitating membership in Mapai, helping to secure job with Industry and Commerce Ministry in Haifa.

records.title: Jewish Life in Arab Countries; Jewish Life in Middle Eastern Countries.

descriptions.value: נולד בבצרה, ולמד בבית ספר כי"ח עד לשנת 1919. עבד בין השנים 1929-1933 כפקיד מכס בבגדד. דן בתנועת התיאוסופיים: השתלטותם על ועד העדה, הויכוחים הפנימיים וביטול התנועה ב1934. מציין את שמות ראשי העדה, ואת שם המועדון היהודי שנוסד ב1949.#The Jewish community in Basra; Jewish education and communal organization; the Theosophist Movement.

records.title: Jewish Victims of the Generals' Regime in Argentina and the Attitude of Jewish Institutions in Argentina and Israel, 1976-1983 - Gabriela Lotersztain interviews.

descriptions.value: Leon Klenicki is an ADL Rabbi#El rabino León Klenicki se desempeñaba en el departamento de dialogo interreligioso en la ADL (Liga Antidifamatoria) de Estados Unidos. En la ADL trabajaba en forma conjunta con el rabino Morton Rosenthal, representante de Latinoamérica de dicha institución, sobre la cuestión de los desaparecidos de Argentina. El rabino Klenicki estaba en contacto con el nuncio apostólico en Argentina Pío Laghi con quien trabajaba sobre la cuestión de los presos y que lo ayudó especialmente en el caso Timerman. También tenía diálogo con el cardenal Aramburu quien se refería a los desaparecidos como “propaganda del comunismo internacional”. En relación al gobierno argentino, mantenía reuniones con el ministro del interior general Harguindeguy. Mantenía intercambios de información con la comunidad católica de Estados Unidos y de Argentina. Menciona que la ALD consideraba que la dictadura argentina era un gobierno de corte fascista o nazi y por lo tanto constituía un peligro para la comunidad judía. Relata que la ADL tenía una posición “mas agresiva” que otras organizaciones judías internacionales en lo que hace a la presión nacional e internacional. Destaca que la acción de la ADL fue crucial a la hora de liberar prisioneros además de confeccionar lista de detenidos. Con el cardenal Antonio Quarracino afirma tenía una relación fluida y por ende podía hablar abiertamente de las violaciones a los derechos humanos. En relación a la DAIA cree que podría haber tenido una actitud más enérgica “ por su sola razón de ser judía”.

records.title: Rescue of Jewish Children in Hungary from 1944 until Liberation.

descriptions.value: Studies at the religious elementary school in Budapest and at the rabbinical seminary. Organizing the forging of Aryan documents needed by members of the Zionist Youth movement to remain in Hungary or enter Romania. Describes aid from the Red Cross, the Swedish, Swiss, and Portuguese embassies, and the Vatican, which supplied documents to Jewish refugees. Details the roles of Dr. Cuomio, Joshayahu Rosenblum, Dr. Grazunger, Dr. Aryeh Levi and Ezra Gross in organizing the youth movement and children's houses.

records.title: Israel and the Eastern European States at the Time of the Six-Day War.

descriptions.value: Served as Israeli consul in Poland until 1964 and Yugoslavia until 1965 - up to end of diplomatic relations, June 13, 1967. Discusses: diplomatic relations between Israel and Yugoslavia in trade, culture, science and politics; contact with government officials of different levels; Yugoslavia's position on Israel on eve of Six Day War; statements of support for Arabs and against Israeli force; meetings with members of Foreign Ministry and other public figures, in days between outbreak of war and end of diplomatic relations; atmosphere; unique action taken by Yugoslavia and Soviet Bloc on issue of war between Israel and Arab countries; pressure on Yugoslavia, resulting in severed relations with Israel; reasons for Yugoslavia's inflexibility; own statements when informed of severed relations; feelings on Six Day War among Yugoslavian population; position of media; Yugoslavian Jewish community - organization, institutions, governmental ties, financing, ties to Israel, publications, relations with Israeli Consulate, relations with general population; government position on ties between Jewish youth and Israel; reactions in Jewish community to Israeli victory; feelings on Israel amongst upper-classes; motives behind Yugoslavian Jews wanting to make Aliyah.

records.title: Reminiscences about My Father's House: Programs Recorded by Kol Yisrael.

descriptions.value: Member of Maayan Baruch. Discusses: childhood in Aleppo; father's employment; source of surname; ancient neighbourhood; Aleppo Jews throughout the world; brothers who made Aliyah and those who immigrated to Mexico; encounter in Kibbutz with brother he had never seen; similarity and differences between them; history of Aleppo Jews - prayers; food; knowledge of Arabic and French; cultural encounters; family traditions; Aliyah; ethnic discrimination; matchmaking; relations with Arabs; ethnic differences in Israel.

Front Text - 137Edit. A. Scavo#Production period - before 1935#Front Period - UNKNOWN#Category - Synagogues#Description - This horizontal postcard depicts a photograph of the Magen Abraham Synagogue in Beirut. This important synagogue is situated in Wadi Abu Jamil district, the former Jewish quarter in central Beirut. It was erected around 1925, thanks to the contributions of a Sasoon family member who named the synagogue after his father. The Synagogue stills exists nowadays but it has been seriously damaged during the 1982 Lebanon war. The photograph depicts the interior of the Synagogue which looks like a church's structure: a large prayer hall flanked by two arched corridors faced the central holy arch, called Hekhal (a generally ornamental closet which contains the Torah scrolls; located in most case in the direction of Jerusalem). The Hekhal is closed by a Parohet (curtain) and on its top hang the Tablets of Law (two pieces of stone inscribed with the Ten Commandments). Opposite to it appears#Stamp Place on postcard - top right corner of back#Stamp Origin - Lebanon (Republic)#Stamp Period - c. 1935#Post office marks Origin - Lebanon (Country), Marjayoun (City)#Post office marks Languages Of Text - French

Canetti, Andrinople 26#Production period - 1912#Front Period - 1912#Category - Jewish school#Description - This horizontal postcard depicts a photograph of Jewish boys at gym class in the school of the 'Israelite Universal Alliance' of Andrianople. records.title: Efforts to Help Soviet Jewry during World War II (Rescue Via Teheran).

descriptions.value: Aliyah in 1922. Journey to Teheran in 1942. The Jewish Agency's representation in Teheran. Links with the Joint and the parcel project. Dealing with Jewish refugees from the USSR. The Teheran Children. Connections with the British authorities.

records.title: Efforts to Help Soviet Jewry during World War II (Rescue Via Teheran).

descriptions.value: Journey to Iran in 1942. Organization of Jewish self-defense in Iran. The Joint's role in sending parcels to refugees. Meeting in Baghdad with Enzo Sereni. Smuggling of deserters from General Anders' Army to Palestine. Jewish youth in Iran.

records.title: Im Judenviertel von Sana'a. - Volk auf der Straße. (Phot. H. Burchardt.) Orient-Verlag, Berlin.

descriptions.value: Text on the back -Postkarte:In der Landschaft Yemen in Südarabien lebten noch vor kurzem etwa 50.000 Juden. Fortwährende Verfolgungen seitens der fanatischen Einwohner, die sich zudem in stetem Aufruhr gegen die türkische Regierung befinden, und die elende wirtschafliche Lage, die sich oft bis zu Hungersnöten steigert, haben diese jüdische Bevölkerung dezimiert. Gegenwärtig versucht es der Rest, sich durch die Auswanderung nach Palästina zu retten, dem nächsten Gebiet, wo Juden unter günstigeren Verhältnissen leben. Diese Einwanderung anspruchsloser, arbeitwilliger und intelligenter Leute bringt dem allgemeinen jüdischen Kolonisationswerk in Palästina, das zurzeit mehr als 40 landwirtschaftliche Ansiedlungen mit ca. 12.000 Einwohnern umfasst, in den verschiedensten Hinsichten ganz außerordentlichen Nutzen, so daß die Rettung der yemenitischen Juden gleichzeitig auch dem grossen Felde der jüdischen Palästina-Bestrebun#Back Printed Text Translation - Postcard:(Approximate translation) In the region of Yemen, in South Arabia, lived still recently about 50,000 Jews. The continual pursuits from the fanatic inhabitants, in constant riots against the Turkish government, as well as the miserable economic situation which often increases up to starvation, have decimated this Jewish population. At the present time, the rest of the population tries to get saved by emigration to Palestine, the next area, where Jews live under more favorable conditions. The emigration of undemanding, work-willing and intelligent people activates the Jewish colony in Palestine, which covers now more than 40 agricultural settlements with approx. 12,999 inhabitants. Thus, the rescue of Yemenite Jews as well as the large field of the Jewish colony came out right. For these reasons, the association 'Ezra' makes considerable means for the removal of the Yemenites and for their maintenance in the first time.#Production period - ca. 1910#Front Period - ca. 1910#Category - Jewish types#Description - This horizontal postcard depicts a photograph of a crowd of Jewish men and boys in the Jewish quarter of Sana'a. They apparently came out of the Synagogue on Shabbat (day of rest in Judaism fixed on the seventh day of the Jewish week) or on Hagim (Jewish Festivals) according among others things to their white clothes: working clothes were, by decree, dark, while those worn on the Shabbat were festively white. Most of them wear the Tallit (Jewish prayer shawl) on their tunic which is usually called Shamle in Sana'a. It is sometimes worn as a scarf along the body, sometimes folded on the shoulder as we can see on the children of the right foreground. They all wear the traditional low dark felt cap (Kufiyeh) and have payot (long side curls in hair); Yemenite Jews often sport payot and refer to them as signs (Simanim in Hebrew) which differentiated them from Yemeni

(Part A) Born Ukraine, 1892. Discusses: life in Ukraine; Hebrew studies; bo she remembers; Russian studies, especially Russian Literature; establishment of Russian-language school; Aliyah, 1921; request to open popular university; establishment of adult-oriented Russian library, 1923; funding; organization; readers; publishers she worked with; distribution of books; young authors; bookstores in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv; popular books, 1920's; readers; unpublished books; 1920 bohemians; 'Moriah' up until financial crisis, 1929; attracting buyers; her opinion of Bialik as author; Bialik and Rabnitzki's joint work; establishment of 'Masada' publishers, 1932; their publications; Bialik's ties to 'Masada'. (Part B) History of Moriah and it's branches. Discusses: Moriah and foreign Droinov; Hebrew literary circles; economic crisis, 1929, and effect on publication; story of publication of 'Encyclopedia Izrael', people from 'Masada' involved; distribution of Gordon's Bible; 'Encyclopedia Neurim'; cooperation with 'Mosad Bialik'; financial problems during WWII; books printed and sold by 'Masada' during war; end of war; publication of 'Atidot'; other publishers; cooperation with 'Shteibel', 1939; 'Moadon Hasefer', 1943; expanding to other areas, ie. textbooks; working with Rabbi Berlin on publication of Talmud Encyclopedia; business ethics. (Part C) Summary of accomplishments of 'Masada' publications, up until issua Hebrew Encyclopedia ('Encyclopedia Ivrit'); character of Ahad Ha'am;#dedication to publication of books; working towards creation of Hebrew Encyclopedia; first edition, 1949; opening 'Masada' branch in Jerusalem; enlisting help from intellectuals to decide on contents of Encyclopedia; number of volumes; editors; printing; people involved in project; proofreading; criteria for admitting information; number of copies; signatories; establishment of 'Hachevra La Hotzaat Encyclopedia' and 'Hachevra Shel D'foos Masada'; publication of books in languages other than Hebrew; Encyclopedia Judaica, 1951; contact with authors; textbooks and dictionaries from 'Masada'; present plans; her successors; competition in field; her work in comparison to publication today; today's readers in comparison to past readers.

records.title: Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: Served as chaplain in US Air Force in Germany, 1945. Discusses: first encounter with survivors, Furth German; burial of stray bones in Furth cemetery; restoration of Furth cemetery, and restoration of synagogue with help of German prisoners; High Holidays; survivors considering going to Palestine or America; replacing chaplain Abe Klausner; providing D.Ps with relief supplies; freedom given by Army to help D.Ps; discord between D.Ps of different backgrounds; involvement in package program; black market; soldiers' gestures of kindness; reaction of Army to his work; contact with, and perception of JDC; Jewish Agency; involvement in Aliyah Bet; D.Ps mixed feelings about going to Palestine.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Krakow, Poland. Holocaust survivor. Immigration to Israel motivated by Holocaust experience. Beriha, underground rescue activities. Deportation to Cyprus. Arrival in Israel, 1949 and induction into IDF. Marriage. Construction worker for 15 years. Administrative position in Housing Ministry. Accomplished all without government assistance.

records.title: Jewish Resistance in Slovakia during World War II.

descriptions.value: Discusses: work as doctor for army in Bratislava; people he knew from, and work they did in, 'Hashomer Hatzair'; forging documents; buying and transporting arms; smuggling Jews from Poland to Slovakia (1943-44); Dr. Maiar's role in saving Jewish children; period of the war; Jews he encountered; making aliyah, 1949. (His wife takes part in interview, offering additional information). Born southern Slovakia, 1907. Received Zionist education. Completed medical studies, 1932. Served in army, 1932-35. Discusses: life under Germans; attempt at making aliyah, 1940; work as doctor in villages, 1941-44; partisan activity in eastern Slovakia, 1942-43; gendarmes.

records.title: The Educational Systems in Jewish DPS Camps in Germany and Austria 1945-1951.

descriptions.value: Born 1920 New Jersey. Pilgrimage to Palestine in 1925 for opening of Hebrew University. Return to U.S. a year later because of health. Aliya in 1937. Studied in Gymnasia Ivrit and then in Yechiel Halperin teachers seminar. 1939 went to 21st Zionist congress, and then with parents to U.S., where stayed for duration of war. Return to Palestine 1946. Sent in July 1947 to Austria as part of teachers emissaries. Became secretary of Eretz Israel delegation. Was liaison between delegation and official bodies- American army, IRO and Joint. Mostly worked on Aliya from Austria. Left Austria in 1950.

records.title: Efforts to Help Soviet Jewry during World War II (Rescue Via Teheran).

descriptions.value: Attempts to cross the Polish-Romanian frontier after the outbreak of war. Imprisonment in a Soviet camp. Release and journey south via Samarkand to Guma. Unsuccessful effort to get to Teheran with the Polish army. Contacts with Palestine via Teheran. Illegal return to Poland.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: born 11/03/1910 in Biala-Bielitz . Trade school. Training in his father's business. From 1939 on various camps in Slovakia. Emigrated to Palestine via Hungary. Explanations for the name Naor. Arrival in Israel in 1946. Reports about various camps, change in schooling, daily life in the camp and beginning deportation. Building of the deportation camp Nowaki. About the camp. Slovak uprising in 1944, occupation by Germans, mass murder of Jews. Flight and confrontations with German soldiers. Stations of the flight: Budapest 1945, Maehrisch Ostrau, back to Budapest. Their goal was illegal emigration. Judenburg. In Italy (Livorno) they were supposed to go on board of an emigration ship. La Spezia: hunger strike of fleeing Jews. Historic details on Palestine. new beginning in Israel. Memories of childhood and school years. Various anecdotes from school years. Participation in a Zionist organization, religious attitude in the parental home: parents were Zionists and wanted to emigrate in 1937 Linguistic priority of German. Sojourns in Germany: Munich and the Oktoberfest. Relationship to Hebrew, which he doesn't speak well. Attitude toward religion. Literary interests: reads Alice Schwarz. About the danger of the extinction of Germans in Israel. Present relationship to Germany. Retrospect on school years and the hatred of Jews. Anti-Semitism in present Germany.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Born 11/23/1904, Mainz. Graduation from high school, commercial training, salesman. Studied Mathematics and Natural sciences but did not finish. Emigration 1933. Construction work, truck driving, retired. Interview: Parents: very orthodox. Father from Bavaria, came to Mainz to work in his sisters business. Father's shop was closed on Shabbat. Mother from Kaiserstuhl. Had 5 siblings. Schooling: Jewish school, high school. Jewish community in Mainz in 1933: 2.600-2.700 members. School years. His later wife was also in the orthodox community, had been friends for 7 years. Proposal and setting the wedding date. Wanted to study but was not allowed. Became a salesman. Later he financed his studies in Frankfurt partly himself. 1939 father had to pay back his scholarship. About son's interest in family roots. His parents refusal to let him study. About Rabbi Carlebach. The difficulties in raising children in a religious way. 1918 bombardment of Mainz. A Cousin was hit by a bomb. Parents moved to Bavaria. Invasion of French troops, confiscation and devastation of the apartment. Parents went to Hassfurt in 1939 and could not escape from there. 1934 mother's brother went to Italy and was killed. About his son's name (Michael Jacob). After the wedding his wife ( a singer) supported him, she was a singer. 1931-33 Mainz. Contacts with non-Jews Was not a Zionist. No interest in politics in Palestine. 01/30/1933 they decided they had to leave. USA, France or Palestine? Episode about a#French officer 1921/22. Why they did not go to France. Member of the social democratic party in Germany, became a leftist. Emigration: no way through Austria. Flight from Griesheim to Munich, flight to Venice, Trieste, boarded a ship. Arrival to Nahalal then Haifa. The first days and nights in the new country. Could bring along all their belongings. His sister took them in. A car accident. Own apartment in Tel Aviv. Lived in Pardes Bernstein. Episode about his son. Work as truck driver. Meeting his cousin from Wuerzburg in Jaffa. His own business. About his German. Always spoke German at home. About what they brought with them. The 1930s. His first customer. About his good constitution. Childhood memories. About his business. Son retired but doesn't want to come back to Israel. About the car he brought with him from Germany and other useless things they brought along.

records.title: Resistance to the Final Solution in Auschwitz.

descriptions.value: Part A: Born Dziedzice, 1909. Discusses: family background (grandparents, parents...); grandparents' life as Jews in town of Oswiecim (Auschwitz); schooling in Tarnowitz; languages used; life in parents' home; religious customs, observance; Jewish community; lack of antisemitism; identity; Jewish youth movements; studying to be pharmacist; being drafted to officer's course in Cracow-until 1932; exposure to antisemitism in army and university; starting to work as pharmacist in Katowice; being called to report to army 1939; knowledge in Poland of danger to German Jews. Part B: Discusses: travelling freely between Germany and Poland; witnessing changes in lives of German Jews; expulsion of Polish Jews out of Germany; being received by Jewish community; concern in Poland about expected war; religious observance, schooling; involvement in Zionist youth groups; no sense of antisemitism from Polish peers; 'Hakoach' Jewish movement, early 1930's; languages spoken; involvement in 'Agudat Hanoar Haivri Akiva'; own Zionist involvement; 'hachsharot'; sending youth to Palestine; dating. Part C: Discusses: Zionist movements; giving up job as pharmacist to work as editor of 'Divrei Akiva' newsletter; living on 'hachshara'; leaving 'hachshara' to return to Katowice and work in illegal aliyah; specifics of his work for illegal aliyah; end of activity in illegal aliyah following outbreak of war; atmosphere in Poland on eve of war; returning to Katowice immediately after German occupation;#going to work in pharmacy near Auschwitz; atmosphere amongst Jews-trying to figure out what course of action to take; trying to escape Poland with friend; being imprisoned by Germans in Austria; imprisonment in Sachsehausen camp. Part D:Discusses: arrival at Sachsenhausen - changing into uniform, being taken to barracks...; life in Sachsenhousen - conditions, different prisoners, hierarchy, daily routine, treatment, illness, deaths, friendships, food, work, torture, stealing; illegal Aliyah - details of work he did. Part E: Discusses: life in Sachsenhausen (continued...); trying to protect older people from beating; forced labour; people being buried alive; identifying SS officer as former school friend, receives extra bread from him; clothing; food; mutual assistance amongst inmates; working as carpenter; absence of antisemitism from non-Jewish inmates; inspection by Swiss Red Cross; rumours of development of war; murder of Russian POW's; production of counterfeit money in camp; guards-cruelty of SS guards; Jews in camp being given papers to leave Germany; existence/ continuation of small, Jewish community in Berlin, 1941; receiving letters from family until 1940; father's death; knowledge that he was the first Polish Jew in a concentration camp; transfer to Gross-Rosen; readjusting to life in Gross-Rosen - guards, work, horrific living conditions, quarantine, typhus epidemic of Jewish inmates, murder of the ill, transports of Jews, lice, recieving package from family,#impossibility of resistance, praying. Part Fa: Discusses: conclusion that Gross-Rosen was worst af all camps encountered ; transfer from Gross-Rosen by train; cruelty of guards; arrival at Auschwitz; life in Auschwitz (arrival, being tatooed; number on clothes and arm, clothing, importance of shaved head; housing); being appointed assistant in barrack; working in hospital as nurse; staff in hospital; conditions in hospital; slave labour for IG Farben industry. Part Fb: Discusses: details on physical layout of camp; managing to smuggle in some prescription drugs; forming small group of resistance from within the camp; starting to understand the extent of what was going on in the Holocaust; selection of weak and ill in hospital by SS. Part G: Discusses: gassing of weak and elderly; eating in camp; being transferred to work in Erziehungslager hospital; non-Jewish forced laborers; work at Erziehungslager; escape of his superior; contact with others including Gestapo; ways of peparing for selections in hospital- trying to save people; getting information to mother in Bedzin Ghetto by bribing guard. Part Ha: Discusses: duties in Sachsenhausen; murder of Russian prisoners; carrying bodies to be burned at crematorium; duties in Gross-Rosen and Buna; fellow inmates at Buna; conditions at Buna; relations with friend Max Wilner; maintaing hope for survival, Buna; maintaing some sort of contact with mother and sister from Buna; black market; death of mother in gas chamber, Auschwitz.#Part Hb: Discusses: meeting cousin in Auschwitz; reunited with sister in Auschwitz; first learning of gassing in Auschwitz, 1943; selections; trying to help people escape; conditions in hospitals in Auschwitz-Buna; selections done by doctors. Part La: Discusses: leaving Bremenhaven for New York on marine boat; others on the boat; Nazi collaborators granted refuge by Americans; chosen for boat; journey; belongings when left Germany; arrival in New York; assistance from HIAS; reception by relations in Ohio; contacting family in US; adjusting to ife in America; employment. Part Lb: Moves to Los Angeles in 1959; upset by poor conditions in the city hospital and compares it to the hospital in a concentration camp; daily life; challenges in business; health difficulties; children and grandchildren; involvement in Jewish organizations. Part Lc; Discusses: background of his wife, Ruth (family, childhood, education, fate of family; her fate during the Holocaust); his family (maintaining contact with mother and sister in Auschwitz - Buna, her life after the Holocaust); extended family; dates of imprisonment and transfer to different concentraton camps; working with American War Crimes Commission following war; medical selections in camps; people condemned to die taken away; decisions involved that determined whether a person would live or die;feelings of guilt, hate and revenge; people he met in the camps with whom he is still in touch; layout of Auschwitz-Buna.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Tripoli, 1907. Rabbi of Homs, Libya. Life in Homs: commerce and education. Work in American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC), Tripoli. Preparation for immigration of Libyan Jews by JDC and Jewish Agency. Distribution of food and clothes, medical care. Giving lessons in Maccabi club and editing Behayenu bulletin. Establishment of Aliya Office in Tripoli. Visit of Yitzhak Raphael, head of Jewish Agency Immigration Department. Conflicts between Baruch Duvdevani and representatives of JDC. Delegation of United Nations to Libya. Immigration to Israel with Youth Aliya, 1949. Absorption process. Life in Beit Lid immigrant camp. Teacher, school headmaster and political activist. Office to facilitate absorption of Libyan immigrants opened in Tel Aviv by Zion Nimni, emissary of Jewish community in Libya, 1950. School in Beit Lid immigrant camp. Hapoel Hamizrahi member of Knesset for 14 years.

[S.H]

records.title: Fate of Belorussian Jews during the Second World War.

descriptions.value: UNED Born Luzk, Ukraine 1946. Her father spent the World War II period in the Zhitomir region. Her father joined the partisans. His wife was a non-Jewish Ukrainian. When her father returned to the town he was told of the murder by the Germans of his family. Father moved to Luzk. Remarried and Adela was born. Mother was Yiddish teacher. When school was closed mother worked in trade. Thoughts of aliya 1975-76. Stayed in Luzk with few other Jews. Opening of synagogue in the town.

records.title: The Educational Systems in Jewish DPS Camps in Germany and Austria 1945-1951.

descriptions.value: Born in 1925 in Philadelphia. Aliya with family in 1933 and settled in Jerusalem. Drafted into American army as American citizen in February 1946. In March 1946 arrived in American zone of occupation and served for a year as a supply clerk in chaplain's division; Job allowed him close contact with displaced persons in Zeilsheim camp. In March 1947 released from army and joined Eretz Israel welfare units under Dr. Chaim Yachil. After three weeks sent to Austria to American zone and active in Eretz Israel delegation in Salzburg. In November 1947 moved to British zone to help organize aliya and transfer of olim from Austria to Germany.

records.title: Rescue of Jewish Children in Hungary from 1944 until Liberation.

descriptions.value: Organizing affairs of children's houses. Some of the houses left without staff after the war, since many people were not members of any Zionist movement, and so some of the children had to be relocated to other children's houses in places liberated earlier. Parents bringing their children to children's houses. Help from non-Jews.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Ari Rath, born Arnold Rath, was born on 01/06/1925 in Vienna. Four years “Gymnasium” (grammar school) in Vienna (“Wasa-Gymnasium”). Emigration to Palestine with Youth Aliyah in 1938. 1938-1941 he stayed in the Ahava Children's Village (children's home and agricultural school), 1941-1957 in a kibbutz (Hamadya). Activity in youth movements. 1946-1948: Stay in the United States for the Zionist youth movement. 1957-1959: Studies of contemporary history and national economy in Jerusalem. 1958-1989: reporter and political journalist for the “Jerusalem Post”, since 1975 as its editor in chief. Since 1989 work as independent journalist.#Interview I: Ari Rath's youth in Vienna: The students in his “Gymnasium” were segregated into Jewish and Christian classes, nevertheless Ari Rath had contacts to Christians. Memories of a friend who was killed in World War II. Ari Rath came from a wealthy bourgeois family. His mother died early. His grandmother was very devout, she was an important attachment figure to him. His father had immigrated to Vienna from Galicia during World War I, he was a businessman. A maternal uncle emigrated to Israel in 1935. His grandmother also emigrated to Israel early. Ari Rath was not yet interested in Palestine in 1936/1937. His political consciousness and Zionist attitude did not develop until the annexation of Austria. His grandmother's influence and the antisemitic statements heard at school roused his wish to go to Palestine. He joined a Zionist youth movement. His father was arrested and brought to Dachau and Buchenwald and was released on the condition that he took his chance to emigrate to Cuba. Ari Rath's emigration and his beginning in Palestine: While their father was still in the concentration camp, Ari Rath and his brother emigrated alone to Israel. His brother got a certificate and was moved to a youth group in a kibbutz. Ari was in a preparation-camp and chosen to get one of the few certificates to an Israeli school. He departed in November 1938. For the first three years in Palestine, he lived in the Ahava Childrens' Home in Kiryat Bialik. He describes his life in the youth group and their teachers. (Ahava was a children's home with an agricultural school, founded in and transferred from Germany by Beate Berger). Despite the collective spirit, Ari attempted to maintain his individuality. After the three years, he served in the Hagana.#Ari Rath's attitude towards the German language: He and his brother decided to speak only Hebrew with each other. A.R. ranks German nowadays as his third language. In 1946, the brothers went to see their father in New York. As Ari was not yet able to speak English and they did not want to speak German, they gave their German a Yiddish “touch”, to avoid the language of the Hitler-era. Slowly, English was established as a family language with their parents.#Interview II (1999): Mixted biographical topics, statements on Ari Rath's attitude towards the German language and his political activities: Life in the Ahava Children's Home mainly consisted of physical work and school lessons. There he learned a Hebrew with a Yekkish slant. In Palestine/Israel he spoke with his brother only Hebrew, even if they hardly mastered it at the beginning, but despite their refusal of the German language in daily communication, they read German literature. A.R. thinks that nowadays the Yekkish Hebrew influences his spoken German. The teachers and educators at the children's home gave them a firm framework which helped him to overcome the hard times. He always attempted to do intellectual work besides the physical work. The education aimed at integration into the collective. In 1941, A.R. became the co-founder of a group who wanted to found a new kibbutz. He thought that life in a kibbutz was like living in a sect, therefore he tried out several groups. About the political debates in the 1940s concerning the foundation of a Jewish state. Ari Rath served in the Hagana. He got some military education already in the Ahava school and he was already very interested in politics during his first years in Palestine. Rath was involved in different groups; 1945/46 he was a member of a youth movement in Haifa. He became a leader of conferences, debates and actions. In this period, he had a negative attitude towards the British. In 1946 he moved to New York for the youth movement and met there after 8 years his father, step-mother and half-sister. His main task was giving lectures to young Jewish university graduates to encourage them to form kibbutz-groups and go to Eretz Israel.#A.R. describes his autodidactic learning of English by reading newspapers. Since the reunion with his father at the end of 1946, they intuitively spoke a mixture of German and Yiddish (though they had only spoken standard German in Vienna). Soon, they changed to English. Ari Rath analyzes his political interests. He describes the situation in Palestine in 1946/1947.#Interview III (1999): Ari Rath's activities in his early adulthood in the USA and in Palestine/Israel: About his stay in the United States in 1946/1947. Analysis of his interest for the political situation in Israel. Description of his work as a journalist. About the languages he speaks with his family in Israel and in New York. Flashback to the Ahava Children's Home. A.R. joined the Hagana in 1940 after initial skepticism. About the task to buy weapons for the Hagana in the States and to send them to Palestine. Return to Israel in September 1948. His first stay in Austria after the War was a journey from Paris to Vienna, where he had an official function for the tenth year of remembrance of the “Kristallnacht”. He returned to Israel by ship from Marseille to Haifa and arrived in October 1948. (His father would have liked his sons to help him to rebuild his business.) Back to the kibbutz he did again physical work. He considers the period in the kibbutz as very important for his life. Furthermore, he considered the commitment in the youth movements as a personal obligation. 1951-1953 he was the secretary-general of the “United Pioneer Youth Movement”. - He has always tried to maintain some private life and to keep private things in the kibbutz. Since autumn 1945, he lived in kibbutz Hamadya (first not voluntarily, because he had wanted to found a new kibbutz). Descripton of the housing conditions in the kibbutz. - In 1956, A.R. was the delegate of the Israeli Workers' Party (Avoda) at the international congress of the Socialist Youth in Finland. He considers his experiences all over the world as an important part of his life.#Ari Rath's career and his (short) marriage: 1957-1959 he stayed in Jerusalem for studies of history and economy, the kibbutz had allowed him two years off-time. He describes the entrance exams for the studies. After the engagement with an English Jewish woman in spring 1958, he searched for a job and an apartment. A friend of him arranged contacts with the publisher of the “Jerusalem Post”. Ari Rath started as a political reporter in Jerusalem. He married in November 1958. Besides his work as journalist, he continued his studies. Analysis of the problems of his marriage, his divorce. About his work for the “Jerusalem Post”. In 1960 he wrote a report on Ben-Gurion's journey to the United States and his meeting with Konrad Adenauer, which he had observed closely.#Interview IV (2000): Ari Rath's (short) military service and his career as a journalist: About his work for the “Jerusalem Post”. Once he refused the offer of an employment by another newspaper. Ben-Gurion was a very important person for him ( and a positive character). A.R. became interested in political developments already in the 1950s. He discusses the Lavon-affair and the campaign against Ben-Gurion until his resignation in 1950. About the splitting of the Israeli Workers' Party in 1956, when Ben-Gurion founded his own workers' list. The “Jerusalem Post” has always defended Ben-Gurion's line. Ari Rath describes his temporary work as Ben-Gurion's secretary: In 1965, the “Jerusalem Post” allowed him four month off- time to support Ben-Gurion in his election campaign. Rath's contacts with politicians were already formed during his period with the “United Pioneer Youth”: his experience in the youth movement enabled him a political commitment, but after this experience he made a conscious decision against a political career. In 1960, he had a stay in Washington and New York in the scope of his work as reporter. (About the separation and divorce from his wife.) After his work for Ben-Gurion, Rath became the head of staff at the editorial office of the “Jerusalem Post”. Analysis of the situation of an English newspaper in Hebrew-speaking surroundings. The “Jerusalem Post” was at this time liberal and open. Rath considers it as his own merit that the slightly strange newspaper became an original Israeli newspaper. Analysis of the political developments in the 1960s. Rath served as soldier in the Six-Day War. During the Israeli War of Independence he was in New York with the secret order to organize weapons there. About his official swearing-in to military service in New York. In Israel he later became a member of reserves. He served as infantryman in deployments in the Six-Day War#War and 1973 in the Yom Kippur War. Later voluntary military service. The years 1967-1973 were marked by his active commitment to the work as journalist and for the reserves. Before the Yom Kippur War, Rath made a journey to Santiago in order to see an uncle. Analysis of the tensions in Chile. (Rath thinks that Salvador Allende has always been a kind of model for Israel because of his socialism without communism.) He watched a revolt from the window of his hotel and was hurt by a shrapnel. He wrote critical reports from Chile, but there were problems with the censorship. Within the scope of this journey, he also went to Buenos Aires and Rio de Janeiro. In October 1973, he returned to Israel when the Yom Kippur War broke out. About criticism of the government of Golda Meir and Moshe Dayan and protest movements, resignation of the Meir-Dayan government at the end of 1973. A.R. thinks that then a new era in the history of Israel started. - The “Jerusalem Post” was basically faithful to the government, above all to the line of Ben-Gurion. After the Yom Kippur War, there were different political opinions among the editors. About Rath's daily work on political incidents and as head of staff.#After the war of 1973, a younger generation of politicians came to power (Rabin und Peres). Criticism of the uncompromising politics of Golda Meir. In 1972, Rath brought his father to Israel, he stayed together with him for five years: difficult years with too little private life. Rath's father died in 1977; though A.R. had not always positive feelings for him, the common time in Israel was important to him. After the editor in chief of the “Jerusalem Post” had died, there were negotiations about a successor. In 1975, Rath took over the “Jerusalem Post” together with a colleague, he became publisher and editor. Analysis of the economic situation of the newspaper during the 1980s. Disappointment about the end of these activities in 1989, when new owners forced a change of the political orientation of the newspaper, which Rath did not accept, and disappointment about the lack of loyalty among his colleagues. - Since 1990, Rath has been active at the Jerusalem Foundation and worked as a free journalist.
Front Text - Komárom.Nádor-utcza.Schnell Béla kiadása, Komárom#Front Text Translation - Komárom.Nádor street

records.title: Bricha (Organized Escape) and the Camps in Germany 1944-1948; Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944.

descriptions.value: Born Poland 1924. Was raised in Zionist home. Discusses: Zionist youth movement in hometown; Hebrew school during Russian rule; life under Germans; atmosphere of fear; needing to flee and hide; people executed; becoming involved in helping people flee; relations with local Jewish community and British; dynamics of smuggling; refugees he helped escape Zagreb; retraining refugees in fishing, boat building etc.; group of 'Haoved Hatzioni'; refugee involvement in getting boats to Palestine, 1945; work did for Aliyah Bet; problems with legal Aliyah, May 1948-1949.

records.title: Jews in the Yugoslav Partisan Movement during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born Bosnia, 1919. Studied engineering, Czechoslovakia. Returned home following German entry. Joined army as pilot. Following release from army worked as engineer. Redrafted, 1941. After collapse of army returned home to first anti-Jewish decrees. Discusses: forced labour; roundup of Jews to concentration camps; flight of youth into forests; family's escape to Italian-controlled territory disguised as Muslims; transfer to refugee camps; kind treatment by Italians; hesitation in joining Partisans because of anti-Jewish behavior there; joining Jewish battalion of Partisans, then artillery; comrade who saved his life; transfer to air-force, 1944; harsh treatment there because of Jewishness; illness and recovery in hospital; release, 1944, to search for wife; finding her in refugee camp for Jewish Yugoslavians; Aliyah, 1945.

records.title: Baltic Countries Jewry between the two World Wars and during WWII.

descriptions.value: UNED Soviet rule in Lithuania. In Ghetto Kaunas. Partisans. Active in Berihah. Aliya, 1945, via many countries, to Italy and then to Palestine.
לחן עממי אוקראיני. פורסם בספר "הדי הארץ", ניו יורק, 1929.

Born Damascus,1896. Memories about the Kitab, the Jajam and as tailor apprentice. Fled to Beirut escaping the army. Called by a brother, arrival in Vera Cruz in 1912. Discusses itinerary to Mexico City. Memories about neighborhood la Merced and Jajam Dabbah. Worked with non Jews on trust. Memories about Isaac Capon and Mount Sinai, and private ceremonies. Worked as salesman on commission. Commercial bonds with Pancho Villa. Discusses labour occupation in textile factories under Cardenas' ruling. Father and son participated in hotel industry.

records.title: לשיר זה כמו להיות ירדן .[ביצוע מוקלט].

descriptions.value: השיר הוקלט בקונצרט "נועה היא שם בשדה" שנערך בספרייה הלאומית.

Born in Ferrara, 1903. Active in the Jewish Community and Zionist g Ferrara. Summer tourist, Israel, 1929. Aliyah to Israel, 1933. Teacher Technion Institute, Haifa, 1934. Hagana member, Kiriat Bialik, 1935-1
לקול ופסנתר
Born in St. Polten. The local Jewish youth movement; immigration to Palestine in 1933. Activities in Betar and Irgun Tzvai Leumi. Work in a health insurance company.

records.title: קולופון של העתקת ס' המצוות ללוי בן יפת.
History of the Jewish National Fund (Keren Kayemet le-Israel).

descriptions.value: Jewish life in Rotterdam, The Netherlands in the 1920s and in Antwerp, Belgium in the early 1930s. Religious observance. Life and work in Kiryat Anavim, Kiryat Haroshet and Kefar Yedidyah, 1934-1945. Emissary to Cuba and Mexico, 1946-1951. Entering those countries difficult for Jews in those years. Organizing the Jewish community in Havana, 1946. Department of Jewish National Fund (JNF) handling South American affairs and its office in Central America. Organizing the Jewish community in Mexico. JNF activities in Mexico. Working conditions as an JNF employee. Purchase of arms for Israel, 1947-1948. Administrative work in the JNF head office, 1951-1961. Administration of the JNF. Estates. Israel Land Administration Law.

records.title: Ha'apala (Illegal Immigration) from Italy, 1945-1948 [including material from the Haganah Archive].

descriptions.value: Communication activities in Italy; the signal station at Lake Como and its capture; other signal stations; relations between refugees and the active members; the immigrant ship "Katriel Jaffe"; capture and deportation; the camps in Cyprus. UNED Joined Palmah, 1943. Wireless course. Sent to southern Italy to open wireless station. Caught, interrogated by British, released. Founded 'Miriam' wireless station in northern Italy. Communications with Palestine, Jewish Brigade and Aliya ships. Trips to Milan on vacations to meet with other Israelis. Sent as wireless operator on 'Katriel Yafe' (and 'Ha-kaf-gimel'?) ship(s). Witnessed deportation ships in Haifa and resistance on ship.

records.title: Illegal Immigration from Italy and France, 1945-1948.

descriptions.value: Born Frankfurt, towards end of World War II. Discusses: personal story up until joining Aliya Bet; involvement in Haganah; being sent on mission to Egypt, 1944, and from there to Bari; being drafted to Aliya Bet; training he received for this work; moving from Italy to France; aims of his work in France; ties with French underground (1944-1945); forging certificates; ships that left from Marseilles; his activity in France; working with David Shaltieli, Leon Blum and others; contact with French defense, to avoid being caught; assistance received from French Jews; ship equipment; opinion of Aliya Gimmel; issue of armed Aliya; plan to execute Mufti; Father Glassberg's assistance to Aliya Bet. Discusses: his relationship with Shaul Avigur and his group; work done; cooperation with Abba Kovner's group 'Hanokmim'; problems with emissaries that came from Palestine to work in Europe during war; conflict between emissaries, problems with planning between them and head of Mossad working in France; difficulty in carrying out his work; being sent to US with aim of bringing first radio station to Germany, 1946; ties to Yitzhak Levy; being sent to US to raise funds for Mossad and to buy supplies no longer used by Canadian navy; change of identity upon return to France; people he worked with; atmosphere amongst Palestinian emissaries and difficulty understanding leadership in Palestine; dealing with refugees from Germany in France - how they got to border, getting them to Palestine;#places where refugees stayed in France; human resources in Belgium; centre in Marseilles; British pressure regarding Aliya Bet (1946); open conflict with British; the French newspapers' approach to the 'Haapala'; contact with professional bodies in France and French intelligentsia; period was in France following Exodus and roles filled. Discusses: obtaining military supplies; ties to Sylvia Neulander from American Red Cross; her role in sending off 400 children and her role in illegal Aliya; problem of French orphans; French socialists' position on Israel and Zionism; illegal work of Ruth Aliav and frameworks in which she worked; attempts at organizing Bricha and Mossad; Yitzhak Grimboim; problem of obtaining authority in Mossad; clarification of Ruth Aliav's work for illegal Aliya, 1945; French-English relations following war; organization of French police; relations between Sneh and Ben Gurion; Aliya Gimmel; six month delay in leaving France (Aliya Bet, 1946).

records.title: El Barriya, Abu Shusha Sub-district Ramle; Block plan index / Survey of Palestine.
The Revisionist Movement, Irgun Tzevai Leumi (Etzel) and Lochamei Herut Israel (Lehi) 1929-1948.

descriptions.value: Rivka: Born 1930 in Tel-Aviv to a family with a Labour background. Enlisted in Lehi, 1946, despite family's opposing ideology. When this was discovered she was beaten and thrown out of her home. Sent to a weaponry course, 1947, with 10 others. Were caught by the British. Shots were fired, 5 killed, the rest interrogated and imprisoned. Following her trial was sent to Bethlehem to serve life sentence. Describes close bond between Lehi prisoners in jail. She and others rebelled, demanding they be transferred to a Jewish environment. Were then transferred to Atlit along with prisoners from Acco and Eritreia. Released, 1948, enlisted in fighting unit in at which point she cut off ties to underground movements. After Independence War, studied in art teachers' seminar, married her instructor Herzl Eliav ('Ilan').

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born Yemen, 1932. Discusses: work and hobbies; family of 7 siblings; important role singing played in family; stories and love of Israel instilled in family home; Jewish holidays; Aliya as part of 'Marvad Haksamim', 1949; marriage in tent in Rosh Haayin ; raising five children; great importance and pride in family; husband; tending to family business following husband's death.

The fruit that gives native born Israelis their nickname -sabras - is now being picked and sold all over the country. The sabra is the fruit of the cactus. It has a tough prickly skin and a soft sweet fruit inside once opened. The fruit is very popular and at this time of the year many people can be seen by the roadsides selling passing moterists individual sabras that have been cooled in ice-water.

This year marks the 100th anniversary of the birth of Rabbi Yisrael Abuhatzira, the Baba Sali. Each year thousands of Moroccan Jews gather at the Sages grave for a festive gathering. Baba Sali had both during his long life time of 94 years and since his death a big following and influence among the Moroccan community. He was regarded as an authority on all religious matters as well as being well versed on the more mystical aspects of Judaism. It has been a tradition that on the anniversary of his death there is a gathering at Netivot attended by political and public figures, even if they do not come from the Moroccan Community. This year the Prime Minister has meant to attend the celebrations, but decided not to because Baba Sali's son, Rabbi Baruch Abuhatzira, had been urging the government to talk to the P.L.O. Yitzhak Shamir's boycott of the event did not stop other politicians attending. David Levy, the Housing Minister, who himself is from Moroccan extraction arranged road and parking facilities in Netivot to facilitate the thousands who come each year to the memorial and hold Baba Sali as being almost a saint. Photo shows: a Moroccan origin near the Baba Sali tomb at Netivot.

descriptions.value: Jerusalem Day was celebrated in the Capital today as well as all over Israel, Jerusalem Day commemorates the 24th anniversary of the reunification of the city following the Six Day War in 1967. Thousands of visitors flocked to the city from every direction to dance, sing and march in celebration of the city's vitality and freedom. "any new recent immigrants went to Jerusalem for the first time today to see the place they have only dreamt about. Today also saw the official opening of the excavated Western Wall tunnel. Included in the presentation of the tunnel is an audio-visual film sticking the connection of Jerusalem to the history of the Jewish people. The day was also marked by no reports of violence. Photo shows: The picture shows a scene looking towards the Western Wall of the Old City of Jerusalem.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-13 באוקטובר 2019, המתעדים את חג המים הנחוג בקיבוץ רמת יוחנן בחג הסוכות. קיבוץ רמת יוחנן נוסד בסוכות תרצ"ב (1931) וב-1940 הצטרפו אליו שני ענקים: המשורר והמלחין מתתיהו שלם והכוראוגרפית לאה ברגשטיין. מתתיהו כתב שירים ולאה יצרה ריקודי-עם ושניהם יחד ארגנו את חגי הקיבוץ ברוח הימים ההם. את אותם חגים, עם אותם טקסים, ריקודים ותלבושות (בשינויים מזעריים) ממשיך הקיבוץ וחוגג. בסוכות חוגגים ברמת יוחנן את עליית הקיבוץ על הקרקע (השנה 88 שנים), את חג האסיף ואת חג המים (שמחת בית השואבה). בטקס הנהדר הזה, הנערך על שפת הבריכה של הקיבוץ, משתתפים רוב חברי המשק, מקטן ועד גדול.
נחל בשור ( לאורך הנחל ואדי אל שריעה השתרעה החזית התורכית-גרמנית נמצאו בהרבה מקומות חוטי תיל וגם תרמילי פגזים בקוטר 100מ"מ על 300 מ"מ גובה)

תצלום שחור לבן ובו נראה אחד מחדרי הספרייה הציבורית של כפר אתא, שבו מוצגת תערוכה של הגדות לפסח. תערוכה זו נערכה בימי חול המועד פסח תשכ"ה (אפריל 1965) והוצגו בה הגדות אמנותיות שונות שנאספו בארכיונים ובספריות שונות בישראל, נוסף על אוסף של הגדות שהופקו על ידי צה"ל. בתצלום נראים שלושה אישים, וככל הנראה אחד מהם הוא סגן ראש המועצה המקומית כפר אתא, מר שייקביץ'. בגב התצלום הוטבעה חותמת הספרייה הציבורית של המועצה המקומית כפר אתא.

records.title: ילדי בית ספר במושב מסלול בנגב.

descriptions.value: הדפס כסף מקורי מתצלום שחור לבן שבו נראית כיתת בית ספר יסודי במושב מסלול אשר בצפון מערב הנגב. ככל הנראה, ילדי הכיתה הם עולים חדשים שעלו מאיראן. תצלום זה הופק לצרכי תעמולה על ידי קרן היסוד, ירושלים. בגב התצלום נכתב בעפרון: "מסלול - מושב עובדים של עולי פרס בנגב" וכן הוטבעה החותמת: Photo Keren Hayesod, Jerusalem".

records.title: כרוניקה על עליה לארץ ישראל בשנת תקפ"א.

descriptions.value: A: שנותיו הראשונות ברובנו, לימודיו בחדר, בחדר המתוקן, תאורו של החדר המתוקן ומעבר לבית ספר עממי לא יהודי. המצב הכלבלי במשפחה. הקשיים שעמדו בפני יהודים בדרכם להשכלה גבוהה: ההצואות הכספיות העצומות, תפקידה של האם ברכישת ההשכלה. השלבים בהתקדמותו: לימודיו בבית ספר למסחר בעיר קרמניץ עד 1907. לימודיו לג'נבה בשווייץ - האווירה והפעילות הפוליטית בקרב הסטודנטים, הקהילה היהודית שם ויחסם איתה. ההשפעה של חיים וייצמן. המצב ברוסיה - רוחות המהפכה, וגילויי האנטישמיות: פעולות הטרור - רצח סטוליפין. משפט בייליס. הזיקה לתרבות הרוסית של היהודים - היחס האמביוולנטי לסופרים הגדולים. אבל על מותו של טולסטוי. התפתחות המודעות והפעילות הפוליטית: השפעת המהפכה הרוסית הראשונה ב1905. לאומיות יהודית לא ציונית - דרכו של אנסקי. הפעילות הטריטוריאליסטית ברוסיה. האבל על מותו של הרצל. הזרמים השונים בציונות והוויכוחים ביניהם לבין התנועות הלא ציוניות. ההשפעה של התנועות הפוליטיות הכלליות כל התנועות היהודיות. תנועת "החבר".#B מלחמת העולם הראשונה: מצב בבשכלה הגבוהה: העברת מוסדות ההשכלה הגבוהה מווארשה לפלך הדוני, לרוסטוב בגלל המלחמה. האנטישמיות באזור. גיוסם של הסטודנטים היהודים לצבא והיחס החיובי לכך מצב הקהילה. הקשיים בקבלתם ללימודי הרפואה בדרך כלל והקלה מסוימת בזמן המלחמה. קשיים כלכליים של הסטודנטים וארגון קופות של עזרה הדדית. תפוצתן ופעילותן באוניברסיטה ברוסטוב. קיום מטבחים לסטודנטים נזקקים. פעילות פוליטית בכלל והציונות בפרט: פעילות חלק מהסטודנטים בתנועות ציוניות סוציאליסטיות וסוציאליסטיות הכלליות וכוח משיכתן בעיני צעירים. לתענתו בכל זאת רבים מאוד הצטרפו ל"החבר" שהיה ארגון אל-מפלגתי של סטודנטים יהודיים. מבנהו של "החבר" ודרכי פעילותו. נכונותם לקבל לתנועה גם תלמידי ישיבה. חשיבותו במניעת ההתבוללות. קיומו עד 1917 עד המהפכה הבולשביקית. ההשוואה בין דרך של פעילות פוליטית בחו"ל במערב וברוסיה. הפילוגים בקרב הבונד ובקרב הציונים הסוציאליסטים. ההתארגנות ודרך הפעילות של הסטודנטים האנרכיסטים. אווירה טרום מהפכנית במסדרונות השלטון, בשדרות העם השונות וגם באוניברסיטה. תפקידם הבולט של היהודים וההתלבטויות האם המהפכה הללית תפתור גם את בעיות היהודים. שנת 1917 - ההכנות לקונגרס הציוני הרוסי ולוועידות המכינות לבחירות.#ההתתלבטות מיהו יהודי לקראת לבחירות הכלל רוסית. ביטול הבחירות עקב המהפכה הבולשביקית.

records.title: Ethiopian Jewry: Historical Traditions, Aliya and Absorption.

descriptions.value: Born in Ethiopia. Four years of Great Famine (Kifu-Qen) in Ethiopia at end of nineteenth century. Reasons for Great Famine. War against dervishes from Sudan; King Ade Yohans killed. Life of Qes Yemanu in Ethiopia. Teaching, cooperation with ORT and various other organizations, 1960s-1980s. Italian government in Ethiopia, 1935-1941. Jews moving from one village to another to escape the Italians; some Jews resisting. Establishing new Jewish villages and synagogues. Life in new surroundings.

records.title: History of the Jewish National Fund (Keren Kayemet le-Israel).

descriptions.value: Discusses: beginnings in Keren Kayemet Leyisrael; work in many lookouts; being trained in field work; working for ministry of housing 1989-90; manpower responsible for planning and execution; water sources (1985-88); water sources he was responsible for; manpower problems; cooperation with ministry of housing; manpower sources at his disposal; activity in preparation in field work; changes in workers in Keren Kayemet; relations between employees and Keren Kayemet.
Born Bulgaria, 1933. Discusses: childhood in Sofia; life in parents' home; education; family business; atmosphere and way of life during that period.

records.title: Contribution of Jewish Communal Activities in Latin America to the Establishment of the State of Israel, 1945-1949.

descriptions.value: Born Czechoslovakia, 1920. Aliyah before WWII. Served as Ambassador to Israel in several countries. Discusses: involvement in illegal immigration to Israel; representing Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Rio de Janeiro, 1960; posts in Africa, Latin America and in delegation to U.N.; arriving in Uruguay, 1975; Rodriguez Fabrequat; arranging Fabrequat's visits to Uruguay; trying to organize Fabrequat's funeral to meet his wishes; Uruguay's unique position on Israel; support for Israel in both major parties, Loborados and Blancos; Jews active in political campaign, especially Jacobo Hazan; Battle Blers; Payse Reyes; 'El Pais'; Juana de Jbarburu; support Moshe Tov mustered amongst personalities.

records.title: The Zionist Underground in Soviet-Occupied Poland, 1939-1941.

descriptions.value: המרויאיין חבר השומר הצעיר בוורשה. לפני המלחמה עמד בראש הקן בפראגה. במהלך הראיון מתאר את הפעילות ב1 בספטמבר 1939, עם פרוץ המלחמה: הפסקת הפעילות החינוכית בקן והחלטות ישיבת ההנהגה הראשית; הימים הראשונים עם פרוץ המלחמה: הקמת הנהגה ראשית חדשה, ההוראה לצאת מוורשה לכיוון מזרח, המסע מזרחה; הגעתם לקובל: ההעשה תחת השלטון הסובייטי, המפגש עם חברי התנועות מרחבי פולין שהגיעו לעיר והפעילות בעיר במסגרת התנועה - בגלוי ובמחתרת; ההכנות והפעלות לקראת חציית הגבול הרומני בלבוב, לוצק, קולומיה וקוטי; כישלון חציית הגבול והמעצר על ידי הסובייטים; כליאתו בבתי מעצר שונים עד שליחתו למחנות בסיביר; שחרורו מהמחנה עם פלישת הגרמנים לברית המועצות ביוני 1941; חציית הגבול לאסיה, ההגעה לסטלינובד והחזרה לסיביר, שם שהה עד סוף המלחמה

Discusses: friendship with author Shai Agnon, while living in Talpiot neighbourhood of Jerusalem, 1950's and 1960's; meeting Shai and Esther Agnon; life in the Agnon home; influence of Agnon on husband Zvi's paintings; social interaction.

Discusses: Jews who, following WWI, collected funds to buy property for themselves in Palestine; sending funds, in their names, to Colonial Bank in London; end of the bank's contact with Russia following Revolution; their funds being sent to Keren Kayemet and Zionist Congress; encountering refusal to give them the lands when they arrived in Israel and showed property rights; mobilizing themselves into organization 'Russian Zionist Center'; president - Tribosh; secretary - Halevi Horwicz; receiving some of their lands after years of battling for them; planting orchards and naming land Kfar Havat Tzion after Hovevi Tzion movement in Russia.
A felucca.

records.title: Struggle in Poland for the Return of Jewish Children from Non-Jewish Environments after the Holocaust.

descriptions.value: UNED Born in Warsaw. Taking on false Christian identity and changing his name. Caught, arrested and sent to Pustkow camp, where he was appointed jail commandant. Able to assist other Jews until his Jewishness discovered by another employee. Fleeing and establishing partisans group. After the war in view of his past active in Coordination in taking out children out of Christian homes and convents, appearing as armed governmental inspector wearing Polish Army uniform. Most difficult cases addressed to him: cases in which Polish people refused to hand the kids over or the children refused to return to Judaism. Describing four such cases. Taking out two brothers out of a convent holding on to the claim that Jewish institutions should pay their maintenance expenses. Claiming to be the father of a girl held by an old maid who tried to extort large sums of money for her. Polish law and his uniform helping him take out another child from polish family that exploited him. Eventual absorption of another child that initially refused to return to Judaism and repeatedly escaped.

The man is sitting on a chair; he is richly dressed with a traditional outfit composed of an antari (robe) tightened with a belt, under a kaftan lined with fur. Her wife, standing apparently at his right, looks at him and lays affectionately her right hand on his shoulders. She is elegantly and decently dressed with a traditional outfit composed of an antari, a sleeveless dressing gown, under an apron adorned with flowers. She also wears a bolero, called capitana, which covers her shoulders and partly her chest. Her hair forming two braids, is closed in a cofia (headdress). Next to the couple are standing two women, maybe from the same family, similarly dressed. [S.H]#Back Handwritten Text - Salonique, 27 Janvier 1918 (..)
