records.title: Juden in der Synagoge von Sana'a. (Aufnahme von Hermann Burchardt.) Orient-Verlag, Berlin.

descriptions.value: Text on the back -Postkarte:In der Landschaft Yemen in Südarabien lebten noch vor kurzem etwa 50.000 Juden. Fortwährende Verfolgungen seitens der fanatischen Einwohner, die sich zudem in stetem Aufruhr gegen die türkische Regierung befinden, und die elende wirtschafliche Lage, die sich oft bis zu Hungersnöten steigert, haben diese jüdische Bevölkerung dezimiert. Gegenwärtig versucht es der Rest, sich durch die Auswanderung nach Palästina zu retten, dem nächsten Gebiet, wo Juden unter günstigeren Verhältnissen leben. Diese Einwanderung anspruchsloser, arbeitwilliger und intelligenter Leute bringt dem allgemeinen jüdischen Kolonisationswerk in Palästina, das zurzeit mehr als 40 landwirtschaftliche Ansiedlungen mit ca. 12.000 Einwohnern umfasst, in den verschiedensten Hinsichten ganz außerordentlichen Nutzen, so daß die Rettung der yemenitischen Juden gleichzeitig auch dem grossen Felde der jüdischen Palästina-Bestrebun#Back Printed Text Translation - Postcard:(Approximate translation) In the region of Yemen, in South Arabia, lived still recently about 50,000 Jews. The continual pursuits from the fanatic inhabitants, in constant riots against the Turkish government, as well as the miserable economic situation which often increases up to starvation, have decimated this Jewish population. At the present time, the rest of the population tries to get saved by emigration to Palestine, the next area, where Jews live under more favorable conditions. The emigration of undemanding, work-willing and intelligent people activates the Jewish colony in Palestine, which covers now more than 40 agricultural settlements with approx. 12,999 inhabitants. Thus, the rescue of Yemenite Jews as well as the large field of the Jewish colony came out right. For these reasons, the association 'Ezra' makes considerable means for the removal of the Yemenites and for their maintenance in the first time.#Production period - ca. 1910#Front Period - ca. 1910#Category - Religious life#Description - This horizontal postcard depicts a photograph of four religious Jews in the Synagogue of the Jewish quarter of Sana'a. They are sitting around a table with books and are probably having a Talmudic study after the morning prayer, according to the large size of their books. Among the four men, we recognize the Rabbi and Kabbalist David ben Shalom Jamal (הרב דוד בן שלום ג'מאל) with the tefillin (pair of black leather boxes containing scrolls of parchment inscribed with Bible verses). He wears more precisely the head-tefillin placed above the forehead during the morning prayer and leaves them for studying. On his left stands the Rabbi Yihye Abiyatz (הרב יחיא אביץ). The four men are traditionally dressed and are marked out by their payot (long side curls in hair); Yemenite Jews often sported payot and referred to them as signs (Simanim in Hebrew) which differentiated them f

records.title: Bricha (Organized Escape) and the Camps in Germany 1944-1948; Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944.

descriptions.value: Discusses: being liberated from concentration camp by Americans; state of health after two years in concentration camp; going with member of Jewish Brigade to Modena, Italy 1945; life in camp in Modena; going to Southern Italy; establishment of 'hachshara' kibbutz, through support of British government (1945-46); being sent to Austria; returning to Italy, 1946, to work with leadership in Milan; Aliyah, 1948.

records.title: Jews of Greece before, during and after the Holocaust.

descriptions.value: Reads from a copy of a Greek Jewish publication from the 1940s that describes: attempted escapes to Turkey, moral support of Archbishop, assurance from Germans that they don't discriminate against anyone. Rumours of deportation and concentration camps and denial in Jewish Community of rumours. Round-up of Jews. Transport to Salonica. Support shown by Greeks. Ghettoization, transport to Birkenau. Arrival at Birkenau. (Part IV of Interview) Discusses: pre-WWII relations between Germany and Greece; how Greek Jews who had other nationalities (ie. Italian, Spanish) were saved; the hiding of Jews; Righteous Gentiles; Jewish participation in partisans and guerillas. Zebras' slaughter of Albanians and Muslems; post-WWII tendancy in Greece to whitewash the period of Nazi occupation; Greece's pro-German tendancies; anti-semitism; Jewish participation in the Greek Army. State of the Jewish Community, post-WWII. Government expropriation of a synagogue; intermarriage; assimilation. (Part I of interview) Discusses: Present-day situation in Greece; Greek policy in the Middle East conflict; contemporary politician's histories as Nazi collaborators; anti-semitism in Greece and Greek politics; help given to Jews during WWII. Role and story of Rabbi Bazelai; the Resistance; post WWII war crimes investigations; post WWII feelings of Jews towards leftists; role of Italian council in helping the Jews. Fate of Jews of various nationalities (ie. Italian, Spanish) in Greece during WWII;#emigration of Greek Jews to U.S. in 1920s and 1930s; preservation of Jewish artifacts. (Part II of interview) Discusses: the fate of the survivors, the implementation and enforcement of anti-Semitic legislation. Post war recordings of testimonies. Fate of smaller communities. Question of why some communities were deported to Auschwitz and others were not. Greek Jew's lack of interest in their history. (part III of interview)

records.title: Jewish Resistance in Slovakia during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born 1901 in city of Manitra, Slovakia, to a Haredi family. A member of 'Young Mizrahi', made Aliyah, 1925. In Israel was a member of 'Beit Zera' in the Jordan Valley. Left Israel to help his family financially. Associated with 'Hehalutz' and 'Haoved' until 1941. Discusses life for Jews in Slovakia, and his Aliyah: different forums of the Zionist movement; activities within framework of 'Merkaz Hayehudim' (The Jewish Center); role of Slovakian Orthodox Jewry; Jewish youth who joined the Zionist Communist Movement; the fascist Slovakian state; reduction of activity in the Jewish center following 1941; refugees from Poland and information on murder of Jews; 'Halutzim' from Poland; information on exile; transfer to Hungary; responsibility felt by youth movements towards Jewish community; possibility of fleeing over the border; atmosphere amongst Jews; contact with 'Hashomer Hatzair' and Communist Party; Benito (Yaakov Rosenberg); organization in Novaky and Sered; arrival of refugees from Poland, people who met them and took them to Poland; atmosphere amongst Hungarian Jews two weeks before German entry. Summarises his life in Israel and a retrospective look at past years.

records.title: Members of the Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities.

descriptions.value: Born Kishniev, 1921. Studied Math and Physics, Czernovitz, 1940-41. Did forced labour under 'Todt' - headed by Romanians and Nazis. Fled Labour Camp, 1944. Discusses: Aliya; life in Kibbutz Dalia; studying in Jerusalem, 1945-49, Hebrew University; MA at Princeton University, 1950-52; PhD at Technion, 1956; teaching on Technion faculty; involvement in establishment of Aeronautics Department; work in other universities around the world; scientific work done at Weizmann Institute, as of 1989.

Born in Padua, Italy, 1909. High school teacher. Sister also teacher. Jewish teachers fired, 1938. Invited by Italian Rabbi Lats to teach in private high school in Tripoli, Libya. Teaching Italian, Latin, geography and Italian history. Only three classes in high school. Studying Hebrew at Ben-Yehuda culture club. School closing at outbreak of WWII. Finding clerical work to avoid Italian government returning them to Italy. Immigration to Israel.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Podolia, Ukraine, 1912. Aliya, 1922. Education and training. Teacher and active member of Mapai. Secretary of district branch and party's newspaper Hador. Secretary general of Culture Department of Jewish Agency. Bureau director of Haifa and northern Israel for Culture Department. Director of Culture Department, 1953-1956. Work in Jewish Agency Department of Education and Culture in Diaspora. National supervisor and chief editor of Ministry of Education publications. Establishment of first ulpanim. Director of department for Hebrew language instruction. His efforts to exonerate Nahum Levin.

records.title: The Revisionist Movement, Irgun Tzevai Leumi (Etzel) and Lochamei Herut Israel (Lehi) 1929-1948.

descriptions.value: Born 1923 in Czechoslovakia to established, religious and Zionist family. Spoke Hebrew at home. Made Aliyah with family by way of rabbi's document. Lived with father's step-brother in Mea-Seharim and studied with Rabbi Kook. During this period joined Etzel, participated in planning many missions that failed or were called off. Describes preparations and ambushes for attack on McMichael, 1944. Took part in attack, managed to escape, but later that year was caught and interrogated. Imprisoned in Latrun then transferred to Eritrea where remained four years. Failed attempts at escape. When released, returned to Israel

records.title: Ethiopian Jewry: Historical Traditions, Aliya and Absorption.

descriptions.value: Born in Ethiopia, 1944. Students of Kefar Batya: arrival from Ethiopia 1953-1964, return to Ethiopia and their contributions to Ethiopian Jewish community. Establishment of schools in seventeen Jewish villages. Encouraging local community to immigrate to Israel. Contributions of students choosing to stay in Israel. His visit to Ethiopia 28 years after emigration.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Sousse, Tunisia, 1925. Immigration to Israel. One of the founders of Moshav Gilat in the Negev. Organizing nucleus of settlers, initial inspection of site and finally settling in 1949. First living in tents while building houses. Austerity, food rationing and means of obtaining provisions in early years. Social and political crises. Ethnic composition of Gilat. Social and cultural activity; cultural gaps between different communities. Security problem; Arab terrorism. Relations with non-Jewish ethnic groups in vicinity.

records.title: Members of the Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities.

descriptions.value: Born in Timisoara, Romania, 1928. Childhood. Father Yehuda Leib Fleischer used Hebrew as his second language. Writing poems. Parents' attitude towards that. Romania liberated by the Russians, 1944. Communist revolution. Contacts with Shaul Avigur. Writing six hundred poems during detention, choice of medieval Jewish religious poetry as field of academic research Schirmann guiding his doctorate. Recipient of Israel Prize. Member of Israel Academy of Sciences and Humanities since 1984.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Istanbul, Turkey in 1916. Father local physician. Graduation of Alliance elementary school, 1931. Studies at Turkish high school. Founding Neemanai Tzion youth movement with Moshe Majar, Shabtai Dinur and Reuven Armel, 1937. Zionist activities, 1937-1941. Graduating dentistry at Istanbul University, 1941. Dentist in Turkish Army, 1941-1944. Aliya of Jews effected by his Zionist activities. Acquaintanceship with Prof. Avraham Galanteh. Aliya with family, 1950. Living in Beer Yaakov immigrant camp; opening clinic. Dentist in IDF for eighteen months. Relocation to Bat Yam; opening new clinic. Deep involvement in life of Turkish community in Israel and Turkey. Promoting Ladino culture.

records.title: Evacuation and Flight of Jews in the USSR during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born in Wakhnovka, Vinnitsa, Ukraine, 1924. Family moving to Vinnitsa, 1932. Fleeing to Kzyl Orda, Kazakhstan, through Kharkov and Kupiansk, 1941.

records.title: The History of Cuban Jewry in the 20th century, and today's Cuban Jewish Community in Florida.

descriptions.value: Group of interviewees from Santiago de Cuba. Immigration to Cuba from Edirne (Turkey). Economic integration of the Sephardim. Beginnings of Sephardi organization in the Oriente province. Isolated existence of Jews in Cuba, and tendency to concentrate in large cities. Social integration and maintenance of Jewish identity.

records.title: בית מזמיל ירושלים המחלקה הטכנית של הקהק"ל.

descriptions.value: Born Varna, Bulgaria, 1930. Father served as chairman of Achdut in Varna, mother active in Wizo. Discusses Jewish school and fellows. Refugee in Preslav during the war. Integrated Hashomer, September 1944. Emigrated when communists arrived. From Sofia to Paris by train. Bordeaux, by ship to Portugal. Puerto Cabello, Venezuela. By plain from Havana to Mexico, 1948. Discusses Hashomer Hatzair, Mexico, discussions into the movement and creation of the State of Israel. Returned to Bulgaria, 1957. Back to Mexico, lived separated from the Jewish community.

records.title: Karte von Palästina : nach den neuesten Hilfsquellen / von Dr. Jos.Fr. Allioli und Dr. Lor. C. Gratz.
Daily life in the first neighbourhoods of the city of Tel- Aviv.

descriptions.value: The interviewee, Shulamit Kahana, is also known by the nickname Buba. Her maiden name was Aharonowitz. Born in Vilna in 1913. Immigrated to Eretz Yisrael in 1926, studied at the Herzliya Gymnasia, graduate of 1931 class. In the interview she talks about her school, language of instruction in German; languages spoken at home; aliya of her parents; her studies in Tel Aviv. Among the stories included in the interview are: studies in music, school hikes, family's private car, drivers' license, activities of the Hagana; sport; Tel Aviv beach, bike hike in 1928, 1931 visit to Berlin, meeting her future husband; marriage porposal, dances, cinemas in Tel Aviv. The interview took place as part of the preparations in honor of her 90th birthday.
Born in Baden. The Blau Weiss youth movement and Poale Zion. Immigration to Palestine in 1934. Work at electric power station. Teaching electric technology in high schools.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Sfax, Tunisia, 1928. French education. Member and leader of Zeirim Ohavei Zion, 1945-1948. Aliya, 1948, to instruct in Hagana camps. Fifteen month service in IDF. Organizing people of Tunisian and Morrocan origin to settle in Gilat in Negev. Gilat's secretary 1951-1954, 1957. Problems of housing, agriculture, infrastructure, development and security. Social and agricultural training by veteran residents. Difficulties of agriculture as basis of economic subsistence. Parents arriving after mass immigration from Tunisia in 1949; after stay in immigrant camp in Beit Lid relocating to Jerusalem. Ten people in family; difficult conditions at first. Marrying in Tunisia in 1950 and returning to Israel. As emissary to Tunisia effecting aliya of 500 families in thirty months, 1954. Some 15,000 Tunisian Jews emigrating by 1967. Jewish community in Tunisia almost non-existent. Difficulties causing thousands to leave Israel for France in first years. Since 1954 direct absorption at settlements and abolition of transit camps. Conditions promised in Tunisia surpassed by conditions finally received. At first selection of aliya candidates by age; finally transfer of entire villages from Atlas mountains. Tunisian Jews preferring moshavim to kibbutzim.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Yemen. Immigration from Sadah, Yemen through Hashed Geula transit camp, Aden. Defrauded of jewelry and clothes. Men's hair and side-locks cut upon arrival in Israel. Arrival in Rosh Haayin. Month-old baby taken to children's house. Grandmother not permitted to visit baby. Child almost transferred from immigrant camp under pretense of requiring medical care. Removing child from children's house. Threatened with denial of food. Hearing that other children disappeared from children's house. Relocation to Elyashiv transitional camp one year later. Purchasing permanent housing.

descriptions.value: Last week 180,000 Arabs living in areas close to the Green Line were issued with gas masks. Concern has been expressed that gas masks could be used by rioting Arabs for protection against tear gas. Arabs living in the West Bank and Gaza have been trying, through the High Court, to make the army distribute gas masks to all Arabs. The army has been against such a distribution not only for the reason stated above, bud also because there is nobody who is prepared to pay for the cost of such distribution, The gas masks distributed to Israeli Jews and Arabs have been paid for by the National Insurance Institute from money paid in to a fund by citizens for the equipment. Today Jews and Arabs in rural parts of the country have started to receive gas masks. Photo shows: an Bedouin from the Israeli Arab village of Beit Zarzir collecting his gas mask. Many Bedouin from the village have served in the Israeli Army.

Archaeological excavation being carried out this season at the ancient Galilee city of Tzipori (Sepphoris), have revealed a fifth century mosaic floor of exceptional beauty and Interest. Tzipori -which is taken from the Hebrew word which means bird, was given to the ancient capital of the Galilee because it perches on top of a mount like a bird? In the newly discovered mosaic there are many artistic references to the Nile River animals and features, it was a common subject for artists of the time. The exact function of the structure is still not quite clear, particularly as Tzipori was a mixed city of Jewlsh, Christian and pagan population. Several important finds have been like at the site during the past seven years of active excavation. Four years ago a mosaic centrepice was discovered of Dinysos, the Greek god of wine. It is regarded by many as the most beautiful mosaic portrait ever found in Israel. The Dinysos mosaic was removed and taken to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem to prevent its theft as well as making it more accessible to the public. A permanent structure is now being built at Tzipori that will enable the Dinysos to be returned to its original location as well as developing the whole area, One cause for concern in the fact that the Housing Ministry proposes to build a new town next to Tzipori that would, according to the archaeologists, destroy valuable remains of water systems that supplied the ancient city. Tzipori was an important Jewish spiritual centre and was the home of many eminent Talmudic scholars, including Rabbi Yehuda Hanassi, who lived and died in the city in the second century. It was Rabbi Hanassi who compiled and edited the Mishna. Photo shows: A beautiful mosaic was encovered at the Tzipori archaeological site.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-7 באוקטובר 2019, המתעדים את טקס ה'תשליך' שהתקיים בגן הוורדים בירושלים. בתחילה הגיעו בודדים, קבוצות קטנות ומשפחות לתשליך וממש לקראת שקיעה הגיעה קבוצה גדולה של חסידי ויזניץ עם האדמו"ר שלהם.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-29 במאי 2019 המתעדים את טקס המלידה של עדת בני-ישראל מהודו, המתקיים במערת אליהו בחיפה. טקס המלידה הוא טקס ייחודי ל"בני ישראל" - עדה שמקורה בדרום-מערב הודו (קונקאן). את הטקס נוהגים לערוך בחוג המשפחה בהזדמנויות חגיגיות (כמו לידה, בר-מצווה, נישואים, חנוכת בית). התפילה בטקס כוללת חלק המוקדש לאליהו הנביא, הנערץ על ידי בני העדה, ועל כן בישראל נוהגים בני העדה לערוך אותו גם במסגרת ציבורית במערת אליהו שעל הכרמל, לרוב אחרי ל"ג בעומר. המלידה עצמה היא קערה או מגש שעליו פיצוחים, פירות יבשים ו/או טריים ובמרכז ענף ריחן, הדס או כל צמח ריחני אחר. לא ידוע מה פירוש המילה אך מקור המנהג, כנראה, במגש תקרובת שההינדים נוהגים להגיש לאליהם במקדשים. למערת אליהו הגיעו ארבעה אוטובוסים שאספו את בני העדה ממקומות שונים בארץ, וערכו טקס נפרד, זה אחרי זה. כל משפחה הביאה מגש מלידה מכוסה במפית רקומה, הניחה אותו על שולחן או על מפה שנפרשה על הרצפה, הסירו את המפית והסתדרו מסביב. אחד הגברים הנחה את הטקס וקרא שלושה פיוטים: הראשון לאליהו הנביא, לאחריו ברכת יעקב לבניו ולבסוף קטע מתהילים. בסיום אוסף מנחה הטקס את צמחי הבושם מקערות המאלידה ומחלק אותם לנוכחים המריחים אותם יחד עם הברכה על הבשמים. אחרי כן נוטלים הנוכחים תמר מהקערות ומברכים את ברכת בורא פרי העץ, ועם תום הברכות לוקחים את קערות המלידה ומכבדים את הנוכחים. קיימים גם טקסי מלידה פרטיים שבני העדה עורכים במסגרות פרטיות ובתאריכים שונים.

records.title: ירושלים: מאה שערים, חצרות בתי אונגרין בפסח.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-27 באפריל 2019, המתעדים את טקס שריפת עגל הזהב בעין הוד. בשנות התשעים של המאה הקודמת התכנסה מועצת כפר האמנים עין הוד כדי להחליט כיצד יחגוג הכפר את הפסח בדרכו המיוחדת. נקבע שבכל שנה אמן אחר יכין עגל זהב שאותו ישרפו בטקס המוני שמח. "הרעיון הוא שאמן יעבוד על פסל, שאותו יעלו באש. כך ילמד האמן שהאגו שלו מוגבל ובן-חלוף" - כך אמרה לדנצ'ו ארנון נחמה, שבעלה ז"ל היה בין מייסדי הטקס. בשנת 2019 הוטל התפקיד על אלון ירקוני. הנושא - המאבק על אסדת הגז. לכן טרחו אלון ובני משפחתו והכינו עגל זהב שחציו לוויתן. בארבע אחרי הצהריים העמיסו את העגל, עטוף במעטה, אל כיכר הכפר.לקראת שש בערב היו כל תושבי הכפר ואורחים מכונסים בכיכר. אהרון הכהן עלתה למרפסת המזכירות וקראה בפאתוס את דבר היום, שעסק בנזקי אסדת הגז. כשסיימה, הסירו את הלוט מעל לפסל לקול תיפוף להקת מתופפים והקהל התחיל לרקוד מסביבו, כשבידי רבים בקבוקי משקה. לאחר זמן מה נשאו כמה גברים את הפסל ותהלוכה גדולה וצוהלת יצאה אל תצפית הכפר, ובראשה אהרון הכהן מחזיקה בחופן דולרים. ביציאה מהכפר הצטרפה לתהלוכה חבורת "בני ישראל", ילדים שהכינו ניסים עם ציורי סמלי 12 שבטי ישראל.כשהתהלוכה הגיעה לתצפית הניחו את העגל במרכז הרחבה. משה רבנו ירד מהר סיני וטיפס בסולם אל גג סככת התצפית, שם הניף את לוחות הברית וקרא את דבר שומרי איכות הסביבה. לאחר מכן הוא ירד אל העגל והצית אותו ואת הלוחות. כל אותו זמן העם רקד סביב העגל לקול התופים ונרגע רק כשמהעגל נותר רק אפר.

records.title: Dan--Where Jeroboam built a temple and established the worship of the Golden Calf

descriptions.value: A natural area, lush with trees and low vegetation.
A wall of sculptured carvings and hieroglyphics.

records.title: Abou Simbel. Façade of the small temple. Nubia

descriptions.value: Looking up at the temple and the five huge sculptures in niches.
View of the Valley of Elah
A priest and several other men are outside a cave.
A pylon with carvings outside the entrance to the Temple of Horus.

records.title: Mount Serbal, from the Wadee Feyran

descriptions.value: A wady is in the foreground with Mount Serbal in the background.
The Nile River at the Aswan Dam.
A boat is tied up on the bank of the Nile.

records.title: Mont des Oliviers, vu de l'ouest

descriptions.value: A view of the Mount of Olives, showing the Garden of Gethsemane and the Tomb of the Virgin.
Two sets of columns and architraves. A small v-shaped container is next to a row of columns.

records.title: "The new Calvary" and "The Tomb of Jeremiah," looking north from the northern wall, Jerusalem

descriptions.value: Several people are on a roof or wall with the caves of Golgotha behind them. In the far background there are a number of stone buildings and, at the right, a stone wall.

records.title: "And after six days Jesus taketh Peter, James, and John, and leadeth them up into an high mountain, and was transfigured before them. And his raiment became shining, exceeding white as the snow." Mark ix.3. Mount Hermon--The Mount of Transfiguration

descriptions.value: A snow-topped Mount Hermon is in the distance.
The remaining section of an ancient bridge sits in the Tiber River next to a more modern bridge.
A pyramid with a rectangular base and six mastabas.

records.title: Bethel--Where Abraham went with Lot and his wife

descriptions.value: Stone structures are on the top of a hill. Stone walls divide a field into sections.

records.title: Palmyra or Tadmor--One of the Cities built by King Solomon. Ruins at the Western End of the City

descriptions.value: Two columns stand among a field of stone ruins. In the foreground, there is a stone panel of carved vines and leaves.
View of a sarcophagus.
The exterior of the Tomb of the Virgin with a person standing outside the closed door.
Exterior walls of Al-Aqsa from the west and south, looking east to the Mount of Olives.
Buildings at Luxor, including three columns at the right.

records.title: Tomb of the Horatii, on the Appian Way--Passed by St. Paul in chains

descriptions.value: A stand of trees is on a hill and there are stone ruins.

records.title: Dragoman standing on a rock. The Arno

descriptions.value: A dragoman stands on a thin rock shelf jutting out over the valley.

records.title: Palmyra--Ornamental Door, leading through the side of the Triumphal Arch

descriptions.value: A carved archway with a column in the background.

The Gihon Valley. The city of Jerusalem and its walls are at the right side. At the far left is the Montefiore Windmill (Jaffa Gate Mill) and the Mishkenot Sha'ananim almshouse built by Sir Moses Montefiore.

records.title: The Valley of Ajalon--Where Joshua commanded the sun and moon to stand still

descriptions.value: A panoramic view of the valley with a road crossing from left to right.
The file contains a portrait of Aaron Pavlovitch Haffkine (father of W.M. Haffkine), sent from Kherson, on 08.07.1911 (o.s.), by his grandson Alexandre Solomonovich Haffkine.

גלויה מחולקת ובה הדפס מתצלום שחור לבן של חזית בניין עיריית תל אביב, רחוב ביאליק 27, תל אביב (בית סקורה). בתצלום, שנעשה מכיוון דרום לצפון, נראית הגינה שהיתה לפני הבניין (כיום, מקום המזרקה שלפני מוזיאון "בית העיר"). על הגלויה לא צויינו שם הצלם או תאריך הצילום. בגב הגלויה נדפס שם המוציא-לאור באנגלית: Sidney Schwartz, Tel Aviv, Palestine (סידני שוורץ). במקום המיועד לבול, צויין כי הגלויה נדפסה באוסטריה. ככל הנראה, היא הופקה בראשית שנות השלושים של המאה העשרים. גלויה זו לא היתה בשימוש.
אגם ורתר.#أجام فرتر

ערבי חובש תרבוש בירושלים עומד במרפסת, ברקע עמק ממילא בירושלים, בית הקברות המוסלימי, מלון המלך דוד, מגדל ימק"א#شاب عربي يعتمر طربوشاً في القدس ويقف على الشرفة، وفي الخلفية يظهر وادي مأمن الله، مقبرة مأمن الله، فندق الملك داود، برج جمعية الشبان المسيحيين
לקט חומרי בערה
חליבה ברפת

records.title: The Revisionist Movement, Irgun Tzevai Leumi (Etzel) and Lochamei Herut Israel (Lehi) 1929-1948.

descriptions.value: Born 1923 in Jerusalem to Halpren family. Parents emphasized education and civic duties. Age 14 joined Etzel. Injured preparing explosives, 1939. Later moved to Tel Aviv. Imprisoned by British, 1944. When released in 1948 left Etzel, established established Hebrew Youth (Kenaanim) with others. Philosophy of Hebrew Youth: Hebraism before Judaism. Viewed Hebraism as nationalism exclusive to Israel; Judaism as ethnicity incorporating several languages and places. Aliyah as strengthening concept of ethnicity and religion rather than Hebraism. Attempted to establish center for Hebrew Youth when studying in Jerusalem, 1948. Helped establish League for Prevention of Religious Cocercion in 1950. Active until 1968, fighting especially for civil marriages.

records.title: Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: Arrived to Austria, 1945. Discusses: relation with Eli Bohnen; working with D.Ps in camps; greater influence held by U.S. Army, vs. UNRRA; contact with high level Army officials; D.Ps suspicion when told to transfer to better quarters; removing Austrians from apartments to make place for D.Ps; 'New Palestine' housing complex; getting a hold of food and clothing; 'SOS' (Save Overseas Survivors) for Americans to donate supplies; workshop established by JDC for D.Ps to produce own religious objects; chaplains as buffer between Jews and Army personnel, and Army and JDC; chaplains' role in getting U.S. doors open to survivors; involvement in Aliyah Bet' role of chaplains in sending money and guns to Palestine.

records.title: Anders' Army Defectors in Eretz Israel.

descriptions.value: Service in Polish army. Defeat of unit at beginning of war. Flight from Germans and capture by Russians. Forced labor near Moscow and in Siberia. Enlistment in Anders' Army with friends, 1942. Arrival in Israel and desertion shortly thereafter with aid from relatives, 1943. Change of name when leaving Anders' Army.

records.title: The Zionist Underground in Soviet-Occupied Poland, 1939-1941.

descriptions.value: חבר בקן השומר הצעיר בפשמישל. קיץ 1939: הכנות בתנועה לימי המלחמה הקרבים; פרוץ המלחמה והעברת השטח לשליטת הרוסים. דיונים בתנועה כיצד יש לפעול תחת המשטר מסובייטי; המשף הפעילות בתנועד עד לאמצע 1940; הקשר עם לבוב ועם ההנגה הארצית; נסיונות לחציית הגבולות; אירועי יום המהפכה בשנת 1940: מעצרים של חברי התנועה בלבוב, חזרתו לפשמישל וניתוק כמעט מוחלט עם פעילים בלבוב ועם ההנגה; המשך פעילות התנועה, פעילות הקשרים; פלישת גרמניה לשטיחים הרוסיים ותחילת המלחמה במזרח; סוף פרשת העצורים והמשך הפעילות.

records.title: Jewish Life in Arab Countries; Jewish Life in Middle Eastern Countries.

descriptions.value: נולד בעיר זאכו, עלה לארץ בשנת 1951. מספר על התנועה הציונית שהשתרשה בזאכו בשנים 1938-37, והעברת עולים מעיראק דרך זאכו, לסוריה ומשם לישראל. מספר על היחסים הטובים בין המקומיים והיהודים, שאפשרו העברת אנשים רבים. התנועה הציונית הטילה עליו ללמד עברית בזאכו, ואכן לימד ילדים בסתר את השפה העברית ושירים ציונים. נכלא עם פעילים אחרים בתנועה בבית הסוהר בשל הנפת דגל ישראל ביום העצמאות בשנת 1949. מספר על התנועה הציונית הגדולה בבגדד, העברת מכתבים ומגביות שהעבירו לישראל ואותן קיבלו חזרה בהגיעם לארץ. עיקר הפעילות הייתה בקרב ילדים ונוער, היות וראשי הקהילה לא תמכו בפעילות הציונית מתוך פחד.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Niza Margalith grew up and attended high school in Haifa. She served in the military, got married an has four children. When her children grew up she trained to be a medical secretary, she works in a private clinic.#NM's mother immigrated in 1937. Her father had already been interned for three years at Dachau concentration camp, when he could escape with the famous refugee ship “Patria”. On the ship he was the crewman who was chosen to place the bomb. He was then imprisoned by the British in Atlit, where he met NM's mother who worked there as a nurse. Her maternal grandmother is also a camp survivor; she converted to Judaism when she married an Hungarian rabbi. She was the first one of the family who was deported to a concentration camp. She emigrated to Palestine/Israel at the age of 60, when NM was a baby. Her mother and grandmother told NM many things about the past. NM understood her parents' terrible experiences only at the age of about 15. She has told her own children about it. She is not able to look at pictures from the Holocaust, but her mother watches many TV documentaries about this subject. NM's husband, who also comes from a Yekkish family, works as a travel guide for German groups, therefore NM has many contacts to Germans.#NM's Yekkish parents were very strict. Their attitude towards food and left-overs were formed by their concentration camp experience. Nevertheless NM likes the orderliness and discipline in Germany. She analyzes the advantages and disadvantages of discipline and states that her bosses, 7 doctors in a private clinic, appreciate her precise work. They say that the clinic is so well run only because she is a “jeckete”.#Her mother has some traumatic memories of her youth in Regensburg. NM's maternal grandmother was from Ravensburg, Germany, her grandfather came from Hungary. The Christian family of her grandmother was upset when she married a rabbi and converted. NM went to Regensburg for the first time in 1957 together with her mother; some relatives still live there. NM speaks German well because her parents continued to speak German at home because of the grandmother. NM didn't learn Hebrew before she came to the kindergarten. Her grandmother felt homesick until she died. NM loved her grandmother very much. NM was educated strictly, but she was also spoilt sometimes. NM's father was a sculptor, but in Israel he worked as a joiner; he died in 1975.#NM often goes to see her mother's friends in Regensburg, she has a close relationship to this city. NM thinks that she has a slight Bavarian accent, her grandmother had a strong accent. NM's mother still clings to Germany very much. NM states that she, despite of all, likes to visit Germany.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Maiden name: Anitta Berger. Born 09/12/1919, Brno. Attended a primary school in Baden and a Gymnasium, diploma in a Viennese commercial school. Emigration to Turkey in July 1938, where she worked as governess. Immigration to Palestine in 1941. Since 1960 first assistance (for the German correspondence), later independent work in a solicitor's office specialized in reparation claims (compensation). Chairwoman of a German-speaking lodge and head of the “Former Austrians in Jerusalem”.#Anitta Goldschmidt's family and her happy childhood: Her father came from Vienna, he moved to Brno during World War I, worked as businessman in textiles. The family moved to Baden when she was two years old; after ten years, they moved back to Vienna, where A. G. lived for another seven years. Because of the political situation she gave up her plan to study (chemistry) at the university and acquired instead of that a diploma at a Viennese commercial school. She emigrated in July 1938. Her mother came from Triesch in Moravia, but German was her mother tongue, she also knew Czech, but her father did not. A. G. grew up in a wide and warm social net. All family members played musical instruments. They were a religious family, but they were open to friends from other religions. There were only two other Jews in her class. A.G. has never known Yiddish (what she considers as disadvantage for her actual voluntary work with new immigrants from Russia). She has two sisters, both live in Israel. The caretaker of their house protected them from raids despite his antisemitic remarks. The Jewish and Christian classmates in her school still respected each other after the annexation. Some even left the NSDAP when they heard what happened. The headmaster of her school gave her the diploma several months before the end of the school year because he guessed that she might want to emigrate.#Anitta Goldschmidt's first years of emigration and the fates of her family members: In Turkey, the sisters lived under permanent observation of the police. In December 1940, they were almost deported as German spies but were able to use connections to get back their visa. Soon afterwards, A.G. decided to emigrate to Palestine with a student's certificate. She could not take any belongings from Turkey to Palestine. Her mother, sisters and brother in law joined the “Freie Oesterreicher” (Free Austrians) of Dr. Heizinger and arrived in Palestine illegally half a year after A.G. Their father was interned in Slovakia on his way to Vienna in 1938 and was shot during an escape attempt. Anitta Goldschmidt's life in Palestine and her difficult immigration: A.G. went from Turkey to Palestine by train. The train was stopped in Aleppo because of the Syrian-Palestine conflict, therefore she went on by taxi. At the Palestinian border, she was arrested as a spy and interned in the camp of Atlit; she was freed after she was able to prove that she was an Austrian emigrant. The continuing journey by train to Jerusalem was also difficult because of the war. She was not able to study at the university, because she did not know Hebrew. She tried to learn Hebrew beside her first jobs, but gave up after half a year. She found well paid employments in a Yugoslav governmental office and as a waitress. Later she decided to marry instead of going to the university. She has two daughters and seven grandchildren.#Her husband who had come from Germany (East Prussia) died in 1968. He had served in the British army; because of a cerebral damage acquired during the war, he was paralyzed for ten years. The British did not recognize the war-injury, therefore A.G. does not get a widow's pension. It was difficult to raise her daughters alone.#Mixed biographical events, her attitude towards politics and languages: A.G. learned English at school; at present, she reads books and newspaper only in English. She now feels satisfied about her life, but many of her friends committed suicide or married British men who exploited them. - She thinks that the Germans face their political past more frankly than the Austrians do. She has renewed the contacts to her Austrian classmates. - She considers the atrocities in the concentration camps as medieval; international politicians knew about the camps but closed their eyes. She tells how she tried to arrange the departure of relatives from Austria to Turkey without success. (Flashbacks: The bureaucratic difficulties when she arranged their own departure from Austria; the Austrian joy about the annexation. Her journey by train to Turkey, working as governess of the son of the Head of Protocol. She considers her life among the diplomats as interesting, the governesses were treated well. She watched the funeral of Ataturk. Her first winter in Turkey was difficult because her possessions had not arrived.)#Neither her children nor her grandchildren ask a lot of questions about her past, but at the time of the interview she is writing down her memories. She is a friend of Gerda Hoffer who is also interviewed in this project. About her marriage: A.G. married in 1944. Her husband fell ill in the army two months after the wedding and almost died. Despite of many difficulties she managed to travel to Suez Canal and stayed with him for six weeks; bureaucratic difficulties when she tried to bring him home. She got to know her husband while she worked in a restaurant; he had finished his hachshara in Sweden after his Abitur (A-levels; matura) and had immigrated illegally to Palestine in 1935.#Anitta Goldschmidt's language biography, her attitude towards languages and her national identity: She only spoke standard German in Vienna. Analysis of the difference between the Austrian and the German vocabulary which she noticed when she talked with her husband. She did not have dialect- or Yiddish-speaking friends in Vienna. Her own language did not change, though she used official Standard-German for her international correspondence. German is spoken during the meetings of her lodge, but with her children she speaks Hebrew. The elder daughter and her husband still know German, but she stopped speaking German with her daughters when they came to Kindergarten, where they were attacked because of speaking the “enemy's language”. A.G. thought that a bilingual education would be expecting too much of them. She learned Hebrew by listening to it, but she still makes bad mistakes when she writes Hebrew. Soon after her arrival in Palestine she was accused that she did not know Yiddish. First she only wanted to communicate in English and learn Hebrew. She gave up her intention because of the bad treatment by the British during her entry. - A. G. feels as an Israeli, she has never felt an Austrian identity during her youth. Today, she supports the Israeli-Austrian association for political reasons. The Zionist organizations in Vienna granted a pension to her. - (Flashbacks with more details.) First return to Austria in 1955: When she wanted to see her former apartment in Baden, she was insulted by the new owner and not allowed to see it. - (About illnesses etc.).

records.title: Jewish Newcomers from the USSR - Their Jewish Consciousness.

descriptions.value: Born in Staro Konstantinov, Podolia region, Ukraine in 1941 to family of clerks. Relocation of family to Ural, beginning of WWII, 1941. Return to Zhmerinka, Ukraine, 1943. Studies at Russian school, 1948-1958. Relocation to Odessa and studies at naval engineering institute. Engineer in Sovetskaya Gavan, 1958-1966, and in Vinnitsa, 1966. Ethnic relations after WWII (during studies and at work). Family immigrating to Israel, 1990.

records.title: The Defenders of Mount Scopus in 1948.

descriptions.value: Was amongst first group to go to Old City (Jerusalem) before it fell. Discusses: episodes from Mount Scopus; attacks made from buildings at Hebrew University; fate of convoy to Hadassah; events at Dir Yasin; being wounded; friends who were with him; university library during attacks; scandal of retreat from Mount Scopus to Hadassah; going out for social activity on Mount Scopus; food; shortage of cigarettes; how he was saved from fate of Hadassah convoy.

records.title: Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: 1st Interview: An earlier interview that, with some variation, deals with the same issues as the one from February 1975.#2nd Interview: Assigned as Jewish Chaplain for the 8th Corps Headquarters of 3rd Army. Entered Germany Pesach, 1945. Discusses: life in Buchenwald following liberation (holding Sabbath services; trying to contact family of survivors); how the Holocaust shaped survivors' Jewishness; 'Kibbutz Buchenwald' and Zionist survivors who wanted to go to Palestine; distribution of 500 Swiss visas to survivors; Jews who fled once Russian rule came into effect; establishment of D.P. camps; dealing with illegal goods; relations with Rabbi Robert Marcus and Rabbi Zemach; role, and criticism of, JDC.

records.title: Evacuation and Flight of Jews in the USSR during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born in Luchinyets, 1919. Family moving to Vinnitsa, 1926. Leaving city with Red Army towards Central Asia, August 1941.

records.title: Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: Served US Army as chaplain: April 1942-February 1946. Discusses: unofficial liaison between local Rabbi's, community leaders and military; aiding refugees; work in Palermo, Italy; High Holiday services; help received from Christian chaplains; Jewish Holidays; awards; US Army's reaction to his work; relations between DP's, refugees and US Army.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Czechoslovakia. Member of Kibbutz Maanit. Senior member of Absorption Department of Jewish Agency until 1956. Aliyah activities of Hakibbutz Haartzi; Hashomer Hatzair executive, 1945. Representative of Jewish Agency and later administrator of Athlit detention camp. Active in Central Housing Committee in Tel Aviv from 1949. Contacts with authorities in Cyprus responsible for immigrants en route at sea. Active absorption and dispersal of newcomers in settlements and transit camps, 1948. Difficulties in housing and employment and in absorption of socially problematic immigrants. Newcomers preferring to settle in urban centers. Policy of integrating different communities. Establishment of Amidar, 1949. Establishment of Kiryat Gat. Permanent housing partly financed by newcomers, 1953. Work villages, 1954 onwards.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Original name: Gerhard Mandel. Born 1929, Vienna. Emigration to Palestine in 1939. Secondary school in a children's home. “Gymnasium” (grammar school) in Jerusalem and Tel Aviv. Studies of Hebrew literature and theology, later history in Jerusalem. He became teacher in a grammar school and in a teachers' seminary, later literary scholar and university professor.#Gershon Shaked's childhood and family: His mother's parents fled from Lemberg (Lvov) to Vienna because of a Russian pogrom during World War I. About his mother's many siblings and their fates. His father's parents came from Belz; about the fates of his family during World War II. Both parents ran wool shops. Compared with the economic difficulties of Jews from Galicia, his parents' shops were quite successful. His mother's mother was illiterate, but deeply religious. Shaked's family lived in district X (Favoriten) in Vienna. Though the family was not rich, his father engaged a piano teacher and a private Hebrew teacher for his son (because of his “economic” and cultural ideals). Shaked's parents were not very educated themselves. In Israel, his mother only learned enough Hebrew to talk a little bit with her grandchildren and to go shopping. Shaked's daughters laughed about their grandmother's mistakes in Hebrew; but she read German newspapers and started to read German literature at the age of 60. Shaked's father was a Zionist. He went already to Palestine in 1920, but could work only as agricultural and road worker and fell ill; his mother and his wife wanted him to come back. After the time in Palestine he first despised the orthodox faith. His desire had not been to become a merchant, as he was more a bohemian and would have liked to become an actor; sometimes he performed as a solo dancer (“Eintänzer”). - Analysis of the (not only Jewish) middle-class families in Vienna who used to have maids or nannies even for a single child. - Shaked went to a very small school at Karolinerplatz. He visited the school lately during a stay in Vienna. (Episode: He found again two schoolmates when his memoirs were published in English: His former best friend, who practiced as a lawyer in New York, read the memoirs; he found out that the Hebrew name Shaked means “almond” in English#and “Mandel” in German and figured that the author could be his former classmate. He wrote him a letter. Details about the fates of Shaked's friends after 1938.) Gershon Shaked's first years in Palestine: About his parents' complicated illegal emigration to Palestine in September 1939. His father was interned in Buchenwald until he got a visa for Barbados. Instead of going there, he tried to go illegally to Palestine via Belgrad and Budapest, with a lot of complications. Gershon had immigrated alone several months before in April. He could not join the children's transport because he got measles. His mother, who had gone to Poland before the war started, was also arrested during these months. About his lonely journey to Palestinel via Trieste and his lonely arrival.#For the first five years, Gershon Shaked lived in a children's home and school. He had already learned reading at the age of four because of his aunt's books. This aunt lived already in Palestine and helped him. The conditions for the children in the home were poor, but he appreciated the teachers. Repeated return to the topic of the books he read (German literature, history, psychology). His parents first lived in the south of Tel Aviv. In their small apartment, they collected books of German immigrants, mainly for waste paper trading (recycling). Gershon Shaked tried to save those of famous authors for himself. He started only some years later with reading Hebrew literature intensively, when he was sent to a prestigious grammar school in Jerusalem because he was considered to be very talented. He stayed there only for one year because he felt like an outsider among his schoolmates, who were mostly children of big functionaries of the Labor Union. He then moved to Tel Aviv and attended another grammar school there. He thinks that his teachers there were rather boring. About his interest in Marxist literature. He joined a group of young poets and wrote some publications.#Gershon Shaked's career and family: He did his military service during the War of Independence at the age of 19. Then he decided to study Hebrew literature and theology in Jerusalem. (He gave up his dream of an artistic career because of the typical fear of middle-class people not to be able to earn a living, which his mother transferred to him.) In 1952, he voluntarily worked as teacher in refugee camps for Jewish immigrants from Iraq. He did his BA in 1953 and married. In 1957 he started his MA studies of history. (About the topics of his master and doctoral theses.) For eight years he worked as teacher in a grammar school and parallely in a teachers' seminary. The couple have two children. In 1964 Shaked finished his doctoral thesis and then worked as assistant at the university [and made an academic career: he talks only about some of his books]. Political opinions: About the Israeli-Palestinian conflict: Shaked thinks that the economic dependence of two peoples can force them to coexist peacefully (like Germany and France). - About the dominant role of the oil industry behind all political conflicts in the Middle East. General and personal remarks about psychoanalysis and his later skepticism towards Viennese psychological schools (comparing Jung and Freud).

records.title: Efforts to Help Soviet Jewry during World War II (Rescue Via Teheran).

descriptions.value: Born in Snyatyn, Ukraine. Wide range of youth movements. Being elected for leadership of Hanoar Haivri Akiba, 1939, but getting no hakhsharah due to WWII breaking out. Disassembly of group and attempts to preserve contacts. Organizing small groups, with Shimon Shpiner, trying to find a way to get to Vilna. Relocation to Lvov, 1940, to help movement but being recalled to hometown after NKVD discovering connections. Joining Red Army's retreat during German invasion. Work in kolkhoz in the Ukraine. Relocation to Samarkand, as the Germans approached. Unable to enter Persia. Studies in university of Samarkand. Organized connections within Hashomer Hatzair and contacts with Teheran, versus no connections within Akiba movement. Not being able to enlist in Anders Army and failing officers' course in Red Army due to Jewishness. Secretary of ZPP (Polish New Representatation), in charge of distribution of supplies. Organizing hakhsharah for a hundred Holocaust surviving children in Lvov, 1946, and immigration to Israel through Czechoslovakia, Austria and Italy.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Irit Ovadia grew up and attended high school in Jerusalem. After serving in the military she studied English and worked as a teacher in Be'er Sheva. In 1984 she became the manager of the local conservatory and organized students' exchanges. She is married and has 3 children.#IO's parents immigrated in 1939, her father studied and her mother worked as a nurse. Later her father fought in the War of Independence, in those years, IO's grandparents took care of her. IO's brother was killed in the Yom Kippur War in 1973.#IO is afraid she will make many grammatical mistakes when speaking German in the current interview, and thinks she will probably switch to English often. She has never learned German systematically. She thinks it was unusual in her generation that Yekkish parents spoke German with their children. Some of their friends were therefore angry with IO's mother. Her cousins don't know German at all. Today German is useful for IO's profession.#After she finished her military service, IO went to Paderborn together with the first German-Israeli student's group after an invitation by the Foreign Office because she spoke German. Not all of the members were Yekkish. After IO came back from this trip, she went to the US for 8 months. On her return to Israel she started to study at Be'er Sheva university and met her future husband, a sports teacher. IO's parents had nothing to object, i.e. with respect to his background; her parents in law came from Iraq and all of her husband's siblings are university graduates. IO became an English teacher at the new university of Be'er Sheva. After two years in Be'er Sheva, IO and her husband took their private residence in Omer. Some years ago her parents also moved from Jerusalem to Omer.#IO went to Germany for the first time when she was 15 years old in order to see some aunts in Dortmund. Her parents had gone there before. Before their journey her parents hardly ever spoke about Germany, her grandparents sometimes wanted to return. IO tells an episode how her father went pale from fright, when they were queuing in a post office in Cologne, and he all of a sudden recognized the horrible loud voice of a KZ-official from Buchenwald. Only then she understood what it meant to her father to be back in Germany., she had never asked him before. IO and AB discuss the fear of asking questions or telling about the past.#IO describes how she has slowly noticed the differences between Yekkish, East European and oriental culture in Israel. Her parents did not appreciate Yekkish virtues more than those of others. Even though they lived in Yekkish Rehavia, they sent IO and her brother to high schools with children from various ethnic backgrounds. IO describes the strict rules in other Yekkish homes, her parents were more “relaxed”. Her grandparents hardly knew Hebrew, her parents learned it well but still prefer to read German books. IO does not have negative feelings towards one of the languages. She tells about her father's professional career in Israel as professor and head of the Israeli State Archives.#IO's personal contacts in Germany and her knowledge of the language became useful during her work at the conservatory: she organized a students' exchange program. IO always takes the Israeli students to concentration camps when they visit Germany. She describes their discussions about coming to terms with the Holocaust. IO's parents did not have negative feelings towards young students from Germany. IO has never given up her personal contacts in Germany, she thinks that a general interest for interpersonal relationships is another reason for official international partnerships. IO's conservatory has partnerships with Wuppertal and Rosenheim, and furthermore IO has contacts with France and Belgium. IO is especially interested to organize common visits of young Germans and Israelis to concentration camps, she considers it as important for both sides. She would be interested to visit Buchenwald because her father was a prisoner there, but she is afraid to go. She has been to the 60-years-commemoration-ceremony of the “Kristallnacht” in Dachau. She felt proud of being there as an Israeli and she could understand the feelings of her students coming there with the Israeli flag. IO tells that staying in Wuppertal, the hometown of her father, is always exciting for her, her heart is pounding. Nevertheless she loves to be there with her parents. Staying in Bavaria is different, she remains a stranger though she has good friends. The mentality of the people is not familiar to her. IO thinks that her mentality is more similar to the mentality in North-West-Germany, because her family came from there and some of her relatives live there.

Born in Tripoli, 1907. Studies in Heder until the age of ten. Older brother studying in technical-commercial school. Teachers under supervision of the Jewish community. Community council giving children food at lunchtime, and clothing once a year. Relocation of family when he was eighteen. Studies in small local yeshiva. Studies in Italian school after Italian occupation. Zionist activities in the community, Hebrew lessons and arrival of emissaries from Israel. Relocation to Homs, 1928. Studying ritual slaughter (i.e. to serve as shochet). Organizing community school. Teaching Bible and Hebrew. Founding Ben-Yehuda culture club, similar to that in Tripoli, where people studied and staged Hebrew plays.

records.title: The Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: First went to Europe as chaplain, April 1945. Discusses: conveying information on D.P. situation to American Jewry; first encounter with Jewish survivors of Buchenwald; criticism of JDC's work in Europe; praise for specific JDC workers; need to work outside of law to be effective; underground activity in Czechoslovakia- forging documents, getting D.Ps to Israel; leeway granted to chaplains; army's desire to see D.Ps leave; assistance in underground work received from non-Jewish soldiers; chaplains' unique position; army's reception of his work; illegal mail service for D.Ps via chaplains; assistance from Jewish welfare Board; Simon Rifkin; return to Europe 1947 as civilian liaison between Jewish Agency and US Army; role in 'Brichah'; marriage among D.Ps; direct work in D.P. camps; his assistant- Simon Pava; receiving reprimand from Army; work in Augsburg; division between different groups of Jews in Augsburg; American ignorance of concentration camps; work in Theresienstadt; encountering Dachau; chaos upon end of war; contact with other chaplains; stealing supplies to give to D.Ps; Yom Kippur in Regensburg; anecdote of S.S. prisoners cleaning herring for Yom Kippur; American role in black market; D.Ps being tried for involvement in black market; army's negative perception of Jews.

records.title: Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: Chaplain assistant under Chaplain Bohnen, 42nd division, Infantry. Worked with Jewish D.Ps. Discusses: first encounter with survivors; Dachau liberation; D.P. camp in Salzburg; moral and physical state of survivors; contact between Jewish Chaplain and non-Jewish troops; U.S. package program; Jewish Brigade; package distribution; Army's response to package program; 'New Palestine'- administration, community services, cultural life; roles of UNRRA, 'Vaad Hahazalah'; Jewish Welfare Board; Anglo-American Commission visit. Part II: First section of file contains copies of letters Heimberg sent to his wife from Europe, discussing: misery of survivors; illness; Yom Kippur services; Dachau; success of package program; General Collins' visit to D.P. camp; bringing Torah to camp synagogue; school in D.P. camp; role as commandant of Jewish section of D.Ps camp, Austria; fear of D.Ps organizing illegal mass protest; fear of tension between soldiers and D.Ps; 'New Palestine' community, Salzburg; Chanukah; Billy Rose tour; Jewish Underground movement to Palestine; Christmas; conference of Central Committee for Liberated Jews of Europe; accounts of Dachau liberation.

records.title: Jews in the Czechoslovak Armies in World War II.

descriptions.value: From Jewish family in Subcarpathian Russia. Deported to camp in Hungary, 1939. Taken as Soviet prisoner of war. Heard of Svoboda army, half of soldiers were Jews. Wounded in Dukla battle. Antisemitism in Slovakia. Freedom of religion and Jewish culture in Svoboda unit. Heard about Holocaust only after war. Arrested, 1948. Family makes aliya; he follows in 1953. List of soldiers in Svoboda unit.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: History of Hapoel Hamizrachi. Its position in Yishuv until establishment of State of Israel. Attitudes towards Haoved Hadati. Establishment and purposes of religious coalition. Trend system in education. Labor trend. State education and state religious education. Mass immigration and attitude towards newcomers from oriental countries. Policy of integrating eastern and western immigrants and its lessons. Struggle over education of newcomers: position of religious parties. Socialization of newcomers by education. Attitude towards Yemenite newcomers and Libyan newcomers. Crisis in education in immigrant camps. Series of articles by Yehuda Dominitz in "Hazofeh" newspaper. Born in Czechoslovakia, 1926. Immigration to Israel via Youth Aliyah, 1939. Studies in yeshivot. Educator at Aliyah, Youth Aliyah facility in Petah Tikva. Youth Aliyah emissary to Italy, 1946-1949. Committee investigating religious coercion in Youth Aliyah camps in Italy. Bringing children who survived Holocaust to Israel. Youths from Hungary Poland, Yugoslavia and Libya in institute for religious youth in Florence. Camp for Tripolitan youth in Salerno, 1949. Assistant secretary in Immigration Department of Jewish Agency (JA). Disagreement over limitations on immigration between JA departments of immigration and Absorption. Attitudes of various political parties and of David Ben Gurion towards immigration. Series of articles published by interviewee in "Hazofeh" concerning crisis in education, 1948. Public#debate on education; differences between Hapoel Hamizrachi and Mizrachi. Work in Information Department of Mizrachi. Absorption of Libyan children into non-religious institutions.

records.title: Ha'apala (Illegal Immigration) from Italy, 1945-1948 [including material from the Haganah Archive].

descriptions.value: The Hagana; the Palmach; recruiting for the British Army; activities in Italy; "illegal" immigration from Italy. Born 1923. Studied in Kadurie school. Joined Palmah, 1941-42. Joined British Army, 1943. Yigal Allon's activities. Work as driver. Entry into Austrian camps. Reaction to seeing groups of orphans. Transfer of refugees to Italian seaboard. Excitement of refugees at seeing Jewish Brigade symbols. Released from Palmah and returned to Tel Katzir, 1946. Sent to work with Aliya Bet in Italy, 1947, mainly in acquiring and shipping guns. Blowing up arms ship in Bari. Capture by British, then released with help of Italians. Debates among Israelis whether to stay in Italy once War of Independence began. Attended pilots course in Czechoslovakia then joined Israeli air force.

records.title: Ha'apala (Illegal Immigration) from Italy, 1945-1948 [including material from the Haganah Archive].

descriptions.value: Joined British army. Sent in 1943 to Italy to Jewish brigade. Low morale(?) in unit. Attempt by small group to improve situation by volunteering to help Italian and refugee Jews and to aid in purchasing arms. Some money gathered by contributions from salaries of soldiers. Italy flooded with various groups of volunteers. Arguments over priorities for aliya, particularly among youth, suspicious after Holocaust experience. Problems caused by appearance of Partisan group Nakam under Abba Kovner resulted in expediting their aliya. Arguments between activists and Yigal Alon over aliya procedures.

records.title: The Educational Systems in Jewish DPS Camps in Germany and Austria 1945-1951.

descriptions.value: Born in 1912 in town of Bibolar, Romania. Studied at trade school in Iasi. Active in Noar Hatzioni movement. Outbreak of World War II worked as clerk in glass factory, supplying German army. In June 1947 left Romania illegally and crossed border to Transylvania. Moved to Debrecen in Hungary, then to Budapest, then to Rothschild hospital in Vienna, then to Shatmer displaced persons camp in American zone in Austria. All wanderings together with group of children in framework of Beriha. In August 1947 moved to Vogshied camp for a 11/2 years where active in central committee of Haoved Hatzioni movement. Well known figure among Romanian Jewry. Aliya in October 1948.

Born in Baden, 1921. Galician grandparents. Secular Zionist family. Father Hebrew-speaking and aliya oriented. Receiving Hebrew lessons and achieving fluency prior to emigration to Israel, 1933. Parents following, 1934. Living in Haifa. Attending the Reali high school. Academic education, Hebrew University. Joining the Hagana and the British Army. Social contacts with Israelis and German immigrants. Integration. High school teacher. Retirement. Running "Chidush" publishing house with wife.

Born in Krems. Move to Vienna in 1934 as antisemitism in Krems increases. Work as bookkeeper, arrest by Nazis after Anschluss. Immigration to Palestine. Activities with Betar. Army service. work as a driver and bookkeeper at the Israeli Air Industries.

records.title: Ultra-Orthodox Jewry in Eretz Israel during the British Mandate and Today.

descriptions.value: Claim of discrimination against ultra-Orthodox community in allotment of aliyah certificates because controlled by Zionist movement. Alternative routes to aliyah: Aliyah Bet, capitalist aliyah, yeshiva students. Founding Poalei Agudat Israel to protect these olim, most of whom became laborers. Crisis in 1927, resulting in large emigration from Eretz Israel and closing down Israel branch of Poalei Agudat Israel. Re-establishment in 1933, when many olim from Germany joined. Quarrels over ideology and distribution of resources developed and deepened between Poalei Agudat Israel, and Agudat Israel. Principal reasons for quarrels with Jerusalem wing of Aguda under leadership of Blau over issues of settlement and education. Appeal of Poalei Agudat Israel to Council of Torah Sages. Support of a small group, including Hazon Ish (Rabbi Avraham Karlitz) for Poalei Agudat Israel in area of work agreements, entry into National Employment Office, and acquisition of land from JNF for settlement.

records.title: אל קביבה, בית חנן, כוללת: כפר אהרן : מפתח למפות הגושים.
Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Czernowitz, Romania, 1922. Pioneer training in Transylvania. Leaving Bulgaria. Arrest in Cyprus. Participation in Rotenberg Seminary in Cyprus. Immigration to Israel, 1949. Brief residence in Kibbutz Sheluhot. Teaching in Pardes Hanna D immigration camp. Life in immigration camp. Methods for teaching adults (mainly from Bulgaria). Short term service as emissary of newly established Ministry of Education. Running school in Bet Arif, newcomers' settlement in abandoned Arab village. Summer school in Buber Teachers' Seminary. Teaching in Nahariya.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Djerba, Tunisia, in 1924. Member of religious Zionist youth movement Ateret Tzion. Jewish Agency (JA) worker from 1947, handling immigration affairs. Immigration of Jews to France and then to Israel with Aliya Bet (illegal immigration). Help in administrative affairs from member of Tunisian government. After Tunisians independence JA still active but more discreet; immigration supposedly to France with JA paying travel expenses. Work for JA in Tunis ostensibly as JDC immigration office. Emissaries from Israel coming in 1957 with instructions not to allow old people without support to immigrate; eventually abolished but not before interviewee's parents died in Tunisia. Minimal antisemitism in Tunisia. Aliya with family in 1957. Emissary to Tunisia, 1960-1965. JA worker in Israel, 1965-1968. Founding Tunisian Kisse Rahamim yeshiva, by instruction of Rabbi Matzliah Mazuz, chief rabbi of Tunisia. Many Tunisian newcomers settling in Israel with help from various political parties and their absorption usually successful, but many have left especially intellectuals. Most Jerban Jews stayed in Israel.

records.title: [קריאות ופיוטים בלחן של מסורת כורדיסטן, כוי סנג'ק] .הקלטת סקר [הקלטת שמע].
Reminiscences about My Father's House: Programs Recorded by Kol Yisrael.

descriptions.value: Born to Shabebu and Cohen families - who had both been in Tzfat for 500 years. Discusses: family background, and how they came to Israel; memories of Turkish rule; Sarah Aaronson; Dr. Hillel Yaffe; school in Zikhron Yaakov; bank; association with Romanian immigrants in Zikron Yaakov; different social positions of different ethnic groups; Arabs; death of sister; arrival of English in Zikhron; meeting Rothschild; appreciation and belief in British; anecdotes surrounding people encountered; 1929 riots in Tzfat. Born Eritrea. Father fled Yemen after freeing prisoners. According to legend mother's family was from lost tribes. Discusses: drive, inherited from father, to find lost tribes; leaders of Jewish communities of Yemen; his knowledge of history of Yemenite community; comparison between Yemen and Eritrea; contact with underground; Aliyah, 1930's; perception of Israel; difficulties of integration; fighting in British Army, WWII; meeting Pope; feeling, after Holocaust, that there is no God; meeting European Jews; father's death.

records.title: Mrs De Calderon, wife of Bolivian Ambassador in Israel meeying children of the Givat Hashalom school near Tel Aviv.
ISRAEL AND JORDAN OPEN THEIR BORDERS.

descriptions.value: Ever since the State of Israel's establishment in 1948, she has been in a state of war with the neighbour that shared more of Israel's border than any other country - Jordan. that state of war was ended with the Washington Declaration of 15 July 1994 and finally put into effect on the ground, 8 August 1994, in the Arava. There, Israel Prime Minister Yitzhak Rabin and Jordan's Crown Prince Hassan opened the first border crossing between the two countries 6 kilometres north of Eilat, in the presence of US Secretary of State Warren Christopher, Israel Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, Jordanian Prime Minister and Foreign Minister Abdel Salaam EI-Majali and a large assortment of other dignitaries. Rabin and Hassan cut a ribbon to work the opening of the border crossing - meanwhile open only to Israelis with foreign passports - with scissors handed to them by a pair of specially chosen young local Israeli and Jordanian girls. Prime Minister Rabin said in his speech: - “Friends say to us - The pace of events is too fast. We cannot keep up. Wait a moment'. Your Royal Highness, our friends in the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan, we have waited forty-six years. We have gone through war, pain and suffering. To prevent further loss and sorrow, we cannot wait even one day more”. Crown Prince Hassan's speech was a visionary one:; "The Aqaba-Eilat border gate represents a physical demonstration of our desire to promote inter-regional transportation networks...Our region is the birth place of civilization...In this gateway be a taken of our resolve that soon our peoples will be able to sharp, exchange and marvel at their common legacy". Photo shows The new Jordanian Tourist Office adjacent to the Arava checkpoint with Israel near Aqaba, already set up for visitors from Israel, 8 August 1994. the small complex of offices in the vicinity also houses a post office and a bank.

records.title: ירושלים: שכונת הכורדים, מרכז העיר, ישוב בהר ציון, נוף להר הזיתים.
המצבה על קבר שמעון הרצל, זמלין.

descriptions.value: שלושה הדפסי כסף מקוריים מתצלומים בשחור לבן, ובהם נראית המצבה על קברו של שמעון הרצל, סבו של בנימין זאב הרצל, מזוויות שונות. מצבה זו צולמה בבית העלמין היהודי של העיירה הסרבית זמלין (זמון - Земун). על פי המצויין בגב התצלומים, הם נשלחו אל ד"ר אברהם שבדרון בחודש סיוון תרצ"ט (מאי-יוני 1939) על ידי ד"ר יהודה שיק, זגרב. יש להניח כי תצלומים אלו הופקו סמוך לאותו זמן.

הדפס כסף מקורי מתצלום שבו נראה חיים נחמן ביאליק (שני מימין) בחברת הפועלים העמלים על יציקת הגג של ביתו הפרטי ברחוב ביאליק, תל אביב. במרכז התצלום (חובש מגבעת ומפנה מבטו לימין) נראה המהנדס האחראי על הבנייה, שמואל (סם) ברקאי. תצלום זה צולם, ככל הנראה, ב-15 באוקטובר 1924. התצלום נתרם לספרייה הלאומית בשנת 1935 על ידי מר אריה ויינברג, שהשתתף בבנייה.

records.title: בית הולדתו של יעקב הרצל בעיירה זמלין, סרביה.

descriptions.value: הדפס כסף מקורי מתצלום שחור לבן שבו נראה הבית ברחוב היהודים אשר בעיירה הסרבית זמלין (זמון - Земун) שבו נולד בשנת 1835 אביו של בנימין זאב הרצל, יעקב הרצל. בגב התצלום נוספה הערה בכתב ידו של ד"ר אברהם שבדרון באשר לזיהוי התצלום, וכן צויינה כתובתו המדוייקת של הבית, שהיה ביתם של רבקה ושמעון הרצל (סבו וסבתו של תיאודור הרצל): רחוב אפוסטל (Apostelgasse) מס' 223, זמלין (Zemun). על התצלום לא צויין תאריך כלשהו, ויש לשער כי הוא הופק ברבע הראשון של המאה העשרים.

גלויה מסוג Real photo ובה תצלום בשחור-לבן של עמק המצלבה, מכיוון צפון-מערב. במרכז התצלום נראה מנזר המצלבה וברקע, בתי שכונת רחביה. על הגלויה לא צויינו שם הצלם או תאריך הצילום, אך יש להניח כי דימוי זה הופק בשנות החמישים של המאה העשרים. גלויה זו לא היתה בשימוש, והיא הופקה על ידי חברת פלפוט (Palphot, Herzlia) בישראל, בשנות החמישים או בראשית שנות השישים של המאה העשרים.
סג'ר אל ארוס
הקמת מגדל המים של קיבוץ גבעת חיים עבודת הבניין של חברי הזורע

records.title: History of the Jewish Police (Jewish Division of the Mandatory Police).

descriptions.value: Born in Jerusalem, 1919. Member of Hagana. Service in Jewish Division of Mandatory police, 1938-1944. Noter (guardsman) in Hartuv, Atarot and Jerusalem, 1938-1939. Training instructor for the police in Jerusalem Kishle, 1940-1944. Service in Israeli police, 1948-1972. Work in Tel Aviv security unit accompanying David Ben-Gurion. Investigations officer in detectives section. Activities in Sheikh Jarrah (Jerusalem) during Six Day War. Retired as chief inspector.

Apprenticed with shoemaker in Zakho. Engaged in sending rafts of wood to Mosul, then opened a store in Christian village, returning every Shabbat to Zaco. Jews of Zaco, young and old, devotedly prayed every day. At age 17 he left Zaco.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Moknine, Tunisia in 1922, to religious family of merchants and industrialists. Zionist activists. Relocation to Sousse, 1927. Jewish French education. Antisemitism during WWII. Member of Scout movement from 1941; head of movement from 1942. Volunteer work for Jewish Agency (JA). Hard labor during German occupation, 1942. Occupation and local nationalistic trends reinforcing tendencies towards immigration. Aliya of Tunisian Jews delayed by lack of economic distress. Representative immigration affairs of Sousse Jews at the JA. Four thousand immigrants. French occupation liberal as long as activities discreet; after independence in 1956 passports to France available. Fighting for immigration rights of elderly people without financial support once community emigrated to Israel. Relations with emissaries from Israel. Independence arousing apprehensions ascending dominance of Arabic culture vis-a-vis French culture. Brutal interrogation about activities in the Jewish National Fund followed by five-year prevension from leaving Tunisia. Subsequent immigration department activities more discreet. Aliya, 1962, fear of authorities. Absorption in Israel.

records.title: Ethiopian Jewry: Historical Traditions, Aliya and Absorption.

descriptions.value: Born in Ethiopia. Great Famine in Ethiopia causing Jews to forget their origins and convert to Christianity. People ate roots and were eaten by animals.#המרואיין קיס יליד טיגראי. מוצא משפחות שני הוריו מוולקאי. הוא מתאר את הרעב, עליו מספרים מדור לדור, ששרר באתיופיה במשך 7 שנים, עקב היעדר שלטון, בצורת, ארבה. בני אדם רבים מתו ברעב וכן נאכלו ע"י חיות טרף. המרואיין למד בבית עם אביו בטיגראי. היו יהודים שהרעב גרם להם להתנצר. חלקם חזרו ליהדות בתום הרעב וחלק לאו. אחרי תקופת הרעב בוצעה חלוקת קרקעות; הקרקע הפורייה יותר ניתנה לנוצרים, ליהודים כמעט שלא ניתנו נחלות.

records.title: Jewish Newcomers from the USSR - Their Jewish Consciousness.

descriptions.value: Born in Smela, Ukraine, 1925. Smela almost entirely Jewish before and after revolution. Father construction technician; mother housewife. Family moving to Yerevan, Armenia, due to father's work. Only two other Jewish families there in those years. Studies in Russian class at Armenian school. Family returned to Kiev in 1938. Studies at Ukranian school. Family evacuated to Zelenodol'sk, Russia in 1941. Relocation to Kazan' in 1943. Marriage, 1946. Graduated economics institute. Work in factory until retirement in 1976. Aliya with son's family, 1991.

records.title: Ethiopian Jewry: Historical Traditions, Aliya and Absorption.

descriptions.value: Life in Kefar Batya, 1960-1962. Farm manager and instructional director. First meetings with Ethiopian children who arrived in Kefar Batya in 1960-1962 and noting their progress. Emissary to Ethiopia. Meeting with former Kefar Batya students.

records.title: Jews of Greece before, during and after the Holocaust.

descriptions.value: Andreas: born in Athens, 1935, to a secular Zionist family. He and his family escaped Athens by boat for Crete, Spring 1941. When Germans occupied Crete family went by foot through the mountains to the South Coast. There they were let on an Australian ship used to evacuate British troops to Alexandria. They lived in Egypt and Palestine for the duration of the war. Describes their return to Athens and discusses some issues concerning Jewish Greeks in the 1970s: anti-Semitism and Jewish education.

records.title: The Revisionist Movement, Irgun Tzevai Leumi (Etzel) and Lochamei Herut Israel (Lehi) 1929-1948.

descriptions.value: Describes relations between Lehi and Etzel: imprisonment of many Lehi members, 1940-42, as result of informants; executions of Pritzker and Yelenchik; organization of Lehi prisoners in jail to read books on explosives; beginning of collaboration between Etzel and Haganah, 1947, following increased Arab attacks; Lehi's position against internationalizing Jerusalem; decision to establish underground movement in Jerusalem; enlisting in Zahal after declaration of Independence.
A felucca.

records.title: Jüdische Frauen und Mädchen in Sana'a. (Aufnahme von Hermann Burchardt.) Orient-Verlag, Berlin.

descriptions.value: Text on the back -Postkarte:In der Landschaft Yemen in Südarabien lebten noch vor kurzem etwa 50.000 Juden. Fortwährende Verfolgungen seitens der fanatischen Einwohner, die sich zudem in stetem Aufruhr gegen die türkische Regierung befinden, und die elende wirtschafliche Lage, die sich oft bis zu Hungersnöten steigert, haben diese jüdische Bevölkerung dezimiert. Gegenwärtig versucht es der Rest, sich durch die Auswanderung nach Palästina zu retten, dem nächsten Gebiet, wo Juden unter günstigeren Verhältnissen leben. Diese Einwanderung anspruchsloser, arbeitwilliger und intelligenter Leute bringt dem allgemeinen jüdischen Kolonisationswerk in Palästina, das zurzeit mehr als 40 landwirtschaftliche Ansiedlungen mit ca. 12.000 Einwohnern umfasst, in den verschiedensten Hinsichten ganz außerordentlichen Nutzen, so daß die Rettung der yemenitischen Juden gleichzeitig auch dem grossen Felde der jüdischen Palästina-Bestrebun#Back Printed Text Translation - Postcard:(Approximate translation) In the region of Yemen, in South Arabia, lived still recently about 50,000 Jews. The continual pursuits from the fanatic inhabitants, in constant riots against the Turkish government, as well as the miserable economic situation which often increases up to starvation, have decimated this Jewish population. At the present time, the rest of the population tries to get saved by emigration to Palestine, the next area, where Jews live under more favorable conditions. The emigration of undemanding, work-willing and intelligent people activates the Jewish colony in Palestine, which covers now more than 40 agricultural settlements with approx. 12,999 inhabitants. Thus, the rescue of Yemenite Jews as well as the large field of the Jewish colony came out right. For these reasons, the association 'Ezra' makes considerable means for the removal of the Yemenites and for their maintenance in the first time.#Production period - ca. 1910#Front Period - ca. 1910#Category - Jewish types#Description - This horizontal postcard depicts a photograph of Jewish Yemenite children - maybe a class photograph. They are standing in rows, in a photographic pose. They are traditionally dressed: Girls wear large dresses and traditional headdresses called Kirkoush or Gargush (kind of hood covering the head, neck, throat and part of the shoulders); boys wear tunics recovered sometimes with a kind of Tallit, called Shamle in Sana'a. (It is a large black wool cloth worn on the shoulders, which was used as a blanket too). They also wear a low dark felt cap (Kufiyeh).[S.H]
