records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Bukovina region, Rumania, 1928. Father's job as a railway worker necessitated family's frequent relocation from one provincial town to another. Establishing branch of Deror Habonim, 1945. Participation in movement seminar in Italy and later in France. Denied possibility of return to Romania. Detention in Hungarian prison, 1948. Sent by Arthur Ben Natan in France to help organize the rescue of Jews from Innsbruck (French zone in Austria). Smuggling Jews into Italy in two trains. Coordinator of Youth Aliya center in southern France where North African children were gathered before immigrating to Israel. Sailing from Marseille to Israel aboard the Artza, 1951. Member of Kibbutz Gesher. Parents unexpectedly granted exit permits by Chivu Stoica, then Prime Minister of Hungary, when there was no aliya from Romania, 1953. Brother immigrating via the Netherlands, 1950, under the auspices of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee, Youth Aliya and the Red Cross.

records.title: Jews in the Yugoslav Partisan Movement during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born Czechoslovakia, 1926 to religious family. Studied in yeshiva. Family members sent, along with all Polish citizens, to Aushwitz. Was living in Hungary at time, in hopes of making Aliyah. Captured, along with other Jews, and sent to labour camp in Yugoslavia. Hoped to join Tito's Partisans. Remained in labour camp 6 months, unsuccessful in joining Partisans. Finally managed to flee camp. Was caught by !Tzetniks and placed in their camp with other Jews. There studied to be medic. Caught in Partisan attack on !Tzetniks. Interrogated then included in 19th Battalion as medic. Injured in battle. Went to Romania. Caught and placed in internment camp with Germans. Fled to Bucharest. From there made Aliyah.

records.title: The Jewish Underground Movement in the USSR in the 1930s and 1940s.

descriptions.value: המרואיין יליד 1904, מהעיר דוברוסי שבמולדביה, אותה עזב בהיותו בן 4 למוגילב -פודולסק שבאוקראינה. למד ב"חדר" מגיל 4 וחצי ולאחר מכן, מדי יום אצל מורה פרטי עד גיל 17 וחצי. לאביו הייתה הסמכה לרבנות מישיבת וילנה. בגיל 15 הצטרף ל"צעירי ציון", ולמד עברית והיסטוריה של עם ישראל עפ"י גרץ ודובנוב אצל המורה בראילב. באותה עת, חבריו לקבוצה בני ה- 20 ומעלה כבר הוכשרו במקצועות החקלאות ועלו לישראל. לא היה מודע לפעילות ציונית בערים אחרות. השתתף בפלוגת יהודים להגנה עצמית, בה נוצר הצורך נוכח חילופי השלטון התדירים. היה ממונה על ספרייה בת 600 ספרים בעברית, שנאסר מטעם השלטונות הסובייטיים להחזיקם, ושאותם הסתיר למנוע את לקיחתם. מסיבה זו, בהיותו בן 16 נאסר ל-3 שבועות. 1928-1922 למד לימודי הנדסה בקייב, שם לימד עברית סטודנטים וילדים יהודיים בהסתר, בלי שיהיה מקושר לארגון ציוני כלשהו ובלי ידע על המתרחש בארץ, נוכח מגבלות "מסך הברזל". 1941-1929 גויס ושירת כמהנדס במפעל צבאי למנועי מטוסים, שבמסגרתו פונה עם משפחתו, בפרוץ המלחמה, לאומסק שבסיביר, שם נפטרו אביו ובתו הצעירה ממחלות ורעב. בקשתו להתגייס לצבא נענתה בשלילה.#באומסק המשיך ללמד עברית עד 1944, אז הועבר במסגרת עבודתו החסויה למוסקבה, שם התגורר עד סוף 1949, תוך שממשיך לחלוק מידיעותיו בעברית עם יהודים בלי שהיה חלק מארגון כלשהו. נאסר ב- 1950, בעקבות הבעת תמיכה בישראל במהלך בחירות ברוסיה ונידון ל- 10 שנות מאסר בלי משפט. עבר בין בתי כלא שונים שבכולם נכלאו יהודים רבים, כולל וורקוטה. שוחרר בתום 6 וחצי שנים ב- 1956, נסע למוסקבה, שם שהה עד 1961, לימד עברית והפיץ עיתונים ישראלים שאותם קיבל משגרירות ישראל, בערים שונות. בעקבות פעילות זו נאסר על בסיס הלשנה של בני משפחתו, נשפט ל-7 שנים באשמת פעילות ציונית אנטי-סובייטית וישב במחנות שונים עד 1968. באותה שנה נאסר שוב לחצי שנה, ובסופו של דבר קיבל אישור להתגורר בבנדרי הסמוכה לקישינב. בני משפחתו הסתירו ממנו 2 דרישות העלייה הראשונות שנשלחו מישראל על שמם. עלה לישראל עם אשתו ב- 1973.

records.title: Testimonies from Holocaust Survivors in the United States.

descriptions.value: Born 1914 in Bochnia, Poland. Father restaurant owner, mother housewife. Served in Polish army, 1937-38. Worked as glazier when war broke out. In Bochnia ghetto from August, 1940 through November, 1942. Denounced then sent to Auschwitz in December, 1942. Sent to Mauthausen in December, 1944 then to Theresienstadt in March, 1945. Liberated there by Russians in May, 1945. In Breslau for one year, Mindleheim for five years. Move to United States, 1951.

UNED Born in Sofiya in 1936. Deterioration in state of Jews in Bulgaria. Deportation of Jews to labor camps. Emigration of Jews to Palestine and other countries. Economic and social state of Bulgarian Jews. Family managing to get certificates and immigrate to Israel. Emigration to Italy after the war.

records.title: Anders' Army Defectors in Eretz Israel.

descriptions.value: Chaplain and captain in Polish army. About 3500 Jews in Anders Army of whom 1500 deserted. Much antisemitism in Polish army but not in Carpati Division in which he served with 2000 other Jews. Antisemitism hindering promotion of Jews. Reasons for desertion: Polish antisemitism in Poland and attention of relatives and friends in Israel. Fear of fighting at Italian front. Policy of Anders' Army not to search for Jewish deserters. Those remaining, mainly officers who felt bound by their military oath. Righteous gentiles among Polish officers, for example Kopanski, Durko, Galadyk. Rejection of Stanislav Kopanski's suggestion to Polish General Staff in 1943, that Jews not wishing to continue service in army be allowed to leave. Polish Jews hiding from Nazis in Italy joining Carpati Division of Anders' Army.

descriptions.value: Original name: Anton Jaul. Born 01/15/1915, Neunkirchen (Austria). He attended the “Volksschule” (primary school) in Neunkirchen and a “Humanistisches Gymnasium” (comparable to a Brit. Grammar school emphasizing the study of the classics) in Wiener Neustadt. Studies of jurisprudence in Vienna. Emigration to Palestine in 1938. For the first two years he worked in pardessim of a community of the Betar, afterwards roadworker in Haifa and service in a Jewish batallion in the British army (the “Buffs”). Later he became an employee in the Israeli governmental customs office.#Naftali Jaul's life until his emigration and his relationship to Austria: He attended the “Volksschule” in Neunkirchen and a “Humanistisches Gymnasium” in Wiener Neustadt. After the matura he pursued studies of jurisprudence in Vienna until March 1938. He was a member of a right wing Zionist youth group (Beitar). He describes the situation and torments of the Jewish citizens in Vienna after 1938. He wanted to leave Austria and to go to Palestine. He remembers that he was already insulted several times as a child for being a Jew (“Saujud”). He had five siblings, his eldest brother, who ran the family business (a department store) in Neunkirchen after the father's early death in 1932, supported the whole family. - N.J. visited his father's grave in Neunkirchen after the War and during later visits. Apart from that, he is not interested and does not feel any need to go to Austria. Naftali Jaul's emigration and his first years in Palestine: He describes the difficulties he had when he wanted to depart from Vienna. Finally he could go by aeroplane from Vienna to Athens and stayed in Greece for one month. Then he went to Romania: difficult journey with ship and train to Galatz/Galati, where he joined a ship with 1.500 Jewish emigrants coming from Vienna and Bratislava. The whole transport was organized by Beitar. The passage took a whole month. When they arrived in Palestine near Netanya, they were brought ashore in smaller vessels at night and immediately transported further inland, where the new immigrants were received by foster families. N.J. left his family soon and joined a community of the Betar in Rishon Letzion; he worked there in the pardessim. After two years he left and joined a team of road workers in Haifa. - A brother and a sister of N.J. also came to Palestine soon. Another brother emigrated to Switzerland and moved on to Santo Domingo in 1940; he also came to Palestine in 1946.#Naftali Jaul's military service: Road work was physically too hard for him. Therefore he joined the British military group the “Buffs” in Haifa and finished training as a soldier. It was a Jewish group, but commanded by British officers. He served in the Second Bataillon, first in Egypt and Libya, then against German troops in Italy. After the end of World War II, he travelled all over Central Europe with his military unit. Their task was to guard the German prison camps and the harbors. He visited Bergen-Belsen concentration camp where he was looking for a female friend of his brother. In the camp, he met his future wife, they married in Italy and therefore she could legally immigrate to Palestine. Naftali Jaul's work and family: His mother and one of his sisters were not able to depart from Vienna. They went missing since 1942. N.J. tells the life stories of his wife's family members. She lost her parents, brother and sister in the holocaust. In 1946, N.J. returned to Palestine with his military unit. His wife was later brought to Palestine by the British army. He describes his new life in Palestine and his living conditions. Their first daughter was born in 1947, their son in 1950. After his return, Jaul Naftali looked for an employment. Until 1980, he worked as employee in a governmental customs office. He analyzes the beginning of the warlike unrests from 1946 to 1948.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-15 באוקטובר 2019, המתעדים את חג הסהרנה, הנחוג בקרב יוצאי כורדיסטאן בגן סאקר בירושלים. הסהרנה היא חג טבע, הדומה למימונה של יהודי מרוקו, שיהודי כורדיסטן היו חוגגים בפסח. בישראל, כדי לא להתחרות במימונה, העבירו יוצאי כורדיסטן את החג לסוכות. ביום הראשון של חול המועד סוכות התקיימה הסהרנה בירושלים. נעשו הכנות רבות להשתתפות קהל רב, אבל כנראה בגלל מזג האוויר היו רק משתתפים מעטים. אחרי הצהריים היו במקום רק כמה משפחות שערכו פיקניק על הדשא וכמה צעירים שהתאמנו בצעדי ריקוד כורדי. לפנות ערב נערכה תהלוכה של הכנסת ספרי תורה. השתתפו בה כחמישים איש, לא כולם יוצאי כורדיסטן. רק אישה אחת באה בשמלה כורדית אמיתית. את התהלוכה הובילו שני נגני זוּרְנָה (מין אבוב) ושני מתופפים והוליכו בה שני ספרי תורה. כמה נשים הצמידו מטפחות-ראש לספרי התורה ורבים רקדו לקול המוסיקה. כשהגיעו לאוהל בית הכנסת גברו הריקודים ורבים הסתדרו בשורה ארוכה לריקוד של מין דבקה כורדית. לסיום הניחו את ספרי התורה על שולחן, רב נשא תפילה, הגברים התפללו מנחה ובזה הסתיים החלק הראשון של הטקס. בערב נערכו הופעות מעל במה שהוקמה במקום.
בתי היהודים.
הכפר חצביה לרגלי החרמון.

Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Yemen, 1934. History of family from departing Yemen to arrival in Eretz Israel. Absorption in Ein Shemer immigrant camp. Settlement in Givat Yearim. Crisis in education. Possessions stolen from Yemenites. Missing Yemenite children. Activities of political parties among newcomers.

records.title: Jewish Life in Arab Countries; Jewish Life in Middle Eastern Countries.

descriptions.value: אברהם בן אליהו מוכתאר, יליד 1929, חילה שבעיראק. נולד למשפחה של ילידי המקום מדורי דורות, לאב ששימש מוכתאר הקהילה למעלה מ- 20 שנים. הפעילות הציונית החלה באוגוסט 1943, עת שהה בבצרה ונחשף לתנועה הציונית. עם שובו לחילה, התארגנה קבוצת הציונים הראשונה, שהתפתחה והגיע לכדי 60 צעירים, לה העביר את הידע שרכש. הקשר עם ציוני בגדאד נקשר באמצעות יוסף הרוקח, המשיך להתבצע ישירות והסתכם באספקת חומרים כתובים. ב- 1944 השתתף לראשונה בסמינר ציונות בבגדאד, שלידיעתו היה היחיד שנערך. אנשי הקהילה היהודית בחילה היו מודעים לפעילות, שכן זו התקיימה בבתים ובלי הסתרת החומר הכתוב. אנשי התנועה בבגדאד לא התעניינו בפעילות בחילה ולהפך. הפעילות נערכה בלי מוסדות ארגוניים, לא נגבו כספים ולא נעשו פעולות לעידוד העלייה לישראל של הקהילה כולה או אף של משפחות, אלא של הצעירים בלבד. בשנים 1945 - 1946, הוקמה מסגרת הגנה, פעילי חילה נסעו לבגדאד והתאמנו בהכנת בקבוקי מולוטוב, נרכשו 6 אקדחים שחולקו בין החברים, אם כי לא הייתה התארגנות מסודרת מעבר לאמור. המוכתאר היה מעורב בכל פעולה מול הרשויות, לרבות העלייה.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Saqqez, Iran, 1922. Activities among newcomers, including representation in dealings with American Joint Jewish Distribution Committee (JDC) and Jewish Agency. Public activity in Iran, including Azarbaijan, before State of Israel established. Motives for aliyah. Conditions in Teheran transit camps. Activities of different public institutions on behalf of Persian Jews.

records.title: Youth Movements and Zionist Activity in Egypt.

descriptions.value: Discusses: Jewish upbringing; first encounters with Zionist movement; education; family; involvement in 'Hashomer Hatzair' in Cairo; members; figures in Zionist organization before WWII; Tzadikov; Jewish youth joining Communist activity (1937-38); conflict with Communists; WWII in Egypt; encounters with soldiers and emissaries from Israel; formation of Hashomer Hatzair, 1938-1942; location of chapter in Heliopolis and development of other chapters; people involved, 1943-44; own departure with first Aliyah group, December 1944; people in his Aliyah group; ties between Hashomer Hatzair and emissaries from Mapai's 'Kibbutz Hameuhad'; letter sent to Haim Weizmann insisting that Arab problem had to be fixed for Zionism to succeed; reasons for failure of 'Hehalutz Haachid' in Egypt; becoming distanced from Zionist Organization as representative of 'Hashomer Hatzair'; funding for Hashomer Hatzair in Egypt; number of members and chapters; their location in Alexandria, Cairo and Heliopolis; 'hachshara' at 'Havat Asher' near pyramids; Lord Moyne's assassination; legitimacy of other youth movements in Egypt; criticism of policy for sending emissaries to Egypt before establishment of State, in contrast to policy for Europe; own Aliyah via Lebanon, 1945.

records.title: Jewish Resistance in Slovakia during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born Galnitza, Czechoslovakia, 1919. Served in Czech army. Inmate in Zelina and Sered concentration camps. Discusses: Jews who worked in Zelina; working as watchmaker in camp; life in Sered; work; informants; friends; sources of income; Poles; sport and cultural activities; establishment of commune; internal police network; attempts at organizing rebellion; involvement in uprising; Slovakian secret police; smuggling objects; sources of information in camp; escape; fate of people he knew.

records.title: Kezmarok (Czechoslovakia) and Surrounding Villages during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born 1918. Discusses: family; father's livelihood before and after WWI; economic situation; lifestyle; households in Kezmarok and various sources of income; his activity in 1930's; Zionist organizations in Kezmarok; Zionist youth movements; his desire to move to Palestine and find a career; serving in army as 'Jewish worker' as of 1942; work he did; vacations; situation in 1943; issue of obtaining 'travelling order'; period he spent in Kralovany; sources of income; work in Banska Bela, 1944; capture of him and his family and other Jews by Gestapo; concentration of Jews by Gestapo in Kezmarok; fate of his friends and family; life in camp and prison under supervision of S.S.; train to Auschwitz; life in Auschwitz; how he survived; life in Ravensbruk and Sachsenhausen; 'walk of death' and how he was saved; return to Kezmarok; meeting sister Reshka, family members and other acquaintances; beginning of new life following war, under Russia rule; anti-Jewish influence in Kezmarok; joy following establishment of State of Israel; how his sister survived; Aliyah to Israel; his life in Israel. (This interview includes a testimony of cruelty of Germans called 'Folksdeutshen' in Czechoslovakia, based on Czech witnesses).

records.title: Bricha (Organized Escape) and the Camps in Germany 1944-1948; Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944.

descriptions.value: Born in Wadowice, Poland, 1920, to a Chassidic family. History of Jewish settlment in Wadowice before WWII. Foundation of Zionist youth groups (socialist and traditional - Hashomer Hatzair and Mizrahi). Government's attitude towards Jews. Conflicts within community over questions of status, economy and general way of life. Increased Antisemitism and worsening of Jew's economic situation in the 1930s. Bund organization and attempts to flee from Poland. Rise of Hitler's regime in Germany and effects on Polish Jews. Autobiographical details: life in Wadowice till 1935; accountancy studies in a Jewish gymnasium 1936-39; attempts to escape Poland during German invasion; capture; wandering through different forced labor and concentration camps in Silesia and Poland; liberation by Soviet army, 1945; returning to normal life. Annihilation of immediate family as well as of 90% of other Wadowice Jews. Marriage and aliyah to Israel with wife. Occasional meetings of Israeli Wadowice survivors.

Born Tiberias. Studied at Beirut University. Discusses: Jewish community in Tiberias; life in Tiberias under British Mandate; enlisting in Palestinian unit in British Army; decision to study at Beirut University; working in British Government Agency, Sudan, for three years; learning that a university would be established in Jerusalem; being invited to opening; details of the ceremony; dressing, people there, atmosphere, languages spoken, duration, getting there, leaving; marrying; living and working in Jerusalem; working with Arabs; positive relations with Arab co-workers.

records.title: History of the Jewish National Fund (Keren Kayemet le-Israel).

descriptions.value: Discusses: own Aliyah, 1949; integration; working in agriculture for Keren Kayemet, near Beit Zayit; teaching forestry to new immigrants; education and knowledge received from working in afforestation for 40 years; problems with afforestation; deciding on plots for forests; overview of agricultural projects for Beit Zayit residents, 1950's; income in Keren Kayemet; pruning problem and mechanical solution found; nurseries and seeds; variations in forest; crowding of saplings; outcome of forest; money Keren Kayemet made from selling trees; use of trees for plots; makeup of trees; disinfecting; cooperation with other Mediterranean countries, especially regarding forest fires; different types of plants grown in nurseries; use of seeds gathered; nurseries' specialization in species appropriate to different locations; how to minimize damage from forest fires; dealing with difficulty of putting out fires; cooperation with various sources; contribution of Keren Kayemet to Israeli outdoors by planting forests and creating parks. Emphasizes the need to document the role of Keren Kayemet personnel in afforestation in Israel.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Sousse, Tunisia in 1924, to rabbinic family. Jewish education. Member of Tzeirei Tzion (later Dror Tzeirei Tzion) attached to Hakibbutz Hameuhad, from 1945. Pro-immigration activities in movement. Nazi occupation strengthening Zionist proclivities. Short term hard labor. Antisemitism in Tunisia preceding and during French occupation. Participation in first Hagana course in North Africa, 1947. No selective immigration until 1948. Assistance to first transport of Tunisian Jews leaving as summer campers via Algeria and Marseilles, 1947. Immigrants from three North African countries converged in Algeria. Use of counterfeit papers. Continuing his activities until 1948. Hakhshara (training) in France. Aliya, 1950; wife, 1948. Relocation from Beit Oren to Regavim, then to Kiryat Gat, 1957. Work for the Jewish Agency until retirement at sixty.

Jews of the Areas Annexed to the USSR in World War II.

descriptions.value: Born Reni, Bessarabia, 1903. Discusses: memories from Russian occupation, June 1940; relations between Russian Jews and Gentiles; family's livelihood; life under Communists; language spoken amongst Jews; atmosphere in village; business; evacuation out of fear of Germans; information on those exiled to Siberia; members of village who took part in war. Was Yiddish and Hebrew teacher, 1920's and 1930's. Discusses: family; memories from Russian occupation of Stefanesti, Romania; being drafted to Romanian army; how they were received as soldiers returning to Czernowitz; place of Jews amongst soldiers; changes that came to Jewish cultural life with Communism; Jewish schools and organizations; his work in Jewish school; textbooks; cultural institutions in Czernowitz; situation in Bessarabia and Bukovina; working as teacher; students' motivation to work; Jewish life; expulsion and evacuations from Britchan; situation for communist Jews during first part of Soviet regime; absence of Jewish newspaper in Chernovitz; Jewish authors; Yiddish theatre performing in Czernowitz; journals written about events in Czernowitz, 1940; activity of Jewish schools; government supervision of Jewish activity; half-German Jews in Czernowitz, 1940 and their place in local Jewish community.

Few days later, after several incidents on the Lebanese border, the IDF began a large scale operation into Lebanon. Photo shows: IDF entering a Lebanese town of Einata.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-13 בספטמבר 2013, המתעדים את אירועי חג הצלב הנחוג במעיליא. למחרת הצעדה של חג הצלב, ביום ראשון, נערך בכנסייה טקס קידוש הצלב ולאחר מכן טקס הקומוניון - בו המאמינים קיבלו את לחם הקודש.

Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Samokov, Bulgaria, 1916. Childhood in Sofiya. Studies at local Jewish school. First aliya in family, 1939. Living in Haifa during socialist administration of Mayor Abba Hushi. Broadcasting in Bulgarian from Jerusalem for secret branch of psychological warfare in British Army during WWII. Unofficial consul of institutions dealing with absorption of Bulgarian Jews, 1948-1949. Assisting Bulgarian community in Jerusalem. Involvement in settling of first Bulgarian families in Neve Shaanan neighborhood then uninhabited. Sent by Mapam leader Meir Yaari to work for Mapam in social-political absorption of Bulgarian newcomers in Jaffa. Founder of Bulgarian Al Hamishmar newspaper. Helping medical students that immigrated just before their graduation, later first students of Faculty of Medicine of Hebrew University. Cultural life of Bulgarian community: music, theatre, sports and sciences.

records.title: Jews in the Czechoslovak Armies in World War II.

descriptions.value: UNED Alexander Weiss town in Czechoslovakia conquered by Hungarians. Sent to work camp. Anti-Jewish laws. High mortality rate. Escape to Soviet partisans. Was put on trial during Slansky trials. Aliya 1968.

records.title: Jews in the Yugoslav Partisan Movement during World War II.

descriptions.value: (Session 1) Born Belgrade, 1920. Member of 'Hashomer Hatzair' as of 1931. Sent to organize branch of movement in Macedonia. Discusses: beginning of persecution of Jews; contact with Partisans; ties with Communists; betrayal of Jews by other Partisans; forging documents; refusal by many to use forged documents; own flight to Greece and then Albania. (Session 2) Discusses: flight to, and life in, Albania; capture by police and two-month incarceration; contact with other Jewish Yugoslavian refugees upon release from prison; joining Albanian Partisans; kind treatment by Albanians; return to Yugoslavia, 1945; involvement in Aliyah Bet; flow of refugees into Yugoslavia; own Aliyah, 1949 and difficulties adapting.

records.title: Ha'apala (Illegal Immigration) from Italy, 1945-1948 [including material from the Haganah Archive].

descriptions.value: The Hagana; the Palmach; recruiting for the British Army; activities in Italy; "illegal" immigration from Italy. Born 1921 in Jerusalem. Family moved to Kfar Giladi then to Sheik Abreik. Conditions at Sheik Abreik compelled him and brothers to join Hagana. Murder of father. Joined British army, 1943. Sent to Italy where he met with Holocaust survivors. Served in transport unit. Description of problems in unit. Activities of Eliyahu Cohen to improve situation and encourage Zionist activity. Founding of Hamercaz Lagolah. Surrender of Germany. Unit drafted to transport German prisoners of war. Debates regarding issue of revenge on prisoners. Illegal activities in supportin Aliya Bet. Transport unit disbanded. Organizing of hakhsharot in camps. Ties with Italians to purchase ships. Surveillance by British army. Among activists arrested by British when they confiscated wireless station. Story of La Specia ship. Hunger strike on ship. Local and international press coverage. Freeing of ship via aliya certificates arranged by Harold Laski.

records.title: Kezmarok (Czechoslovakia) and Surrounding Villages during World War II.

descriptions.value: Born Kezmarok, Slovakia, 1929. Discusses: childhood; parents; employment, 1942; fate of family; her life during German occupation of Hungary, 1943-1944; Jewish community of Kezmarok during Slovak uprising; living hidden in bunker for 4 months; first news of murder of Jews; return of friends and family following war; influence Nuremberg laws had on her studies, family and life.

Childhood in Neunkirchen and Wiener Neustadt. Flight to Czechoslovakia. Immigration to Palestine under Betar auspices. Service in British army. Prisoner of war in Germany. Work as clerk of Tel-Aviv municipality.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-28 בספטמבר 2017, המתעדים את טקס ה'תשליך' שעורכים חסידי קרעטשניף מרחובות, בחוף הים של קיבוץ פלמחים.

בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-14 ביוני 2020 המתעדים את המיסה שעורכים הכרמליטים במערת אליהו. את המיסה ערכו נזירים כרמליטים ממנזר סטלה מאריס שעל הכרמל במערת אליהו, שיש בה ארון קודש והיא מתפקדת כבית כנסת. היו שם ארבעה נזירים, נזירה אחת וכחצי תריסר נוצרים מחיפה. אבל מיסה קתולית בבית כנסת יהודי(!) עד 1948 מערת אליהו הייתה מאוכלסת בסופים-מוסלמים שהתירו ליהודים, נוצרים ודרוזים, שהמקום קדוש גם להם, להתפלל בה. כיום, המערה שייכת ליהודים בלבד, אף שבשלט שמעל לכניסה למערה הפנימית כתוב: "כִּי בֵיתִי בֵּית תְּפִלָּה יִקָּרֵא לְכָל הָעַמִּים" (ישעיהו נ"ו, 7).הודות לתקנת סטאטוס-קוו מותר לכרמליטים לערוך בה מיסה פעם בשנה, ב-14 ליוני. אף אחד לא הפריע לטקס, שנמשך כשעה. דוגמה לסובלנות. לדנצ'ו ארנון רק בעיה אחת: האם לחבוש כיפה כיהודי בבית כנסת או להיות גלוי-ראש כדרך הנוצרים.

records.title: חג המולד בפסוטה 26/12/2015 (חגי חורף) חג המולד בפסוטה.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון בתאריך 26 לדצמבר 2015, במהלך אירועי חג המולד בפסוטה ומעיליא, שני כפרים מלכיטים (יוונים-קתולים) בגליל. לפסוטה יש מסורת של חגיגות עממיות לכבוד חג המולד, שלושה ימים של שמחה עם בזאר של חג, מופעים, תהלוכות, אמני רחוב, אוכל ושתיה. בני כל הדתות מוזמנים לחגוג עם בני פסוטה. את הבאים לחגיגות מקבלים צעירי הכפר בסוכריות ובריקודים. עץ חג המולד הענק ניצב בחצר הכנסייה, עם מאות נורות צבעוניות ותאורה מתחלפת. גם בתי הכפר וסמטאותיו מקושטים בתאורה צבעונית לכבוד החג. מתקיימת תהלוכה של להקת דבקה דרוזית.בכנסייה המקושטת שוכב בסלסילה "ישוע התינוק" (רפליקה של הבּוּבּה שמככבת בטקס הקתולי של חג המולד בבית לחם. על פי המנהג העממי-כפרי נבטים מסמלים את הלידה וההתחדשות. ליד ה"אבוס" (Manger) מתקיים שחזור מערת הלידה.

records.title: Jews in the Czechoslovak Armies in World War II.

descriptions.value: UNED His family. Political developments after 1939. Rise in antisemitism. Anti-Jewish laws. Work camps in Hungary and Russia. Soviet prisoner of war camps. News of a Czechoslovakian unit. Joined unit after ideological tests. End of war in Slovakia. Rise of antisemitism. Jewish Brigade organized in 1948 in Czechoslovakia. Aliyah 1949.

records.title: Jewish Life in Arab Countries; Jewish Life in Middle Eastern Countries.

descriptions.value: מזרחי עלתה לישראל מבגדאד לחיפה בסוף 1937, עם בעלה ו-4 ילדיה בעזרת סרטיפיקט שהשיגה משפחת בעלה בישראל. 4 ילדים נוספים שילדה נפטרו בעיראק. מזרחי אינה יודעת באיזה תאריך נולדה. הייתה בת יחידה לאב עשיר שייצר צבעים, צבעי בדים והיה בעל כרמים בהם העסיק פועלים מוסלמים. הוא נפטר בילדותה, והיא גדלה במשפחת אחי האב בדהוק ונישאה לבנו. כשהאב היה בחיים, מימן את פעילותו של בית מדרש שבו למדה יחד עם כ- 50 בנים והייתה הבת היחידה שם. בית המדרש נסגר עם מותו. אמה עסקה בטוויה ובאריגה. הנישואין סוכמו בין הורי הצדדים והיה מקובל לשלם לכלה המיועדת 1000 לירות. בדהוק הנשים לא כיסו את פניהן בהיותן מחוץ לבית, לא כך בבגדאד, וכן היו קשרים טובים וביקורי שכנים הדדיים בין יהודים למוסלמים.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Bessarabia, Russia in 1915. Secretary of Histadrut in Kiryat Ata. Served in British Army, 1940. Active in Jewish Brigade committee at Diaspora Center as organizer of Beriha and hapala. Work at absorption department of Jewish Agency, 1946. Work with immigrants in Athlit and Kiryat Shmuel transitional camps. Dispersal of immigrants from detention camps in Cyprus and Israel to adopting families, 1947-1949. Manager of Haifa Amidar for 25 years. Development and maintenance of different settlements. Initial absorption procedures for newcomers.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Alit Yanishevsky grew up in kibbutz Daliya, she worked in the kibbutz during high school. After her military service she studied public finance. At the age of 24 she moved to kibbutz Idmit, married and adopted a son. Two years before her husband's early death, she returned to Daliya. She worked as secretary at the university of Haifa, and later worked in the administration. After a management studies she became the manager of the new built guest houses in kibbutz Daliya. At present she studies tourism, arranges exhibitions of her photographs and writes a novel.#AY grew up without grandparents. Her parents never spoke about their families, but AY's mother wrote a book about her past in Germany. Her maternal grandfather died early, her maternal grandmother was killed in the Holocaust like many relatives on her father's side. AY has visited their graves in Berlin. AY's mother never had a close relationship to her brother, a philosopher, who also came to Israel, but later remigrated to Germany. Her mother grew up in a 'cool' home. Her paternal grandparents were warmer, her father told her, but they died before the war.#AY grew up in the children's house of kibbutz Daliya, she only saw her parents two or three hours a day. Her brother had a heart disease and was often at home with their mother. AY did not like to be with them because she did not understand what happened with her brother. At the kibbutz she worked with animals. By that time there were mainly Yekkes and Romanians in Daliya, AY describes their cultural differences. When she was 7 years old, she became interested in music and took piano lessons. She also attended a conservatory. Music is still very important to her. AY's parents bought a lot of classic German literature in Israel, however they never spoke German in the kibbutz or with their children. AY and her brother knew better Hebrew than their parents. AY tells about the famous dance festivals in kibbutz Daliya. There were many Arab settlements near Daliya, AY had friends in one village.#AY was in a youth association. During her military service, she sued a general for sexual harassment. Apart from that she enjoyed her military service very much. Because she wanted to study but kibbutz Daliya wouldn't allow her, she left her kibbutz and joined the new founded kibbutz Idmit. She met her husband there, who had a Polish family background. After 4 years they left Idmit and lived for some years in a moshav. After that AY returned with her husband and their adopted son to Daliya. Her husband died from cancer, they were married for 12 years. AY's father now decided to pay for her studies (from the reparation money he got from Germany), later he did the same for her son. She went to Haifa university in 1979, worked there as a secretary and studied administration. Later she did several other studies, for example management. She met interesting people at the university, for example the author Nathan Zach, who at present encourages her to publish her first novel.#AY's mother, whose German name was Lotte Adam, already had a lyric poetry prize in Berlin and a doctorate in journalism when she came to kibbutz Daliya. As a convinced Zionist she since then mainly worked in the factory of the kibbutz. But she also worked hard to improve her Hebrew and to write in Hebrew. She might have been the only author who was a member of the Hebrew Writers' Association as well as of the German Writers' Association in Israel. AY did not like the fact she wrote about her and her brother. After her mother's death AY misses the philosophical conversations with her mother. AY had a rather distant relationship to her mother, who did not speak a lot. AY was afraid she could never show feelings in her marriage. She did not know how to behave, she does not remember when she was ever hugged or kissed by her mother. Her father could show more warmth. Both parents behaved like typical Yekkes, her mother always wanted her to be perfect. When AY began to write books she did not get positive reactions from her mother. AY describes her son's relationship with her parents, it was warmer. She compares her parents to those of her husband. Her relationship with her brother was very distant as well, she thinks this was also her mother's “fault”.#Her mother's brother, a philosopher, who lived in kibbutz Givat Brenner, returned to Germany after 1967. He did not feel comfortable in the kibbutz and in Israel. For a long time AY was very angry about that. A cousin of her mother returned to Germany too. AY later often stayed with her uncle and his wife in Bad Reichenhall, where they lived. At first she did not want to go there, but she soon felt comfortable. AY has friends among a group of students who visited Daliya. She went to Berlin again in 1996. She has never been to Germany with her parents, but she saw where they lived.

records.title: Rescue of Jewish Children in Hungary from 1944 until Liberation.

descriptions.value: Born Budapest, 1932. During Nazi occupation (as of 1944) lived with three brothers in International Red Cross residence for mute and deaf children. Parents were in labour camp. Discusses: cramped conditions in residence with 100 children and dozens of adult refugees who fled from labour camp; difficulty in organizing kids into activities because of hunger and cold; arrival of Hungarian Nazis - moving everyone to Ghetto, shooting adults; horrible conditions; mother's decision to bring him and his family to safe house for adults under Swiss protection.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Burgas, Bulgaria in 1928. Orphaned and adopted when very young. Growing up in Sliven, small town with three hundred Jews. Studies at Jewish school and general high school. Studies at medical faculty of Sofia University. Motives for aliya. Strong influence of David Ben Gurion on immigration of Bulgarian Jews. Arrival aboard immigrant ship; immediately drafted into Israeli Army. Relocation from Beit Lid camp to Sarafand and becoming part of IDF's primary medical aid force. Work in psychiatric unit attending soldiers suffering from shell shock and in Jaffa military clinic. Helping parents who came to Israel in 1949. Living with parents in one room apartment of deserted property in Jaffa. Studies in first years of medical faculty at Hebrew University; financed by army. Army and university as most significant institutions in his absorption.

records.title: The Zionist Movement in Romania during World War II.

descriptions.value: המרואיין ממנהיגי "גורדוניה" ברומניה. בין השנים 1940 - 1947, היה מזכ"ל התנועה, ראש קן בוקרשט ונציג התנועה בהסתדרות הציונית. המרואיין עסק גם בארגון סניפי התנועה בבוקרשט, בגאלאץ, ביאסי ובטימישוארה. עד 1944, היה מראשי המחתרת הציונית. ב- 1944, ע"פי המפקד האחרון, "גורדוניה" הייתה התנועה היהודית הגדולה ביותר ברומניה. מקור התנועה, בסיסה והנהגתה - בלץ שבבסרביה. מאפייני התנועה ברומניה: תנועה עממית של הנוער העובד ברחוב היהודי, התחושה ש"גורדוניה" נועדה לעבות את הקיבוצים בישראל. תחילת התארגנות המחתרת היהודית בראשית שנות ה-40', לפני הכיבוש הסובייטי, עם ארגון הברחת הילדים היהודים, כשבניגוד לדעת ההורים, הנהגת התנועה צפתה את האסון המתקרב. הפעילות המחתרתית גברה בימי "הלגיונרים". הקשר עם הסניפים ועם טרנסניסטריה התקיים באמצעות נסיעות בתיעוד מזויף ובהתכתבות בצופן. המרואיין ביצע את מלאכת זיוף התיעוד. הנהגת התנועה לא האמינה בכוחם של הפעילים מטעם ההסתדרות הציונית, שדגלו בארגון הצלת יהודי רומניה באמצעים פוליטיים בלבד, והללו מצידם סברו שהתנועה תביא אסון על יהדות רומניה. התנועה הבריחה פליטים מצ'רנוביץ לבוקרשט, ובעקבות כך נאסרו חבריה, והחל משפט שהופסק באמצעות שוחד ולחץ מישראל.#מפות ששרטט המרואיין על בסיס עדויות של פליטים יהודים מפולין שימשו את בנות הברית בהפצצותיהן. לאחר השחרור ב- 23.8, יצאו חברי התנועה לחדש את פעילות הסניפים, וזאת במצוות "השליחים" שהורו להעדיף פעילות זו על פני עלייה לישראל.

records.title: Role of American Jewish Chaplains in Rescuing Holocaust Survivors in Europe, 1944-1948.

descriptions.value: Worked with JDC as of May 1945 - first in Paris, then Germany. Served in 6th Army Group, under US Army. Discusses: involvement in French Army; work with DP's in Germany; Jewish US chaplains encountered in Germany; Rabbi Abe Klausner; Feldafing- first all Jewish DP camp, Bavaria; contact with UNRRA; challenges arising from Army's perception of DP's and prioritization; Army's negative feelings towards Jewish DP's; relationship between JDC and Abe Klausner; separation between Jewish and other DP's; Central Committee; Farenhenwald; Eisenhower's visit to Feldafing; package program; continued work with JDC in New York; 'Bricha'.

Born in St. Polten. Childhood in Graz. Studying graphics in Berlin. Immigration to Palestine in 1934. Work as a graphic artist.

Born 1920 Bialystock, Poland. Upon father's death went to live with aunt after mother remarried and moved to Israel. Discusses: Jewish education; Aliyah at age 18; studies at Mikve Yisrael; working for British Police; involvement with Lehi; leaving British Police and Lehi; marriage; livelihood; serving in tanks in IDF; fighting in War of Independence; different roles in Israeli Police; living in Yad Eliahu neighbourhood of Tel Aviv; moving with family to Jerusalem.

PM Rabin and PLO Chairman Arafat agreed on November 8, 1994 to speed up the process of Palestinian autonomy as outlined by the Declaration of Principles and the cairo Agreement. Meeting at the Erez Checkpoint at the entrance to the gaza Strip, the two leaders - in their 9th public meeting - took several steps: to hand over the administrative powers in territories outside gaza and Jericho in the fields of health and taxation; to allow more Palestinian workers to enter Israel; to allow a freer flow of Palestian goods. Education will be transferred to palestian control in September 1994. Outside the meeting, palestinain women demonstrated for the return of their sons and husbands from Israeli prisons.". Photo shows: Palestinain women demonstrating outside the Arafat-Rabin meeting - demanding release of the of their sons and husbands from Israeli prison.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון ב-13 בספטמבר 2013, המתעדים את אירועי חג הצלב הנחוג במעיליא. בעולם הנוצרי חג (רוממות) הצלב הוא לרוב חג מינורי. הכומר של מעיליא, כפר נוצרי יפהפה בגליל המערבי, החליט להפוך את החג הזה לחגו של הכפר, ומאז מתקיימת בו תהלוכה נהדרת, בה לוקחים חלק רוב התושבים. בתחילת מסלול התהלוכה התאספו הנערים והנערות שעברו השנה את האישוש (קונפורמציה) לבושים בגלימות לבנות ובידם צלב מקושט בפרחים. הנער באדום - מהמשרתים בקודש. עם שקיעה התארגנה תהלוכה נלהבת. בראש תזמורת הצופים, אחריה צופים נושאי לפידים, הנערים והנערות בלבן, נושאי לפידים ואחריהם כל תושבי הכפר, ביניהם כמה גברתנים שנשאו צלב עץ ענקי. לאחר צעדה ארוכה נאספו כולם בכיכר הכנסייה העתיקה, ליד המבצר הצלבני.

records.title: אנשי קבוצת כנרת במדי הבריגדה העברית.

records.title: תל אביב יפו: שכונת שבזי, בית ספר הרוס.

descriptions.value: דיוקן גר צדק מהולנד, קורא בספר תנ"ך בחצר המשק החקלאי שהקים בשכונת נחלת יצחק, בפאתי תל אביב: הדפס כסף, שחור לבן. על פי החותמות המוטבעות בגב התצלום, הוא הופק בידי זולטן קלוגר ("חברה מזרחית לצילומים בשביל העתונות") כנראה בהזמנת אחד המוסדות הלאומיים, בסוף ספטמבר 1934.

A two-arched bridge over a riverbed. A large building is visible behind the bridge. A mountain is at the right side.

descriptions.value: Men (one with a rifle) and sheep are on the top of a hill overlooking Wady Arnon and the surrounding mountains.

records.title: General view of the Forum--Where St. Paul was imprisoned

descriptions.value: Ruins are in the foreground. In the background, there are a variety of stone and marble buildings (including the Temple of Antoninus and Faustina and Santa Francesca Romana's belltower).
The interior of a mosque showing a man seated on a rug and a small domed structure. The mausoleum of Khalid ibn al-Walid.
Part of the Jerusalem city wall is at the right. The view is of the Tyropean Valley.

records.title: History of the Jewish National Fund (Keren Kayemet le-Israel).

descriptions.value: Developed interest in forestry and forestization, 1943-46. Received PhD, 1949. Aliyah, 1949. Worked in research. Discusses: forestization in Israel; collaboration with Prof. De Filipis; field workers and their professionalism; administrative work; Amiud Gur's promotion under British; relations with Ministry of Agriculture following creation of State of Israel; publishing reports; his work in Israel; relations with researchers abroad; Israel's work in forestry as compared to other locations in Mediterranean; stories about eucalyptus and poplar trees; industrial use of trees in Israel; number of saplings for planting; planting on sides of streets.

records.title: The Zionist Underground in Soviet-Occupied Poland, 1939-1941.

descriptions.value: הימים הראשונים של המלחמה והמסע של חברי ההכשרה מזרחה, הרחק מהחזית עם הגרמנים. ההגעה לרובנה, התארגנות של חברי מרכז החלוץ ושיתוף הפעולה עם חברי מרכז השומר הצעיר במציאת הדרך לחצות את הגבול בדרום. מתאר הניסיונות שבוצעו ואת פעילות מנהיגי התנועות השונות. התחלת הניסיונות לחצות את הגבול בצפון כשהיעד היה וילנה שבליטא. המרואיין מתאר את תפקידו כפעיל בכיר ושותף לארגון ההברחות הללו. תפיסתו במהלך ניסיון חציית הגבול, מעצרו על ידי סובייטים והוצאתו בשל בך ממסגרת התנועה על לסיומה של המלחמה.

records.title: Autobiographical interviews of Jews born in German speaking countries ("Yekkes") - 50/60 years after their immigration to Israel.

descriptions.value: Jehoshua: Jehoshua ben Abraham Bruenn. Ben - Rabbi - Jehuda - Nachmann. Born 01/19/1913 in Allenstein / East Prussia. Education: Senior high school and vocational school in Allenstein. Commercial apprenticeship (3 years). Emigration: May 1933 to France, January 1934 from Marseilles to Palestine on a ship. Career: Commercial employee in Berlin (2 years), Work for Ha-Chaluz in Berlin/ Paris. Hachshara in Southern France. Kibbutzworker from 1934. British Army from 1939 (6 years), various jobs, police service (librarian) until 1974; retirement; helped to build up the library of Jerusalem. Member of the IPA (International Police Association), various visits to Europe and USA. Charlotte: Born 09/22/1923 in Homburg. Education: primary school in Homburg until 1935, school in France, was a dressmaker's apprentice. Emigration: 1935 to France, from 1939 flight and underground, in France until 1949 then Palestine. Career: worked as seamstress and maid in France, Hachshara, pharmaceutical assistant, medical assistant to a neurologist, after her wedding she became a housewife and day-care-mother. Interview Jehoshua: Attitude toward Judaism in his parental home: very religious. He was raised by his grandfather. Zionist upbringing. Learned Hebrew as a child. There were only 2 Jews in his class. Classroom memories. Allenstein: 280-300 Jewish families. His friends were Jewish and Christian. He was a member of Blau- Weiss. He wanted to join the Reichswehr (army) after school, his mother#wanted him to go into business. Why he wanted to join the German army. Berlin and his job in a warehouse. His friends. 04/01/1933: Boycott Day, SS men were looking for him. Ha-Chaluz. Paris. Southern France: Hachshara, agricultural work. Neglecting Jewish customs, no religious life in Southern France. Episode in Southern France. Talks with Liechtenstein to get the certificate. Marseilles: he gets his visa and goes on board the ship to Palestine. On board there was king Faruk's sister. A blind passenger. Reception in Haifa (brother). Knowledge of Hebrew: learned it at Ha-Chaluz in Berlin. An experience with the Gestapo. Hebrew was every day language, but he also spoke Yiddish. Work in the Hagana. Malaria tropica, Malaria tertiana, various diseases. In 1937 he wanted to meet his mother at the Zionist Congress. About his mother's wish to remain in Germany. Zionist Congress. Kibbutz En Harod. His mother's arrival to Jerusalem and her death. Arrival of brother from Basra. J. volunteered for the British Army. About his times in the army. Invasion into Egypt. Brother's military career War and how he was injured. Baghdad. Memories of the war. Return to Israel after the war. Professional career: various blue collar jobs, (carpenter). His wife traveled to France to pick up her belonging. J. was unemployed. Further jobs. J applied for a job with the police and was accepted. Work as a librarian for the police. Language: Hebrew. Stayed in this job until 1974. 1973 Yom-Kippur-War he#had to join the patrol. Heart attack and retirement. Part time work in the library of Jerusalem. Reading: Hebrew. Language with his wife: German; with children: German but children answer in Hebrew. About his poetry. Many friends in the International Police Association. Trips to Germany. He is making a family tree back to 1620. His grandmother was related to Albert Einstein. Family history. J. feel very close to the German language and remained Prussian inside. Contacts: owns a letter from Kennedy who visited his daughter in Florida. Political interest. United States of Europe. About the Gulf War. About the IPA. About a TV report about Neonazis in Dresden. About friends in Germany. About being proud to be a Jekke. Interview Charlotte: born in Homburg, very religious parental home. Attended a Jewish school which was dissolved in 1934. About Homburg. Emigration to Southern France in 1935. They could take everything with them. A Jewish community developed in France. Father did not find work and bought a farm in the mountains. The family lived in the city. Older sister went to school in England. About learning French. German was only spoken inside of the house. Hatred between Germans and French people. Outbreak of war: her youngest brother volunteered for the French army. Various hiding places. Professional activities: sewing course, apprentice to a dressmaker. Her father had a feeling that something would happen, they left immediately and were picked up by the police and#almost sent to Germany. The family was hidden by farmers. Her brother helped. Her sister organized a job in Marseilles, she was a maid. Her brother helped their parents to escape to the mountains and organized faked passports. She got a new name: Charlotte Hiller and was taken to a convent. The nuns knew she was Jewish, but they hid her as an orphan and told her to behave as if she was Catholic. Small chores for the nuns. Denunciation through a baptized Jewish woman. No contact with parents, only with sister and cousin. Work at a farm. Position as assistant to a pharmacist in Toulouse. She wanted to get to her parents and got permission to go. They lost their house and their belongings. Language situation: French fluently, almost no German. Relationship to French. Decision to emigrate, joined French youth movement. She wanted to convince her parents to leave for Palestine, they didn't want to. Marseilles, departure for Palestine. Ramat Gan, Haifa, Tel Aviv. Found work with a neurologist. Hebrew. Friends. Meeting her husband. Engagement. Worked as a day-care-mother. Relationship to Germany and France: she only feels related to the language but not to the people. About religion and her attitude toward Judaism. Very religious mother, died in Avignon. Fate of siblings. Visit to her parents.

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Yael Ben-Mordechay spent her childhood and school years in Jerusalem. She met her husband, a kibbutznik from Ramat David, during her military service. After the marriage they first lived in his kibbutz, but then moved to Kiryat Bialik. Later they moved to Amirim, a village of vegetarians. YBM worked for a nature conservation organization for more than 20 years. Since 14 years she works as a travel guide with tourists in Israel and also with Israelis abroad (especially in Germany). She has three children and eight grandchildren.#YBM's mother came to Palestine with her husband in 1932, their house became a place to go for new immigrants after 1933. Her father was born in Koenigsberg, but spent his childhood and youth in Montreux, Switzerland. YBM only spoke German in her family, but it was forbidden to talk German outside. Her family was typically Yekkish. All of her family members learned and used their languages in different ways. Her parents had a large Yekkish circle of friends in Jerusalem. YBM grew up in an ethnically heterogeneous quarter near the university. She noticed social differences very early. She describes the distance of the Yekkes to Jews from Eastern Europe. She thinks that her growing interest in the Arab culture was a conscious setting herself apart from her family. Her parents were against her interest in the Youth movement, although her mother came to Israel as a Zionist.#YBM's grandmother on her mother's side came to Israel in the 1920s, she was a Hebrew teacher and acquainted with the intellectual elite. Her parents did not talk about the family history until their grandchildren showed interest. YBM had more information about her father and his three brothers, who all emigrated. Despite her early immigration, her mother had difficulties to assimilate in the Israeli society. She always said she never wanted to live anywhere else though. YBM talks about the difference between city life and the life in a kibbutz. She also talks about her school career and her resistance to her mother's wish to attend a technical college.#Military service brought YBM to Ramat David in 1963, she met her future husband there on the first day. Initially she felt attracted to the life in a kibbutz. She tells about their wedding and the birth of their first child. She did not want her children to grow up in the children's house, so they left the kibbutz. The relationship between her husband and her parents was rather reserved in the beginning, because his family came from Poland. In contrast she was welcomed very warmly by his parents: 'Yekke' seemed to be a good predicate to them. After leaving the kibbutz, life was very difficult for YBM and her family. She got many contacts with immigrants when she was teaching Hebrew. YBM analyzes the ideology behind the children's houses in the kibbutzim. She describes her life in the town Kiryat Bialik: she a lot of friends, the atmosphere was open-minded and spontaneous (in contrast to the Yekkish way of life in her parents' house).#YBM notices that the interests of her children's generation are more versatile than those of her own generation, which had to experience more armed conflicts. Despite the many antagonisms, YBM considers herself as Yekkish and recognizes herself when analyzing Yekkish culture and identity. She talks about her move to Amirim and her professional work. When her children went to military service she studied tourism at Haifa University. She works as a guide for tourists in Israel and for Israeli groups abroad.#Her father visited Switzerland for professional reasons in 1965, her parents then travelled to Europe several times. YBM's first stay in Berlin at the beginning of the 1990's, together with her husband, was not easy. Nowadays she has many friends in Germany through her work and has overcome the first difficulties. She considers Germany as a Western country which is very much influenced by the United States. YBM analyzes the importance to know the German language for establishing relationships in Germany. She tells about her guided tours to concentration camps in Poland and about her encounters with young Germans in Poland. She opposes the comparison of Nazi-Germany to the Israel of today. She speaks about the Second Intifada. YBM tells about guided tours on the Golan Heights and about how tourists react to the (political) reality about which they have not been correctly informed by the media. The Holocaust once was a taboo topic for Yekkes, while Jews from Eastern Europe on the contrary have always discussed their persecution. YBM tells her husband's story, whose parents emigrated in 1937 and 1939. She also tells about a visit to Poland.#YBM's her second daughter motivated her grandmother to tell her the family history on tape. YBM's children don't speak German and they are not interested in German or European passports. YBM analyzes the youth's attitude towards Israel and the growing tendency to emigration. She discusses Fanija Oz' book about Israelis in Berlin and analyzes the attitudes among the young generation towards Zionism and the idea of the Israeli State. YBM sees Israel as a country of migration and a model of cultural plurality. The new immigrants nowadays come with different motivations than the Zionists. YBM notices the increase of orthodoxy. Her grandchildren are very interested in the State of Israel. She describes the Mediterranean way of life. She also speaks about Arabic as compulsory subject and optional subject at school and makes observations on Israeli Arabs and the occupied areas. YBM also tells about a conference about Yekkes in Jerusalem and about invitations of former emigrants by German cities and the German-Israeli relationship today.

Book and Paper Hussein Tevfik Aydin (Turkey) G5939 14#Production period - beginning of the 20th century#Front Period - beginning of the 20th century#Category - Children#Description - This horizontal postcard depicts a colored photograph of the exterior school of Aydin, founded by the 'Universal Israelite Alliance'. Several children and their teacher are standing in front of the school, in the budding courtyard - boys on the left and girls on the right. The Universal Israelite Alliance (Alliance Israélite universelle) is a Jewish organization, founded in 1860 in France to protect human rights of Jews as citizens of countries where they live. In addition, the organization opened several schools in numerous country, particularly in Muslim countries. These schools aimed at furnishing a 'modern' education with French standards to the local Jewish youth; they were however opened to non-Jews. [S.H]

records.title: Second generation of immigrants from German speaking countries ("Yekkes").

descriptions.value: Eviatar Michaelis grew up in kibbutz Daliya. He could not serve in the army because of a heart disease, instead of that he worked for three years at the Youth Movement in Tel Aviv. Afterwards he studied Psychology. He works as child psychologist partly in kibbutz Daliya, where he lives with his family, partly in Haifa.#The first interview (2001): In EM's childhood half of the children in the kibbutz were Yekkish, the other half Romanian; their relationship was not very good. Later a third big group of holocaust survivors from Bulgaria joined the kibbutz, but their children were younger. Roots were not important in day-to-day life, but as a child, EM felt happy being a Yekke. His parents usually did not speak German at home, but when family visited they spoke German. EM's cousins also spoke German and EM could not understand them, therefore EM did not like German. Until now he does not like the language, but he does like listening to German music. As a child EM was proud that his parents knew Hebrew as well as German.#Because of EM's heart disease EM often stayed home and his mother stayed with him. For this reason EM had a closer relationship to his mother, but she was a complicated, very closed and depressive person, which influenced him. His father was closer to his sister, EM envied her and would have liked to spend more time with his father too. As he grew older EM's relationship with his father became better and closer, but the relationship with his mother became more and more problematic. In 1957 EM's father was sent to Germany by the kibbutz because of restitution affairs; he did not like it but felt obliged to go. His father was depressed in Germany, therefore the kibbutz sent his mother to Germany to give him psychological support. EM's mother was already an author in Germany and she tried to write in Hebrew as well. EM did not like her books, he did not appreciate her writing about him and his disease repeatedly. He considered her Hebrew as rather bad and is convinced his mother lost a part of her personality with the change of the language (he even speaks of a split in her personality).#The second interview (2005): Both of EM's parents died in 2004, for EM his father's death was more difficult to cope with. EM tells more details about his heart disease, he had a very rare heart operation in 1957. He couldn't do what the other children did. In the kibbutz the children lived in the children's house, whenever he was ill EM stayed at his parents' home instead. He felt ashamed to be always protected by his parents and it was difficult for him to find friends. Only during high school, outside the kibbutz, he started to feel some independence.#EM does not know a lot about his mother's family, because he did not ask. He knows much more about his father's family. His mother's brother lived in Israel as well; he was a philosopher and a complicated person and he criticized everything in Israel. He later returned to Germany with his wife, but he did not feel happy there either. EM's associations with the Yekkes are their culture, music, philosophy and academic education, he thinks they live by strict rules, e.g. their sense of order. He analyzes the differences between Romanians and Yekkes in the kibbutz, for instance they celebrated holidays very differently. EM preferred the Romanian way because of the better sweets. Yekkes used to plan their days. EM had a good relationship with a Yekkish friend of his parents, this friend introduced EM to music at the age of 7 or 8. EM saw his parents every day as a child, but their relationship was superficial and reserved. EM's children did not have a close relationship to their grandparents either. EM couldn't join the military when he was 18, but he did join later. He wanted to do something for the country and went to work with the Youth Movement in Tel Aviv for three years. Afterwards he studied Psychology, at first his parents did not appreciate this choice. His got much closer to his father when his mother became sick and EM started to take care of him. Their relationship already changed during a trip to Berlin in 1994, during which EM learned a lot about his father's past. EM thinks his mother was never able to speak openly to anybody. After her death he read his mother's poems, which she wrote in Hebrew and he likes them better than as a child. He kept many of his mother's writings and correspondences but he is not able to read her German texts.#EM analyzes the difference between Yekkes in the kibbutz and Yekkes in the cities. Yekkes who went to the kibbutz in the 1930s, like his parents, did so for ideological reasons, most of them were already left wing and/or in the Youth Movement in Germany. People recognize that EM might have Yekkish parents: he takes life more seriously than other Israelis. He explains that there are studies, that prove the third generation of survivors of the Shoa is more interested to work with children and help other people than other parts of the population. EM has difficulties showing his feelings. He tries to treat his children differently from how his parents treated him and tries to be more open to them. His wife comes from a very warm family; EM's relationship to his in-laws was easier than the relationship with his own parents. His wife's family came to Daliya when he was 18 years old and EM had a better connection to her mother than to his own mom.#EM only went to Berlin once, together with his father who has some friends there. However he was in Germany many times to see his relatives in Bad Reichenhall. During his youth, EM was involved in politics, but he has never become a member of a party. He now tries to mediate between Arabs and Israelis.

records.title: Jewish Underground Movement in the USSR in the 1930s and 1940s.

descriptions.value: Moshe Leder, the elder of two children, was born in Czernowitz, Bukovina in 1922 into a traditional family. He learned Hebrew from a very young age and studied in a prestigious Romanian high school. He joined the Zionist youth movement Hashomer Hatza'ir and turned Bolshevik and therefore he joined the International Pre-Komsomol, an underground organization. Russia invaded Romania in July 1940. Moshe was arrested several times by the Russian KGB for being counter revolutionist. On 12 June 1941, the Germans invaded Romania and 200,000 Jews from all over Romania and the Baltics were deported to Siberia. ML managed to escape alone to Kazakhstan where he served as a teacher of German and as a fisherman. Moshe became a devout socialist. He joined the Soviet Army in 1944 and was arrested after a short while for being a Trotskyist. He was sentenced for eight years of labor camp and exile: 12-14 working hours of building with meagre food. ML was severely wounded. His family started sending him packages with food and money, with which he bribed the camp authorities until he was freed. He returned to Judaism and Zionism through debates with his friends and started to look for Jews. Moshe was discharged in 1952 and went to Salekhard. He lived later in Vorkuta and took upon himself the mission of collecting Jewish books. He traveled to many towns for books - Riga, Czernowitz, Warsaw, Lviv, Vilna etc. and ordered books from all over Europe throughout the 1950s until his collection numbered into the tens of thousands. The problem was how to keep the books. He gave them to people and institutes who showed interest. ML lived in Simferopol (Crimean Peninsula). His Zionistic activity was known to everybody including the authorities.#Jewish youth gathered in his apartment for learning about Israel and Judaism. Moshe Leder describes in detail their enthusiasm to be a part of the Jewish people despite the risk. He announced his wish to immigrate to Israel, and was sentenced for political agitation. Eventually he was authorized to immigrate on June 1964. He went to Vienna and worked for a year with Simon Wiesenthal and immigrated to Israel in 1965. Since then he has been active in smuggling written material to Jews in the USSR. ML speaks 20 languages.

The results of betrayal by Jewish underground member.

Chana Golden was born in Czernowitz, Bukovina, Romania in 1922, the youngest of three daughters. When Chana was four years old, the family moved to nearby Jadova. Although her father Zygmund had a doctorate in law, he ran a lumber business together with his brother in laws. The family was financially comfortable. They were taught by a Jewish tutor who lived in their yard and attended the local elementary school. They were enrolled as external high school students in a different town in Bukovina. Despite multiple activities, Chana did not have many friends outside the family circle and was sometimes lonely. By the 1930s many professions were closed to Jews. Chana's parents were socialist, traditional, Zionist with a strong Jewish identity. In 1939, the family moved back to Czernowitz and stayed with her grandparents. The Russians entered Bukovina in June 1940 and confiscated their property and there were rumors that Chana's father was on a list to be exiled to Siberia. A year later, during the Barbarossa Operation, the Germans invaded Romania. When the Germans began bombing Czernowitz, Chana fled eastwards with her cousin and his wife and her parents were sent to Transnistria. Chana learnt Russian and worked in an office. She describes her daily life in Georgia. They were not allowed to listen to the radio and therefore felt very isolated. In 1944 the Russians recaptured Czernowitz and the family applied for permission to return home.#Chana then talks about the fate of relatives. Her sisters and grandparents remained in Czernowitz and except for one sister lived in the ghetto. A Romanian officer moved into her grandparent's home. His wife was Jewish and she offered to store their valuables saying that it was hers. After the Holocaust, she returned the valuables including a dinner service which a soldier tried to steal. After the war, the remaining members of the family reunited in Czernowitz. Chana's family then decided to apply to move to Romania. Chana and her parents left first travelling to Siret, Suchava, Bacau and Bucharest. At this point, Chana began to resume her matriculation studies and then secretarial studies in Bacau. She lived in Bucharest for two years where she was apprenticed to a cosmetician and also worked part time in an office. Chana describes her life and Jewish activity in Bucharest. Through her brother in law Otto, who was a leader of Massada Movement, the family was able to obtain certificates for Palestine. One evening, they were informed by Bricha activitsts that they were to leave that night and Chana describes their flight to Varna, Bulgaria. Two ships, the Pan Crescent and the Pan York were docked in Varna. The British tried to prevent the ships from reaching the Black Sea. Eventually after protracted negotiations, the ships with 15000 refugees aboard sailed to internment camps in Cyprus arriving in December 1947. She then describes life in the camp in Cyprus and her marriage to Chaim whom she met in Cyprus. After the War of Independence, they arrived in Israel and settled in Beer Sheva. Chaim worked for Solel Boneh and Chana first worked as a cleaner in Shekem and then worked as a cosmetician.

records.title: חג המולד בפסוטה 25/12/2015 (חגי חורף) חג המולד בפסוטה.

descriptions.value: בתיק: תצלומים שצילם דנצ'ו ארנון בתאריך 25 לדצמבר 2015, במהלך אירועי חג המולד בפסוטה ומעיליא, שני כפרים מלכיטים (יוונים-קתולים) בגליל. לפסוטה יש מסורת של חגיגות עממיות לכבוד חג המולד, שלושה ימים של שמחה עם בזאר של חג, מופעים, תהלוכות, אמני רחוב, אוכל ושתיה. בני כל הדתות מוזמנים לחגוג עם בני פסוטה. את הבאים לחגיגות מקבלים צעירי הכפר בסוכריות ובריקודים. עץ חג המולד הענק ניצב בחצר הכנסייה, עם מאות נורות צבעוניות ותאורה מתחלפת. גם בתי הכפר וסמטאותיו מקושטים בתאורה צבעונית לכבוד החג. מתקיימת תהלוכה של להקת דבקה דרוזית.בכנסייה המקושטת שוכב בסלסילה "ישוע התינוק" (רפליקה של הבּוּבּה שמככבת בטקס הקתולי של חג המולד בבית לחם. על פי המנהג העממי-כפרי נבטים מסמלים את הלידה וההתחדשות. ליד ה"אבוס" (Manger) מתקיים שחזור מערת הלידה.

records.title: Struggle in Poland for the Return of Jewish Children from Non-Jewish Environments after the Holocaust.

descriptions.value: UNED Born in Cracow, 1929, to well to do Polish speaking family. When about eighteen months old family relocating to Wieliczka. When Germans started concentrating local Jews in Wieliczka mother hiding with two daughters at Polish friend's house in Cracow. Grandmother hidden at Polish maid's house. Father sent to labor camp. When situation in Cracow worsening, relocating to Warsaw to aunt living outside the ghetto as a Christian. Aunt having Christian friends in the underground and those helping them get Arian papers. Mother and sister taken by the Germans with other Jews due to informing. Interviewee managing to escape. Reaching aunt who evacuated her to a friend, a countess, who had a farm and whose husband was senior member of the underground. Leaving after the war to look for her family. Contacting father through mother's Polish friend, that was contact person with father when in Plaszow camp. Discovering two young cousins also saved with the help of Polish friends. Wandering in Poland and finding the survivors from her family, bringing her to the conclusion that Poland is not a place for Jews. Joining Zionist nucleus group and immigrating to Israel.

Dr. Eddy Garfunkel was brought up in Bucharest in 1939. His family is from Galati, Romania. His father, Moritz, was a book keeper, the family was affluent and traditional. The family lived on the edge of the Jewish quarter. His maternal grandfather fought in the Turkish army during World War I. His father was a Zionist and unsuccessfully attempted to make aliyah a few times before the Holocaust. For example, they had tickets about the Struma but were not aboard the ship when it sunk. Eddy's father was arrested by Romanian Legionnaires and sent to forced labor in a labor brigade where he worked on making steel tracks. He returned home changed. Eddy and his mother fled to a small village near Bucharest where they paid a local farmer to hide them. After the war, the family returned to Bucharest and were reunited with Eddy's father. There he describes his interaction wtih children who had returned from exile to Transnistria. Eddy attended a public school, and began medical school. The family made aliyah in 1958 when he was 19.#Eddy speaks about the family's absorption in Israel. His father never regained his status, worked in low level jobs and lived his dreams through Eddy. Eddy himself suffered discrimination as an oleh and as a Holocaust survivor. He served in the army and finished medical school. His father never spoke about his experiences during the Holocaust. The information he has was from his mother. Eddy married a woman whose family is from Timisoara, they have two children. His son has just finished his service in the IDF and his daughter is about to be inducted. He speaks about his children's reactions to the Holocaust and to family survivors. He considers himself second generation and his children third generation. He was about to travel on a heritage trip to Romania.

David was born in Sighet Marmaţiei, Romania. His family were Vizhnitz Hassidim. They spoke Yiddish. David went to cheder and then to public and secondary school. He had 2 younger sisters who survived Auschwitz. David joined a Zionist youth movement, without telling his parents. He was in the partisans and spent time as a prisoner of war in Russia. After the war, he married Devorah and was sent to settle in the Sudetenland with other Jews. After many unsuccessful applications to emigrate, he and his family were given permission to immigrate to Israel. They lived in Tiberias. He served in the Israeli Police Force. Devorah talks a little about her Holocaust experiences. After the Holocaust, the Czechs treated the Jewish survivors well.

records.title: Testimonies from Holocaust Survivors in the United States.

descriptions.value: Discusses: Alliance between Czechoslovakia and Germany; Anti-Jewish Codex in Slovakia; Establishment of Jewish resistance; deportations and murder of locals; missions done for resistance (helping people escape; obtaining food; fighting Germans); people risking selves to help others; members of his group; capture and escape; treatment by non-Jews in Lipa; make-up, missions and interaction in Lipa.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Sofia, Bulgaria in 1923. Family neither Zionist nor assimilationist. Member of Betar youth movement. Family deported during WWII with all Jews of Sofiya. Arrival in Ruse. Return to Sofiya after war. Continuing studies. Sister immigrating to Israel, 1948. Family waiting for his graduation from technical school and not joining mass immigration to Israel of Bulgarian Jews. Aliya in 1950, among last Bulgarian families. Entrusting their property in Bulgaria to relatives who stayed behind. Welcomed by Israeli relatives. Various experiences in Shaar Haaliya. Living in a shack with another thirty people at Bat Galim immigrant house Later receiving private room and after one year moving to rented apartment. Finding employment as engineer at Barbur ceramic tiles factory in Akko. Father remained unemployed.

records.title: Struggle in Poland for the Return of Jewish Children from Non-Jewish Environments after the Holocaust.

descriptions.value: UNED Born in Warsaw, 1934. Only child of well off Polish speaking family. Parents having social and commercial contacts with Poles. After father had been taken away and conditions in the ghetto worsened, mother deciding to relocate to Aryan side with help (for a fee) of Polish acquaintances. Being separated from his mother. Suffering a lot due to separation. Relocated from one family to another for three years until 1944. In 1944 contact was established with mother's brother, an officer in Polish Army and a bachelor who could not keep him and thus relocated him to a convent. Due to pressure converting to Christianity and becoming the priest's assistant. Difficult living conditions: scarce food supply and harsh discipline. Taken out of the convent by wife of a cousin but due to their difficult economic condition transfered to Jewish childrens' house in Bielsko, one of communist orientation. Relatives who were Zionists later relocating him to Zionist childrens' house in Gliwice. Suffering much provocation by the other children due to Christian belief which took him a long time to forget. Aliya in 1948. Settling in moshav Talmei Yafe. Never forgiving his family for not taking him in.

records.title: Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Former mayor of Beer Sheva. Memories from 1947-1948, then engineer for Solel Boneh on the Southern Command in Israel, heading 300 workers. Only several secluded settlements in the Negev then with no water or defense. Organization of contact between Southern settlements and the army who took care of food supplies and protection. Camp settled in Nir-Am, until the front moved south and then settled in deserted houses in Beer-Sheva in 21.10.1948. This being the outset of the civilian foundation of the city. In 1949 when Golda Meir was Minister of Labor, resources were found for raw materials for building the city in the nearby dunes of Revivim. Connecting to water supplies from local wells and to electricity and telephone lines with minimum expenses and a lot of good will on part of the state authorities. 7,000 people in immigrant camp during snowy winter of 1950. Beginning of education in city conducted in schools from British mandate period. The Histadrut investing a fortune in Beer-Sheva out of a will to assist absorption of newcomers. Commending the establishment of the university in city which helps promote matters of culture and education. Claims that the government should take it to distribute the population and settle half of the forth million that will arrive to Israel between 1973-1983 in the Negev, with Beer Sheva as the central city in this district.
A view of a city from the sea.

records.title: Resistance Movement in the Cracow Ghetto during the Nazi Occupation.

descriptions.value: Born in Cracow, 1925. Activities as member of Hashomer Hatzair underground as a young boy. Bunker built by movement as rescue place at time of ghetto's liquidation aktion, with the intention to flee to the forests after that to continue activities from there. Missions outside the ghetto. His life since liquidation of the ghetto (13.3.1943). Transfered with his brother Moshe to Plaszow. Their survival. Liquidation of Mr. Chilevitz, successor of Simcha Shapira as head of the Ordenung-Dienst, the Jewish Police in Plaszow. Attitude of Jewish and Ukranian officers in the camp towards Jews. Cruelty of Jewish officers who hoped to gain favors for this in due time but were disappointed.

Born Morocco, 1936. Father died 1946. Discusses: family business; community's appointment of guardian over family when father died; mother continuing father's business once he died; other work she did to sustain family financially; studies; becoming involved in Zionist movement 'Habonim'; influence 'Habonim' had on his life and connection to Israel; hachshara in France; Aliyah, 1951.

records.title: The Zionist Underground in Soviet-Occupied Poland, 1939-1941.

descriptions.value: לפני המלחמה המרואיין (בן 21) שהה בהכשרת ברדום. עם תחילתה הוא וחבריו החלו לנדוד מזרחה, והתרחקו מהחזית הגרמנית. הגיע לביתו ברובנה, שם חווה את כניסתם של הרוסים. החל בתכנונים לחצות את הגבול הרומני. לאחר שהניסיון שכל והרוסים תפסוהו, נשלח למעצר ממושך בבתי הכלא הרוסיים. נושאים עיקריים בראיון: המצב בתחילת המלמחה בערים ובייערות שבהן עברו בדרכו מזרחה, הלכי הרוח ובעיות הקיום בשבועות הראשונים; השפעת הכיבוש הרוסי על פעולות התנועה, בעיות ההסתגלות לשלטונות ומציאת אלטרנטיבה. הנסיון הכושל לחציית הגבול לרומניה. השהייה במעצר בבתי כלא שונים. נשלח מזרחב להמשך מעצר וחקירה. תנאי הקיום במעצר ובדרכים בין מתקני הכליאה, הקשר עם אסירים אחרים (עם חבריו ועם אסירים אותם לא הכיר - גויים ויהודים).

records.title: Jalil el Qibliya : Jaffa sub-dist. Block plan reduction / Survey of Palestine תוקן והודפס ע"י מחלקת המדידות.
Absorption of the Mass Immigration to Israel 1948-1954.

descriptions.value: Born in Yemen. Immigration from Yemen in 1949 through Hashed Geula camp in Aden. Attended by emissaries of Jewish Agency. Defrauded of jewelry and valuables by fellow Yemenite olim and Ashkenazi emissaries. Messianism among Yemenite Jews while immigrating. Arrival in Rosh Haayin. Newcomers' hair and side-locks forcibly cut. Yemenite Mapai repesentatives objecting to Yemenite olim joining religious parties. Daily life and absorption process in immigrant camp. Disappearance of newborn baby from children's house and unfulfilled promises of his return. Relocation to Elyashiv transitional camp, 1951-1952. Enlisting in the Israel Defense Forces. Relocation to Emek Hefer transitional settlement, 1953-1954. Struggle between Histadrut and religious parties. Activities for promotion of religious education. Losing job due to membership in Hapoel Hamizrahi. Establishment of enquiry committee to investigate disappearance of Yemenite children.

records.title: Absorption of Jews from Arab Countries in Israel.

descriptions.value: Born Northern Iraq, 1923. Discusses: personal biography; making Aliya via Syria, 1938; arriving in Israel; serving in British police; being drafted to IDF, 1948; story behind establishment of Moshav Azaria, 1949; serving as social leader in moshavs of new immigrants; different jobs and appointments held - particularly involving new immigrants; education; wife and children, their education; living conditions; language spoken at home; food; social environment; religion; hobbies.
